A fascinating contribution to the rich global trend of blending documentary and fiction.
Snowed under by misjudgment on every level, The Big White is DOA.
Writer-director Matt Mulhern confidently anchors his drama-comedy about an alcoholic Atlantic City pit boss with good writing and sharp dialogue.
Lacks even the urge to find a sparkling angle on an overdone subgenre.
movie_title: National Lampoon's Barely Legal (After School Special) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Cooking up new Rube Goldberg torture contraptions isn't enough to get Saw II out of the shadow of its unnerving predecessor.
A nice auto-portrait.
A spare and almost unbearably tense drama.
Embodies the high-stakes risks inherent in switching between multiple genres, particularly considering the story's central point is nearly lost in the process.
A string of scenes in search of a movie.
An honorable but failed attempt to dramatize the dynamics that propel a basically good man to become a suicide bomber.
The care and craft exhibited by director Robert SchwentkeRobert Schwentke in Flightplan is largely undone by a script that self-destructs in the third act of an otherwise well-made thriller.

A true account of how a woman's intelligence and stoicism saves her huge family, The Prize Winner of Defiance, Ohio sensitively presents an unvarnished view of the 1950s and early '60s through the subtle filter of the present.
movie_title: The Prize Winner of Defiance, Ohio (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Family drama appears content to present the situation without going for anything remotely close to the emotional jugular.
Immensely engrossing.
Not content with a straight psychological police procedural, Alvart mixes in distracting -- and unconvincing --Biblical symbolism in a curious bid for weightiness.

A cheeky, somewhat suspect documentary on the battles between an icon of stoner comedy and the Feds, a/k/a Tommy Chong serves up a biased account of Chong's arrest and incarceration for manufacturing drug paraphernalia.
First-time feature director's disciplined objectivity is coupled with humanism in this collaboration with a gifted cast and cinematographer.
A thoroughly winning and unexpectedly observant lark.
Pic displays filmmakers Kevin Harrison's and Kemp Curley's love of snowboarding, but suffers from an unjustifiably long running time, considerable repetition and a generally awkward structure.
One of a number of American indie pics unveiled at Sundance but destined to go nowhere.
A classically made yet personally accented fable about the clash between old and new in a strange Andean village in Peru.
Uncovering why a great be-bop jazz singer fell into near-total obscurity is only one accomplishment of Raymond De Felitta's magnificent and moving 'Tis Autumn: The Search for Jackie Paris.
movie_title: 'Tis Autumn: The Search for Jackie Paris (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The concert film has never looked or sounded classier than Jonathan Demme's superbly crafted Neil Young: Heart of Gold.
Heidi Specogna's The Short Life of Jose Antonio Gutierrez sensitively and methodically tells the story of the first U.S. soldier killed in the 2003 Iraq invasion.
movie_title: The Short Life of Jose Antonio Gutierrez (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A golden opportunity to analyze the most vital and probably most creative contempo American playwright is missed.
The impossible personal and political quandaries experienced by ethnic Koreans living in Japan find gentle, touching expression in Yang Yonghi's docu.
Even if it overplays its ghoulish central concept, Subject Two honorably reps the neglected cerebral horror sub-genre.
Brings back nothing journalistically substantial from the war front.
The effect is one of a fabulous acting showcase more than a wholly finished work.
movie_title: A Guide to Recognizing Your Saints (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Plain wrap filmmaking that's single minded, capped with a pitch for organic eating that's much too weak.
Pic is influenced by the structure of standard Hollywood music biopics, and not always to its benefit.
movie_title: Two Sons of Francisco (2 Filhos de Francisco) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Any genuine emotions get smothered in inept humor.
Even in fantasy, an internal logic must apply.
movie_title: The Promise (Master of Crimson Armor) (Wu ji) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: The bark of The Ringer is far more outrageous than its bite.
Dangerous Men will strike horror in the hearts of anyone expecting coherence.
Thoroughly hapless and embarrassing.
... pic is never too insulting to the viewer, and works up a fair amount of goodwill by the good graces of Usher's Will Smithian charisma and an extremely attractive filmmaking package ...
Good-natured but only memorable as a platform for the amusingly feisty Peter Falk.
Topically urgent and ripe with outrage over the myriad injustices visited upon the African poor.
Niccol's script is finally too much for the film to hold onto.
Director Marilyn Agrelo is able to capture with easy charm and grace what happens between 10- and 11-year-old boys and girls as they break out of their childhood shells and interact with each other.
The illogic of the situation is so extreme that the final confrontation plays like an afterthought.
Eye-popping lensing and an appreciation of social complexities combine for an entirely satisfying experience.
Despite a reliable cast led by Scott, Patricia Clarkson and Peter Sarsgaard, the human impact is ultimately lost in a too calculated scenario.
The only thing that really matters is whether the action scenes push the envelope -- and they don't, especially compared with the extreme sports style of the first XXX.
...lacks even a penalty kick's worth of tension and is paradoxically inert for a movie about guys running up and down the pitch for the glory of the U.S.
Unconvincingly attempts to update the futurist dystopian traditions of Orwell, Huxley and William Gibson.

Cinderella Man takes the almost impossibly perfect elements of the saga of underdog boxer James J. Braddock and fills it with emotional gravitas, wrenching danger and a panoramic sense of American life during the Great Depression.
Commercials vet and tyro helmer Alejandro Lozano is more struggling traffic cop than director as plot's increasingly ridiculous complications bunch up into a knot.

Eisner shows himself to be a solid helmer of complex and beautifully staged action sequences with a sure ear for character interplay and an exact eye for glorious widescreen framing with nods to images from Lawrence of Arabia.
A blast and a half -- as entertaining as mainstream American docus get.
A thoroughgoing and affecting film on the nature and causes of the American military-industrial complex.
Irresistibly entertaining and full of unique character portraits.
Rupert Murray's unsettling mystery-of-the-mind movie, Unknown White Male, posits the simple notion that we are the sum of our memories.
Lame and inoffensive.
As the story further ramps up the complications, poor plot mechanics run pic off the road.
A string of fine, thought-provoking ideas.
A forgettable blur.
A beautifully observant and wholly unpretentious film with roots more in Cassavetes than Sundance-style showbiz.
Superficial and disconcertingly conventional.
[A] functional if thoroughly uninspired movie.
More a love letter from daughter Jenny to her father than a worthy portrait of Abel's caustic, media-savvy and mind-bending social comedy.
Feels stunningly familiar as it goes through the rote edicts of the scientific crew vs. toothy beastie formula.
As a cautionary drama on the price of fame, Undiscovered could not tread on more exhaustively discovered territory, and the result is a reel-by-reel trail of cliches.
Deeply lost in the woods.

Male exploitation denizens will file this under 'must-see,' but everyone else above legal age should consider the barf bags that distribdistrib Dinsdale Releasing is considering handing out during limited release.
Red Eye relies on hoodwinking an audience with its tension, so that the sheer illogic of the conspiracy plot can slip by without detection.
Messy admixtures of drama and mockery crucially undermine pic's serious message.
Rude, crude and, uh, cosmopolitan, Deuce Bigalow: European Gigolo waves the flag for R-rated politically incorrect studio comedy but doesn't top the laugh ratio of the first Deuce misadventure.
This overlong march will bore all but the most nobly patriotic of auds.
Depicts a nocturnal Caracas with tense energy while gingerly trying not to offend any political group in the current class wars embroiling Venezuela.
Aiming to join the Jerry BruckheimerJerry Bruckheimer/Michael BayMichael Bay school of American movie war games, Stealth is just too dumb to make the grade.
The Skeleton Key is unable to ward off the nasty spirits of formula screenwriting.
Pic's strange construction and pacing shed more heat than light.
As any revolutionary knows, there's a big leap between theory and practice, and that leap proves too much for tyro helmer Stephen Marshall's This Revolution.

Pic draws a full and balanced measure of the man, from his stratospheric rise to a remarkably humbling fall, and includes as thorough a study of the super-agent-turned-mogul's shady ties with organized crime as any feature docu could hope to muster.
movie_title: The Last Mogul (Life and Times of Lew Wasserman) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Never entirely convincing yet always watchable.
Pic's balance of emotional truth in the hands of a talented cast and charged by Medencevic's lensing and Kiril Dzajkovski's powerfully moody score, reps a bold step forward for Balkan cinema.
A frustrating example of convention-defying filmmaking that tries too hard to be different.
Though Stallone directs with little visual inspiration outside the ring sequence, he sticks to the original's up-from-the-streets spirit and rejects the slickness that had crept into the franchise.
Extremely limited and almost without purpose except as an organizing tool for party foot soldiers.
Pic holds to a dreamy mood and a radical aesthetic but, in the end, the extremely repetitive use of certain sound and images has truly diminishing returns.
Alternately breezy and profound, pic hits enough emotional chords to connect with auds.
An emotionally stunning journey of a father's return to his senses after a horrible accident.
The fact that 10 Items has a 72-minute playing time before credits (containing the seemingly obligatory outtake montage) only points to how slight it really is.
Pic's depiction of rising above is less a candy-coated inspirational pill and more a piece of solid dramatic fiction.
Kabul Express at once lamely revives buddy road pics and trivializes global politics.
Instead of delivering a wallop to the gut, The Colonel is too rigidly conceived to be anything more than a polite reminder of man's inhumanity to man.
A virtual template of every imaginable cliche of the musical biopic, pic suffers from a lack of narrative and character focus.

Mike Judge's Idiocracy is absolutely a satire for its time. What Judge is less sure of here than in his previous, perfectly pitched live-action comedy Office Space, is how to build a complete movie around his key ideas.
The best version by far of the Lassie story, an ocean away from the sappy June Lockhart TV series.
The underground version of basketball known as streetball comes above ground in Crossover, but the fascinating freeform game gets screened out by a ludicrous soap opera with poor dramatic moves.
An especially vapid and woefully unoriginal look at why young, innocent white guys should never get into the drug trade.

While it doesn't reach the level of visceral -- or dramatic -- impact of Friday Night Lights, Invincible generally gets the game's physical nature right, most ironically via Core's choice of slo-mo action shots.
Ghost throws its most powerful punch in its second half, reporting on contempo events as a direct repeat of the ghastly Leopold era.
The teens this time resemble only those processed through TV's feel-good filter.
A dumbed-down remake of Kiyoshi Kurosawa's disturbingly abstract Japanese horror film.
A terribly sentimentalized account of a Japanese father's quest to understand what captured the interest and imagination of his estranged son.
movie_title: Riding Alone for Thousands of Miles (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A tendency toward broad novelistic storytelling... robs Sweet Mud of a focus.
Pic is truly undone by a bizarre structure that constantly cuts between the timeframe before the 100-day massacre and the aftermath.
Only occasionally effective in its telling of a loving mother's frustrated attempts to clean up her daughter's act.
Unfortunately, much of the pic suggests a quality family film that could have been directed by dozens of other pros.

Though it never disguises its sympathies for Kasparov and contempt for a powerful corporation's machinations, docu is finally a speculation on the limits of the human mind and how truth can never be fully known.
movie_title: Game Over: Kasparov and the Machine (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A psychological thriller that establishes interesting situations only to lose its sense of direction.
The important and intriguing issue of classified global audio surveillance of private citizens is all but garbled in The Listening.
Fascinating if overly self-involved Slamdance entry is among the few U.S. pics that deliberately smudges the line between non-fiction and invention.

With Sally Field as the cancer-ridden mom and the combined talents of Ben Chaplin, Julianne Nicholson and Tom Cavanagh surrounding her, pic veers unsteadily between melodrama and light comedy, with no confidence in either.
Continually tickles the mind while leaving a heavy lump in the chest, establishing and sustaining a unique low-key tone of mystery and dread.
Pic's weak ending demonstrates that its multi-narrative strategy, though full of cinematic potential, also holds traps for a film's overall impact.

Cinema's natural felicities for time and action have seldom felt as beautifully dovetailed. And even when the plot in Bill Marsilii and Terry Rossio's script begins to push plausibility, it stays grounded in Washington's emotional drive.
... charmingly quaint ...
What begins as a faintly unsettling Twilight Zone riff, soon becomes deadly with repetition and a lack of ideas.
Curse of the Golden Flower, Zhang Yimou's strangest and most troubled film, abounds in hysterical, mannered Tang Dynasty-era palace intrigue and dehumanized CGI battle sequences.
Jauretsi Saizarbitoria's and Emilia Menocal's film serves as a metaphor about artistic freedom and wiliness.
A bigger problem lies with Leigh Whannell's script, which utilizes so many flashbacks and explanatory inserts that the tension, a defining feature of the first Saw, is lost.
It's hard to imagine even devout Catholics coming away from the film without a sense of rage at a religion that appears to value members of the priesthood over the well-being of children.
Pic's midsection, with the increasingly likable Zack threatening to overcome Vince's early lead, is unexpectedly funny and involving.
Pic's rough production values and flubbed comedy contrast with the amusing and plentiful voice-over narration and the dazzling graphic design that suggests Peter Max on ecstasy.
movie_title: The Boys & Girls Guide to Getting Down (2007)

movie_review_blurb: As coffee drinkers know, not all beans are equal, but the meaning of inequality gets an entirely different spin in Marc and Nick Francis' handsome and astute doc, Black Gold.
If there were a 99 Cents Store for movies, cheapo pic -- designed more for lonely male geeks in their teens and above than the date crowd -- would fit nicely on the shelves.

Simultaneously teasing and loving a subject doesn't make for easy comedy, but writer-star Will Ferrell and director/co-writer Adam McKay pull it off with good-ol'-boy good nature in Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby.
movie_title: Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A perfectly respectable second entry in the saga of gay private eye Donald Strachey.
movie_title: Shock to the System: A Donald Strachey Mystery (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Though it can't hide occasionally crude dramatics, pic is an undeniably bold and daring tragedy.
Intriguing and surprisingly witty.
She's the Man gathers up enough energy and likeable goodwill that it almost skirts past some extremely strained passages in which Bynes plays out being a boy.
Odyssey is laden with symbolic gestures denoting a nation in search of itself, but the pic suffocates in its own cuteness.
Too routine to stir up much energy or portent about the present-day impact of the mysterious disappearance in 1755 Princeton, Mass.

Pic is hermetically sealed in a synthetic wrapping that's so total -- Sony's top-flight high-def cameras, visibly low-budget CG work, exceptionally hackneyed and imitative action and dialogue --that it arrives a nearly lifeless film.
There's a distinct letdown after an astonishing and unexpected opening section, as if the gravitational pull toward trash-kitsch horror was too much to resist.
A head-scratcher supreme -- not least for pondering what possibly attracted Robin Wright Penn to her intractable, impossible role -- Jeff Stanzler's Sorry, Haters is sorry indeed.
Humane, visually exquisite and resists simple descriptions while moving toward a more mainstream non-fiction form.
16 Blocks does raise the banner for the tradition of the textured urban cop drama, spurred by action but made substantial by characters at crossroads.
Director-lenser Howard Hall's return to the depths should have been more urgent than Into the Deep, but instead, it's more superficial.
Because it's bolstered by proud memories of Vietnam vets who turned against the war, Sir! No Sir! rings with an exultant, even elated tone.
Black comedy doesn't get much clumsier than Jay Floyd's Forgiving the Franklins.
Making something beautiful out of the grime, labor and noise of the dragster circuit, Kevin Jerome Everson continues his string of fascinating doc-dramatic hybrid films.
An instant classic of contempo American non-narrative cinema.
Pine Flat is a stunning and intense contemplation of children in nature.
A kind of comic variation on the Stations of the Cross transferred to the ordeals of a Gotham playwright, pic feels indifferent and empty.
Pic and its ambitions are undermined by insistent cartoonishness and comic ineptitude.

For a film that depicts the filthy, dangerous work of building the second level of Mexico City's Periferico freeway, the unlikely beauty of Juan Carlos Rulfo's In the Pit is just one of the surprising complexities of [this film].
The potent cast, Tony Vitale's assured direction and a solid foundation with lead thesp Patrick Cupo adapting his own play help mitigate many of the pic's deficiencies.
A would-be comedy that suffers from a lack of energy and imagination.

The fusion of effects-fueled action fantasy with comedy worked well for director Ivan Reitman 22 years ago in Ghostbusters and, less so, five years ago in Evolution. But, it fails to save his latest, My Super Ex-Girlfriend.
Gustavo Loza's excessively heart-tugging triptych of three youngsters venturing from home and into unknown territory, contains one-third of a fine film crowded by much weaker material.
Shadowboxer admirably jostles and upends the fatigued killer-for-hire genre.
Sloppy but unconcerned about it...
Sustains a disturbing, somnambulistic mood...
Strikes all the familiar notes and no new ones.
It doesn't hang together, and acting and black-and-white lensing defeat Shupe's vision...
An original and resonant feature debut by co-directors-writers-editors Randy Walker and Jennifer Shainin.

John Maringouin's emotionally raw Running Stumbled makes the term 'dysfunctional family' quaint and insufficient.
[The Lake House is] for profundity through multiple story levels that aren't fully realized.
Jindabyne never obtains the full impact of its potentially powerful inner core.

For a guerrilla-style, no-budget Yank indie to even tackle issues of jihad terror and naive Western thinking is noteworthy in itself, but Gamazon and Dela Llana inflame the issues with a gutsy, athletic filmmaking package.
No amount of last-reel optimism will cool the anger of progressive-minded auds.
A keen vet docu-maker's eye and a chronicler's compassion lends pic real resonance.
So under the spell of the be-here-now philosophy of Dan Millman's New Age-y memoir from which it was drawn that it loses sight of the need to credibly dramatize the ideas.

The use of the prim but rigorous world of women's gymnastics as a setting for teen rebellion is so strained it leaves the pic's ode to personal authenticity feeling as phony as a dubious decision by a competition judge.
What could have been solipsistic is a lovely and genuine account of generational understanding, and a wonderful display of the inherent advantages of the tiny 24p vidvid camera.

That such a place even exists may seem extraordinary, but director Laura Gabbert wisely doesn't trumpet Sunset Hall itself. Instead, her vid-shot docu reveals what a special place this is through the vector of her heroines, Irja Lloyd and Lucille Alpert.
De Niro infuses his familiar NYC cop identity with a feeling of near-exhaustion and emotional fatigue, the outward face of a man who has been privately suffering for years.
Some chilling characters are on display.
movie_title: The Letter: An American Town and the 'Somali Invasion' (2005)

movie_review_blurb: All of the original's formulas and alternating tones of goofball antics and deadly serious conflict are studiously yet fluidly preserved in this superior sequel.
Gina Wendkos' screenplay dutifully installs roadblocks in Mia's path, but her future as princess is never in doubt; it's in her training where the comedy should lie, but virtually never does.
America's Sweethearts begins as a smartly promising, gently farcical comedy of manners and ends as sourly and haphazardly as the lives it is poking fun at.
Restoring the seductive style of the no-nonsense procedural heist movie to complete luster, this is the kind of pic that knows the difference between being masculine and being macho.
In many ways, this is the East Asian equivalent of the old Europudding productions, where international players have created something that's more cacaphonous than melodious.

Darts back and forth from being a psychological thriller to a vaguely metaphysical drama to a fate-driven romance. Such a schema may, in the right hands, make for a powerful, all-seeing movie; here, it all becomes a blur.
The Animal is never more nor less than stupid, but stupid in ways that deliver goofiness rather than rampant humiliation.
Like the human body it imagines as a sprawling metropolis, Osmosis Jones has some precincts operating at peak efficiency, and others in need of urban renewal.
A pinpoint study in what not to do with an adaptation, as well as in why altering a well-known fictional character to suit a poorly cast star is almost always a bad idea.
movie_title: What's the Worst That Could Happen? (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Stuffed with the most obvious points imaginable.

It's not a good hair day for Blow Dry, in which The Full Monty writer Simon Beaufoy tries to mesh melodrama and camp, but comes up with merely a fraction of the inspiration of his previous international hit.
Seldom have movie co-stars been ordered to stoop so low in a film's sorry quest for laughs
Dunst can't really hold pic together.
The crisp images and Bill Foster's unnerving ambient sound of hovering copters enormously aid this low-budget powder keg.
Darren appears to be so idiotic that he's hardly worth saving.
With its themes of racial harmony and good high school kids realizing their dreams, pic avoids easy exploitation.
Deadly dull when it should pulse with the realities of what was one of Europe's most electric and fecund cultural periods, Bride of the Wind virtually defines the costume drama at its most starchy.
Little remains after Jade Scorpion is over other than a hazy nostalgic sense for a time that most viewers never knew and that Allen himself was barely old enough to remember.
movie_title: The Curse of the Jade Scorpion (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Although aimed at restoring the psychological horror movie to full life after years of dormancy, Session 9 is little more than an overworked exercise in jostling red herrings, and not particularly fresh herrings at that.
Less a movie than another efficient moneymaking machine for Universal Pictures, American Pie 2 is a remarkably boring comedy.
As a project to place Bruce Lee's final, unfinished 1973 film, The Game of Death, in its proper context, Bruce Lee: A Warrior's Journey is up to the task.
As with too many studio pics, plot mechanics get in the way of what should be the lighter-than-air adventure.
Jacobson produces a remarkably creepy piece of cinema that disturbs by suggestion, nuance and ambiguity.
In the end, alas, the obvious interests of an actor of Sinise's range and depth are subsumed to the blunt demands of a standardized chase movie.
Undone by its best intentions, I Am Sam is an especially insipid example of the Hollywood message movie.
[L]ike a string quartet performing a half-beat off, the team behind Chocolat only occasionally captures the story's essential tones of absurd tragedy and comedy.
Burning with a quiet intensity, Monster's Ball is bolstered by a poetic, intelligent sensibility not seen in an American film since Terrence Malick's The Thin Red Line.
Edet Belzberg's fearless aesthetic is also a measure of her film's brilliant indictment of any society that can allow its most vulnerable to slip into oblivion.
Having gone through a few different titles on its ignominious path to the big screen, Glitter deserves yet another title: A Star Is Dull.
There's no cork inside Hardball, but there's more than enough corn.
Despite being helmed by Robert M. Young, who knows more than a bit about docus and drama, China immediately plays as a wooden period piece.
There's nothing in genredom quite so unhinged as the badly made psycho-thriller, and long before it's over, The Glass House collapses from wretched design and execution.

Few recent movies have conceived their central female character more contemptuously -- a fanatic for a lifestyle that appears to have come from the bestselling The Rules and someone who is obviously set up for a satiric fall.

A movie about the gullible and pitched to the naive, Rock Star struggles to resist being as generic as its title, but is never more than just another replay of the hoary postulate that showbiz is all about rising, falling and being redeemed.

What's almost charming about Carpenter's new film is that he doesn't seem concerned about providing auds with their weekly fix of new screen effects but instead prefers his space adventure on the funky side, even if that means the funk gets ridiculous.
Confusing a serving of beefcake for real chow, American Outlaws sadly symbolizes the decline of the Western.
There are no winners in Rat Race, only a lineup of comic actors running on empty long before the dust settles.
This is minor stuff more suited to an up-and-comer than an established marquee headliner.
Obediently follows the verities of the submarine movie and its true story origins but without the imagination needed to refresh the genre.
Bears outs the wisdom of the shift from the original, serious conception to this comedic one.
Running Free is the only evidence anyone will ever need to demonstrate what a ruinous trend wallpapered narration has become.
Tech work is exemplary, and sometimes astonishing.
A devilishly energetic vehicle that contains about as many laughs as his previous features combined.
This pacifist spirit of brotherhood echoes the heroics in Princess Mononoke and other anime titles, but the artistic gap between the Miyazaki masterpiece and this project is huge.
movie_title: Pokemon the First Movie - Mewtwo vs. Mew (1999)

movie_review_blurb: Animation work is generally far below the standard tolerable for the bigscreen.
Mangold's camera has zero energy, making this probably the oldest-looking movie by a young director out of Hollywood this year.
Flaws and all, this is superior family entertainment in the tradition of quality that co-producer Mark Johnson has long championed.
Harvey is pretty much flawless.
The hope that Shelton would bring fresh insight to the sweet science is unfulfilled on nearly every level.
An interesting, if deeply unbalanced, combo of random shots of South Bronx street life.
Ultimately fails in its ambitious cinematic and narrative goals.
Wonderland feels contrived.
Utterly lacking the drive and roller-coaster energy expected of top action pics, this latest try at repackaging Speed is a Kmart version of a Jerry Bruckheimer production.
Ludicrous premise and slim thrills!
This rambling and episodic autobiographical saga of three friends coming of age in Inglewood, Calif. in the '80s is so determined to be likable that it forgets to be interesting.
Dramatically, the tragedy couldn't possibly be flatter.

The bucolic wonder buried in Luc Besson's Arthur and the Invisibles has been snuffed out by this alienating and dislikable animated film. As overproduced and acrid as The Messenger: The Story of Joan of Arc and The Fifth Element.
movie_title: Arthur and the Invisibles (Arthur and the Minimoys) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Thesp voicings are outstanding, and sometimes reach the level of comic warmth of the Toy Story ensemble.
Warts and all, Fantasia 2000 is a glimpse of the future.
A formulaic spy thriller with an intricate puzzle-box story and action that speeds along nicely once it gets going.
The makers of The Thirteenth Floor never figured out how to build a dramatically intriguing story around the concept!
Result is uneven; the story's more serious intentions often jar with the goofy sideshow.
Is a combo of thrills, juicy one-liners and fine star turns by Kevin Bacon and Elisabeth Shue.
The lightest, most forgettable item yet backed by Phoenix Pictures.
The thrills are such a rush, however, and the balance of digitized and analog effects is generally so satisfying that pic's sheer dumbness finally becomes part of the fun.
The results are disconcertingly bland under Reginald Hudlin's direction.
In the wake of a summer of capers and cons, Blue Streak arrives as a dull afterthought and a sorry vehicle for the comic expression of Martin Lawrence.
Relentlessly mediocre.
Too calculated by half and underwritten by about as much, as witlessly unaware of its faltering sense of comedy as its stoner-dude heroes are of everyday reality.
In his big bid for Hollywood stardom, Chow lacks what gave him star power to begin with: an intensely masculine soul of fire and ice.
Mild and underwhelming.
Despite numerous cutaways to juice things up, a movie that once moved becomes static and verbal in the stretch.
Nothing more than an ultra-formulaic Hollywood romantic fantasy grafted onto Belfast.
Double Jeopardy is single-minded and engaging thriller storytelling without an afterglow.
Begins with considerable charm but eventually loses its winning ways with an excess of ridiculous elements.
Ultimately a mechanical wind-up contraption that shoots out little buzz-bolts every few minutes to keep you on edge.
Few stars of late have displayed more sheer joy in a mainstream project than Jackson does here.
A studio-manufactured product with no reason for being other than to exploit millennial angst, this film is better titled End of Schwarzenegger.

The script by Parker and Laura Jones also borrows massive chunks of McCourt's narration, in voice-over style, but the result is constantly to tell us rather than show us, or worse, tell us what we've already been shown.
A sequel that's much too big for its britches.

This ill-conceived and expensive project winds up looking like a bunch of talented thesps slumming it.
Andersen's key accomplishment is to profoundly alter the viewer's assumptions of what is good in movies.
Except for brief injections of camp administered by John Waters' vet Mink Stole ... and Dom DeLuise, there's little in Girl Play that doesn't evaporate by closing credits.
The movie is never more than a hesitantly filmed recording of the play.

What could have just pushed the usual youth comedy buttons is instead a crafty spoof on issues from racial politics to American highway monoculture that belies its cover (and marketing) as only a dumb gross-out laffer.

movie_review_blurb: The goulash suggests a scaled-down but feature-length edition of what could have been an Imax film (and certainly would have benefited from Imax's usual under-an-hour running time) or, worse, one of those deadly educational films of yore.
movie_title: What the Bleep Do We Know!? (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A determined and often affecting romance that doesn't speak down to audiences.
Contrived and emotionally incomplete, and strained further by self-consciously cockeyed dialogue.
No one without a working knowledge of the fabulously profitable Manga-turned-gamer phenomenon will find it easy to enter here.
In tripling the original length, the film's delightfully pointed mockumentary aspects are combined with a pallid chain of sketched-in characters reacting to events.
Filmmakers Ferne Pearlstein and Robert Edwards display considerable sensitivity to the sport's near-holy status in Nippon culture.
Envy can't decide whether to be an eccentric black comedy or a middle-of-the-road diversion.
Too inconsequential and too earnest to belong in the So Bad It's Good category; rather, it's merely bad.
A repetitive, globe-hopping Imax project that dresses up well-known ecological truisms with pretty nature photography.

A moving portrait of the late Haitian radio personality who campaigned for democracy, Jean Dominique.

Both an inspirational sports movie and an unexpected multi-level urban drama that plays by its own clock.

Shows both how far Hollywood's tech departments have advanced in 40 years and how shallow the pool of solid action thesps has become.

An unusually intelligent adventure film scaled for younger viewers, which never leaves adults behind.
Far more jocular, good-natured and thoughtful than Moore partisans might expect.
As a return volley to Moore's cinema, Celsius shares Moore's blatant agit-prop but none of his humor or entertainment sense.

As a true or accurate portrait of the real Iraq ... pic pales in comparison to various in-depth U.S. and European reports, and to Bahman Ghobadi's brilliant new drama on wartime Kurdish refugees, Turtles Can Fly.

Will intrigue only those interested in the nooks and crannies of Mamet's career.

movie_review_blurb: Though obstacles are de rigeur in this kind of comic formula, the ones applied in Along Came Polly have the effect of reminding viewers of how unrealistic the pairing of Reuben and Polly is.
Stuffed with attitude but just as hackneyed as the original.

This is surely one of the most frantic, virulent and foul-natured Christmas season pics ever delivered by a Hollywood studio.

movie_review_blurb: Comedy's cardinal rule is never make it look hard, but that wisdom is ignored in My Boss's Daughter.

The animation doesn't display the kind of artistic advances that would compensate for the underdeveloped story.
An assured example of storytelling artistry.

Emotionally deeper than Corbijn's pic, [Control] in its portrayal, using fine one-on-one interviews to reveal the terrible regrets and guilt that wracked everyone in and near the band about [leadsinger Ian] Curtis.

... a cogent, almost intuitive study of female self-identity and body perception, and would be inconceivable without star Silvia Perez.
Despite both Steen as a thesp and Jensen as a writer making their early international impact with Dogma works, the austere verities are long gone here.

So unspeakably bad is screenwriter John August's debut as director, so hilariously unaware is the film of its overweening pretensions that it's tempting to want to deem it a Hollywood writer's fever dream.

A monumental if cheeky culmination of the French New Wave.

movie_title: Glass: A Portrait of Philip in Twelve Parts (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Even the long, long waits between goals in a match on the pitch are more enthralling.

An extraordinary debut.

Touching if by-the-numbers.
Unexpectedly amusing and inevitably disturbing.

One seriously confused documentary.

movie_title: Before the Devil Knows You're Dead (2007)

Bright and witty physical and optical visual touches spill off the screen, though the use of effects is scaled to the tale.

Little more than a slipshod, trashy, sometimes exploitative thriller.
