Faults aside, it is still a return to form for Kormakur, as his recent foray into Hollywood certainly was met with a drop off in quality (Everest had about 5,000 characters climbing the mountain including Jake Gyllenhaal who literally had nothing to do)

Regardless of its flaws, the strong character work and their associated performances keep everything afloat. Skarsgard is also allowed to deliver a far more twisted take on Pennywise. Bring on the 27 years later chapter
Coco is dealing with life and death in ways that will genuinely move just about anyone that watches it
Where is the conflict and why should I care about any of this?
Rebel in the Rye works when Nicholas Hoult and Kevin Spacey are ironing out the creative process together, but past that it's a bore
American Assassin will satisfy those looking for mindless gunplay and a desire to see the world rain blood
The Villainess is determined to make audiences remember every bombastic segment of carnage
I didn't feel any love tonight, but I sure felt a lot of pain being dished out by one Sir Elton John
Even after the hostility and the circus preamble, the matchup ends with a classy handshake, one that will continue to spark discussion and change backward thinking
Friend Request is an incompetent, ghastly looking, woodenly acted, unintentionally howlingly hilarious, nonsensical mess of a fright feature
The road to recovery is filled with both the good and bad sides of Jeff Bauman, and thankfully so, as that's what makes a biopic truly captivating

Visuals should always service the story, which is why Tom Ford (another fashion designer turned director) has found success, and that's the lesson that the Mulleavy's should take away from their misfire of a feature debut
The Mountain Between Us falls right off a cliff, dipping down from a serviceable tale of inspirational survival into over the top, melodrama cheese

Antiheroes require an actor that radiates charisma, so it's no shock that Tom Cruise (reunited with Edge of Tomorrow director Doug Liman) makes for a likable drug runner, gun smuggler, and greedy scumbag whose financial thirst cannot be quenched
It's an arresting blend of artistic and blockbuster sensibilities that will stand the test of time right beside its trailblazing predecessor

The Meyerowitz Stories (New and Selected) is Noah Baumbach continuing to provide authentic portraits of upper-class dysfunctional families, only this time he has unleashed three career-best performances (Adam Sandler, Ben Stiller, and Dustin Hoffman)

Zahler is still growing as a filmmaker (he hopefully will learn that more isn't always better) and on the cusp of crafting a truly great piece. Until then, enjoy this gruesome work of character-driven brutality that is Brawl in Cell Block 99
Aronofsky is once again challenging audiences in the maniacal, extreme way he has perfected. Prepare for unabashed, unforgettable madness

Doubles down on visual grandeur to such a scale that despite how frustratingly flawed and occasionally downright abysmal the storytelling is, the summer blockbuster is one that absolutely needs to be seen on the big screen
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It loses its way and literally becomes another A Christmas Carol, so why watch this when one countless other and undeniably better adaptations exist?
The side-by-side comparisons during the ending credits will leave you speechless if you're magically not already dead from laughing

There probably is room to create a complex character study of Sarah Winchester, but instead, the experience is only concerned with giving screen time to a bullet containing sentimental value engraved "together forever"

Peter Rabbit is a curious combination of tried and true British humor and the standard components that make up most younger geared American animated talking animal features; as it stands it's decent real-life/cartoon hybrid fun for the whole family
The only question left is who will despise The Cloverfield Paradox more; fans of the franchise or those turning it on seeking some sci-fi escapism
It's not inaccurate to say that The 15:17 to Paris succeeds better as a European touristic attraction rather than a look at average-Joe bravery

Societal stature and class rank make no difference in regards to how poorly Marina is treated by people, and one can safely assume that the issue isn't exclusively Chilean. Hopefully, A Fantastic Woman can also become an agent of education for America
If Christian Grey was ugly and worked at McDonald's he'd be either arrested or on an FBI watchlist.
The strong ensemble cast is unable to do anything of interest with the script; it's far too self-indulgent and offputting
Michael Pitt also makes a special guest cameo appearance, except his line delivery is so forced and awkward it feels as if he doesn't even want to be there, and truthfully, I can't blame him

Have a Nice Day has fair comparisons to Quentin Tarantino, specifically his bank heist debut masterpiece Reservoir Dogs and is broken up into chapters, but it lacks interesting dialogue, memorable characters, and an engaging narrative
movie_title: Have a Nice Day (Hao Ji Le) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: If Wakanda, invisible to the naked eye yet brimming with futuristic technology that could better the entire planet, is a beautifully depicted metaphor for representation, then Killmonger is a manifestation of African-American pain past and present

Things are just as bleak at the end as they began, driving home the point that citizens, absolutely women, have every right in the world for wanting to seek refuge in more hospitable, progressive, developed, countries

The introduction sees Dominika's beloved dancing career ended by a nasty leg injury, but following her first espionage mission, she is an infinitely stronger woman in both body and mind, and really, that's the world's best weapon
It's a must watch for anyone that values relationships; the trio of women are unequivocally absorbing
I admire what Heather Graham was going for with her directorial debut (it's definitely coming at the right time), but there's not a fraction of magic here, let alone half

A fine script boasting confident direction that gets terrific mileage out of its diverse ensemble of independent actors, all while set against a Chicago backdrop, make Rogers Park worth checking out and pondering over after the credits roll
Annihilation is high-minded science fiction where only those who actively enjoy thinking about and dissecting multiple themes need apply
Even though during the final act it's difficult not to mentally check out, there's fun to be found in its slightly demented zaniness, all fitted with a dark and electronic score from Cliff Martinez

Chock full of surprises up its sleeve, especially in that it's a thriller of errors beginning unlikable that over time reveals itself to be twisted and thoughtful, commenting on gender politics and more

From a romantic standpoint, the most beautiful aspect of Love, Simon is that through nothing but emails it's believable that these two students could fall for one another; it's not about physical appearances or social status or anything superficial

Eli Roth's ultraviolent revenge trip adds nothing worthwhile to the gun laws conversation... it chooses to exploit the situation for the sake of violence and macho entertainment. Just roll with the throwback 80's action vibe and mindless carnage

For those willing to have their patience tested, Loveless does serve up a provocative examination of relationships and how toxicity can affect those closest to them. Just like the gray, colorless visual palette, it doesn't offer much optimism
Transitions back and forth from being a glorified play to a made-for-TV looking political drama, but well-meaning and educational
Despite director Ava DuVernay's strongest imaginative efforts and ambitious aspirations, like a character in the visual spectacle says, "in order to be great, you actually have to be great"

Increasingly grows more over-the-top every passing minute; by the end it feels as if Burlap Sackman's depiction could be sued as plagiarism of Resident Evil 4 over how much damage he soaks up without dying (all he is missing is the trademark chainsaw).
Gringo has an ensemble cast of eccentric characters but director Nash Edgerton is unsuccessful at bringing out the true zaniness within them that is begging to be unleashed

Haneke is admirably reaching to examine sensitive subjects regarding mental health and social media in a serious way, it's just frustrating that something this cold and directionless is the finished project.
The Legend of Tarzan adds nothing to the legacy and really has no purpose for existing unless you REALLY want to see Alexander Skarsgård's shirtless chiseled up body for almost 2 hours
Honestly, if the filmmakers cut out the numerous filler subplots and took a more playful approach, Den of Thieves might have been entertaining.
12 Strong easily could have been another mid-January true story war drama coasting off of jingoism and an unnecessary thirst for violence, but it instead humanizes the inner conflict in Afghanistan
It's as forgettable as the others, but at least I wasn't ready to fall asleep this time

Of course, considering that a good amount is ludicrous and unrealistic, there are a frustrating number of plot gripes, but thankfully nothing too bothersome factoring in that it is so damn sexy, thrilling, and rich in romantic metaphors
Buckley's script and direction frequently get sidetracked with fictional subplots and bizarre animated sequences that feel wildly out of place
Mara and Mendelsohn are able to provide layers to the troubling past and present of their characters that, in the wrong hands, could have resulted in an irredeemable piece of creepy trash
There hasn't been a historical figure this convincing and meticulously brought to life since Daniel Day-Lewis put on the iconic black top hat to play Abraham Lincoln

It will go down as one of the most magical fairy-tales of its generation and is so mesmerizing that Pan's Labyrinth no longer holds the title of Guillermo del Toro's masterpiece. The Shape of Water is the absolute best film of the year.

Say what you will about Wonder Wheel, but it remains committed to tragedy and melodrama with a self-awareness so in-your-face, it mitigates some of the 1950's Coney Island-set relationship drama's irritating aspects
The Post parallels and thoughtfully expands on the modern-day political landscape while simultaneously functioning as sharply written journalistic detective work

Reynolds mentions that he likes to leave hidden notes and messages stitched into the dresses he creates as a way of forever imbuing that individual garment with a piece of himself; Daniel Day-Lewis does the same in every single one of his performances
Utilizes Bill Pullman's manly qualities to good effect as a gruff, Southern twang speaking, bodyguard/close friend on a path of justice and worth fulfillment.
No one can say that Star Wars: The Last Jedi is a previous entry in a different skin as Rian Johnson has crafted an installment that largely defies saga standard narrative structure and tone
Bookended by a charming beginning and ending, Ferdinand loses its way through the middle stretch quickly becoming the type of animated feature every critic dreads watching and writing about.

A coming-of-age story exploring one's first experience with true love and sexual uncertainty, including the hypnotic pleasures of both physical and intellectual affection balanced against bittersweet heartbreak

Dwayne Johnson has an elaborate melee fight through a bazaar that is so in tune with actual video games it is impossible not to start playing air controller with synchronized button presses to him emphatically announcing his every action
Christopher Plummer is detestable and outstanding in his portrayal of Jean Paul Getty, an insatiably greedy real-life version of Scrooge McDuck
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: I Love You, Daddy is much in line with the awkward situational humor to be expected from Louis C.K. It doesn't necessarily have the answers to the questions it presents, but it certainly brings an interesting discussion to the table
Downsizing is the second failed social satire of 2017 prominently featuring Matt Damon... so much of it is aimless, unfortunately ending up a boring waste of time
It's still early in the career of Margot Robbie, but Tonya Harding will go down as her current performance to beat, and much like pulling off a triple axle, it won't be easy to surpass.
It may be his first time in the director's chair, but Sorkin knows the key to success lies in his rapid-fire dialogue writing and ability to really get inside the head of Molly
The Greatest Showman could have been a rousing and poignant work important to disrespected abnormal citizens, but instead, it's just rousing with a lot of hollow razzle-dazzle.

Kruger's grieving widow and mother seeking justice after a racially motivated bombing attack by neo-Nazis are certainly attention-grabbing, but the execution lacks suspense, drags, and finally fizzles out completely by the ending
Honestly, all the Dave Chappelle similarity recognitions in appearance just made me wish he was the one writing and starring in this race relations blunder
As The Strange Ones drags and drags it certainly becomes more and more strange, but concurrently interest wanes and wanes
Rosamund Pike delivers some of her best work demonstrating the manic shock that comes from sudden loss, and how it tips the scales on someone's behalf mentally
The experiment of granting Elise front and center attention has worn thin despite reliable performances from Lin Shaye
The script (penned by Ziad Doueiri with assistance from Joelle Touma) is fascinatingly able to paint both Tony and Yasser as sympathetic, exploring each character and their prejudices equally
Flaws inside, whatever Quinn Shephard takes part in next will be anxiously awaited

Yes, it's a little silly watching him converse and become friends with criminals, but it's another beautiful reminder that we should all look for the good in everyone. Can Paddington even find the good in his former producer Harvey Weinstein?
Film Stars Don't Die in Liverpool contains upper-echelon work from everyone involved and is a powerful portrait of Hollywood love that never gets unbearably mushy.
movie_title: Film Stars Don't Die in Liverpool (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Nicolas Cage obviously isn't going to win Best Actor here, but he should be placed into consideration for Psychotic Dad of the Year
Someone get masterful video game director Hideo Kojima on the line and throw out the idea for Metal Gear Fat Amy
Dunkirk is a series of survival sequences (occasionally with each one topping the last nerve-shredding dance with death) hammering home the old tried and true never surrender adage

Thoroughbreds consistently defies expectations thanks to a sharply written script that balances reprehensible characters with poignant themes to observe; Anya Taylor-Joy and Olivia Cooke pull off this tricky and bizarre dynamic
Wish Upon is awful, and even teases a sequel. I wish it into abstract hell
It's like Willie said when Thurman found Asprin in his advent calendar - "Well they can't all be winners".
Allied is 1/3rd espionage action, 1/3rd World War II-era romance, 1/3rd relationship trust thriller, and 100% riveting
Essentially, Moana has something for everyone while successfully toying with the tried-and-true Disney princess formula

It never leans on the concept of singing animals too much, allowing for some character-driven scenes that make us actually care about these animals, why they are in the contest, and most importantly, their aspirations and dreams
"I can't beat it" - Those four small but powerful words might be the most emotional piece of dialogue heard all year.
One highbrow yet twisted tale of love and revenge with a loaded cast on their A-game
The drunken tomfoolery depicted in Office Christmas Party is an environment that would be more engaging to be around than to watch play out on a screen

Even though Hidden Figures is overstuffed with plot points and has way too much going on to properly flesh out in its roughly 2-hour running time, the film deserves praise for putting some unknown heroes into the limelight
Still, looking at the number of tantalizing movies being released alongside Why Him? on December 23rd, why this movie?
The ending is filled with both a bittersweet tragedy and hard-fought victory; ' a new hope' is earned, and so is this film's place in the upper echelon of Star Wars lore.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It is astonishing how a movie titled Assassin's Creed explores absolutely nothing about the brotherhood, their goals, purpose, personal motivations or you know, the life of an assassin
If you go see a movie with your family or significant other on Christmas Day, only suggest Passengers if you hate them
Makes sure to remind us that we are all human and make mistakes, all of which usually come at the expense of our own personal failures
For a passion project that took 26 years to reach fruition, Martin Scorsese's Silence was worth the wait
It may not be directed by Steven Spielberg, but it certainly has his magic. No wonder Bayona is set to direct Jurassic World 2
Is there a better way to ring in a new year of movies with some more material to add to the Nicolas Cage 'Losing His S*** Montage'?

It shows that when society is knocked down, it unites. That single important theme is never lost throughout the duration of the film, and for that (along with some terrific performances and realistic look at the bombings), the movie is a success.

It doesn't know if it wants to be a tale of Robin Hood style Prohibition-era mobsters, a classic revenge story, a war between gangsters and the Ku Klux Klan, a battle over turf between Irish and Italian mobs, etc. Repent watching Live by Night
On top of everything else, The Book of Love is an utter bore. No one will care whether Henry gets over the emotional loss of losing his wife or not, or if Millie gets to explore the sea

The horror maestro directs McAvoy to a completely bonkers performance full of scares and laughs (but most of all, terrific acting, made even more apparent during a scene that sees just about all 23 identities fighting for control at once)
It's a potent reminder that nothing is forever and that life rolls on, dealing us new cards (hopefully Aces). Look on the bright side of life and appreciate your surroundings.
Vin Diesel may have just resurrected another franchise.
Anyway, the movie tries so desperately hard to be emotional, intense, thought-provoking, funny, and more that the finished product is beyond rushed and wholly disjointed
Albert Wesker: Toughest motherf****** to put down for good in the history of video games, randomly relegated to keeping a button depressed for the film series' grand finale

American Violence tosses in everything from sordid child molesting uncles to a life of crime to a true love, except none of it is handled remotely in a way that doesn't elicit loads of unintentional laughter
Watching it is like living a lucid nightmare; there are hallucinations and hypnotic abstract images at every turn
John Wick: Chapter 2 obliterates its predecessor and is one of the greatest American action films of the decade
Loving is touchingly tender and one of the most emotionally moving films of 2016, all thanks to its extreme subtly
Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them might as well be a crossover between Pokémon Go and Doctor Who
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The images of someone essentially handicapped undergoing extensive physical training most definitely make for images that are both haunting and inspirational

The biggest takeaway from Billy Lynn's Long Halftime Long though is that Joe Alwyn, a British actor capable of astonishingly nailing a heavy southern drawl accent, just became a star in his debut performance
es, it is completely exaggerated to hell and back, but that doesn't stop Mike and Dave Need Wedding Dates from being conventional R-rated comedy fun with four leading actors having a blast
movie_title: Mike and Dave Need Wedding Dates (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Just like one of those talked about Beethoven symphonies, David Lowery's A Ghost Story will be discussed among film group circles until the end of time
The bait and switch marketing could have been forgiven if The Secret Life of Pets itself felt creative enough when the story leaves home

Realistically, Justin Lin was not selected to take over directorial duties from Abrams because of his storytelling techniques, but because he is gifted at staging action, and that is something that definitely shows when watching Star Trek Beyond
At one point a cell phone becomes a character's greatest means of self-defense, but it goes beyond that, constantly delivering creative thrills.

Even though it isn't the most well-written movie of the year or anything, the movie's primary demographic of teenagers might actually take away something useful regarding how their Internet behavior affects people in the real world

Bad Moms admittedly does have its heart in the right place as made clearly evident by the ending credits that actually features footage of the lead actors talking to their real-life mothers about their upbringing and childhood
Jason Bourne may start out slow, but it continuously builds upon that boiling momentum before exploding into a grand finale that makes you truly happy the franchise has been brought back
Suicide Squad simply shouldn't be a movie about saving the world like every other superhero movie; the characters are far too interesting and entertaining to be stuck in something so cliché
Three words kept ringing over and over in my head after viewing Sausage Party: "What the f***". I mean that as a compliment of the highest order

It truly is a shame that as the year winds down and the Academy begins handing out their Oscar nominations, Stephen Lang's performance won't even be looked at because the film is essentially a horror film with little dramatic substance
Still, the star-making performance and strong character work from Richard Blake will leave audiences with something to talk about. What the hell was DC doing not casting him as Joker?
Sully unexpectedly feels like the natural follow-up and perfect companion piece to Clint Eastwood's previous directorial effort in the polarizing but nonetheless Oscar-nominated American Sniper
"You taught me how to f***, she taught me how to love" is an actual line in the movie
Luke Scott's (yes, the son of Ridley Scott) directorial debut Morgan is essentially Ex Machina for dummies
The innovator has become the bottom of the barrel garbage copycat, ripping off of everything from its predecessor and other movies that have followed in its footsteps.
The action, especially in the last 30 minutes, is outstanding and excellently choreographed, featuring little to no CGI. I'm also just a sucker for watching Chris Pratt act like a smart ass.
Zach Galifianakis turns a public swimming pool brown after eating a Super Taco somewhere from a local stand in Mexico. With jokes like that, how can this movie possibly be a failure?
The effects of this disaster are still felt today, and Deepwater Horizon does an astonishing job at paying tribute to those that suffered because of greed
An entertainingly trashy soap opera story of emotional manipulation and abuse that over time reaches sickening levels
The final moments of the film will be seared into your brain forever
It is as simple as this, if you enjoy Kevin Hart's hyperactive style of comedy, you will enjoy Kevin Hart: What Now?
Director Damien Chazelle shoots for the stars and then breathtakingly frames his leads dancing together in the moonlight
The question "Do you like puzzles"often get asked a lot in The Accountant... well this movie is one overly elaborate puzzle where none of the pieces fit together.
Inferno is just a hot mess

On a week where the recent Marvel superhero film is also being released, Hacksaw Ridge is the real superhero film; one about a deeply religious, family man, pacifist that saved numerous lives without ever touching his rifle
Arrival is another knockout from Villeneuve, and as fans of science fiction we should all be thrilled that he is the one tackling a Blade Runner sequel
Likely no one will be surprised at the trajectory of The Edge of Seventeen's plot and where it ends up, but it has heart, raw emotion, and fantastic performances
During the end, all of the jovial and inspirational feel-good heroic moments feel earned, and that Snowden did operate in the best interest of America
The LEGO Batman Movie may not be perfect or the unexpected heartstring pulling emotional masterpiece that the first film revealed itself to be, but it is a genuine love letter to all things Batman
Hemsworth has more chemistry with the Ghostbusters than the actual Ghostbusters do with each other
Logan would absolutely deserve a Best Picture Oscar nomination, even more than Christopher Nolan's hailed yet arguably snubbed Batman masterpiece The Dark Knight.
Take Me starts off far stronger than it ends, but the one constant throughout is the loud and fierce back-and-forth exchanges between Healy and Schilling playing out this absurd story
The radiating charisma and talent from Dwayne Johnson and Zac Efron come very, very close to saving Baywatch

Captain Jack Sparrow is back with his special compass directing him to whatever he wants most in life, which after watching Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales should be a better script... but it's still fun and adventurous escapism
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Brad Pitt isn't particularly very good in War Machine, delivering a performance so far into cartoonish military caricature that it's tough to buy into the absurdist humor and satire being leveled at the whole disaster of the Afghanistan war
Stellar direction and an exceptional, committed cast elevate Berlin Syndrome beyond clichés into one of the most rewarding experiences of its kind

Dean is a flawed movie that sometimes flubs implementing the same quirky visually stylistic touches that match the personality of the young man himself, but it's also an engaging dramedy with a striking sense of authenticity

As superhero films shift more in the direction of mature themes (even the PG-13 offerings are starting to push the envelope), a specifically child-friendly hopeful franchise starter such as Captain Underpants: The First Epic Movie is an appreciated gift
movie_title: Captain Underpants: The First Epic Movie (Captain Underpants) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: I felt empowered and I'm not wonderful or a woman. You can view Wonder Woman and her first solo entry movie as a feminist icon, but honestly, it's so much more than that. She inspires us all to be more caring and better to one another

It subverts just about every cliché you can think of as far as apocalyptic scenarios go, ignoring monsters and demons entirely to focus on the human mind, making bold statements regarding fear, paranoia, love, and family

"Where's your sense of adventure," asks military soldier/treasure hunter Nick (played by Tom Cruise with his usual charisma and flair for dangerous stunt work) to his partner. It's the same question I pose to The Mummy reboot

I, Daniel Blake is a frustrating movie to watch unfold for all the right reasons; it really gets under your skin and will have you angry at the degrading mistreatment by businesses and governments toward working-class citizens
Often captivating largely in part due to a fantastic performance from Kate Mara; she is able to portray everything from a drifting loner personality to PTSD after an intense battle situation
Zoe Lister-Jones' debut feature is a success on all fronts that examines deeper intricacies of failing relationships with hard-hitting genuineness and authenticity
Ridley Scott is successfully able to marry the wildly different tones and styles of Prometheus and Alien into a unit boasting both substance and chaos
The characters and their banter among each other are enough to pull Rough Night off the ground from a wasted faceplant, but ultimately the story doesn't go dark enough
In beautiful fashion, McQueen essentially uses his ego to boost the near nonexistent confidence of Cruz and her aspirations of becoming a racer
The Bad Batch works due to world building with memorable performances from limited roles that deliver a lasting impression

All Eyez on Me is absolutely awful. It's a collection of scenes showing us events without any tissue connecting the narrative. Nothing here is engaging, which is a shame because it's very clear that Demetrius is giving it his all
Transformers: The Last Knight was doomed from the beginning when a Transformer gave a drunk Merlin magic powers and a dragon to help King Arthur and his Knights of the Round Table defeat... an army
War for the Planet of the Apes is poetic blockbuster storytelling, the kind we don't see enough of anymore. Director Matt Reeves continues to excel handling delicate subject material
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Baby Driver is the first movie of its kind and anything else that follows (unless it's also directed by Edgar Wright) will only be a pale, soulless, bland imitation
Even as it mixes genres ranging from drama/comedy/pulp thriller, Sofia Coppola never loses sight of the poignancy of her socially relevant Gothic potboiler

Also, for as energetic and outlandish as Will Ferrell is, it's Jason Mantzoukas that winds up stealing the whole movie, matching and surpassing his co-star in every way. The house does indeed always win, even if the rewards here are slim at best
The Little Hours continuously gets more raunchy and insane by the minute
Trey Parker was perfect casting for Balthazar. It's also unmistakably him, channeling his work on the near twenty-year running animated series South Park
A towering accomplishment that could potentially change people's outlooks on flesh consumption

This isn't just a homecoming for high school, it's a homecoming for great Spider-Man movies. Spider-Man: Homecoming is another hit for the carefully crafted MCU, which is a force of nature in itself and showing no signs of fading away
It may be dumb and absolutely predictable, but the visionary chops of its director are on full display, with an unexpectedly high focus on lengthy action sequences
For those of you that do end up surrounded by sharks for whatever reason, take great notice of what these characters do so you can do the exact opposite
From a general outline, the story here is fascinating and worth telling (especially on the big screen), but the journey of Chuck is full of bumps, bruises, and bleeding
The Journey is here to give the world a shred of hope as it follows a fictitious account of Northern Ireland political archenemies finding a pleasant level of common ground
This might be the best video game movie ever made and it's not even based on a game
movie_title: King Arthur: Legend Of The Sword (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Snatched simply goes through the motions as an appropriately timed Mother's Day comedy release, although it is nowhere near as downright embarrassingly terrible as last year's film named after the special holiday

Jordan Peele's debut will stand among the cream of the crop as far as 2017 horror films go. It's wildly ambitious, poignant, terrifying, full of laughs, a refreshing take on the genre with subversive tendencies, racially charged, and damn entertaining.
Catfight is here to remind everyone that no matter which side of the extreme one resides on, they're probably a selfish, stuck-up, elitest, snobby a****** that actually has no moral compass
The crushing part of Donald Cried is that although it is a comedy, and that much of the titular goofball's antics are funny, it seems like we all know our own Donald in some form or another
Macon Blair's debut feature has certainly made him a name to keep note of, now also behind the camera
movie_title: I don't feel at home in this world anymore. (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's relentless in its catastrophic, seismic destruction (even containing moderately interesting and likable human characters), and anyone who isn't taken aback by it should check their pulse

All praise for the storytelling and direction aside, the meatiest portion of Raw comes from Garance Marillier, expressing a multitude of personality shifts as she comes to terms with herself in more ways than one
Add another tick to the win column for Kristen Stewart... Personal Shopper sees the actress turn in her most accomplished work to date
Small shortcomings aside, Beauty and the Beast is a splendid remake. Even today, its themes regarding finding love and beauty from within a person and not for social status and appearances resonate
The Belko Experiment is filled with so much untapped potential that it feels appropriate to wish that James Gunn had directed it himself
The Boss Baby is a poop-filled diaper, just one that doesn't stink up the whole house.
Drawing influence from such revered masterpieces like Rosemary's Baby, Prevenge devilishly plays with the concept of unborn babies talking their motherly hosts into all sorts of nefarious acts
Generic characters and story aside, Life is definitely a suspenseful, blood-drenched affair filled with familiar faces that will satisfy those looking to waste 103 minutes
Perhaps most fascinating is that while the title suggests the film is centered on revenge, it's also a coming-of-age dark fairytale
It's almost like the hype surrounding an exciting WWE main event, where the journey is book-ended by filler
T2 Trainspotting makes the case that addicts are addicts and always will be, so they must channel that lust into a different passion, which is brilliantly realized by the end of the film
Something is wrong when the best part of the last 20 minutes is Elizabeth Banks biting into a Krispy Kreme doughnut as Angel Grove is destroyed
If it were physically possible, I would give the movie a ticket for being garbage and wasting 100 minutes of my life

Ghost in the Shell is fighting the uphill battle to break Japanese Anime into mainstream Hollywood cinema. Director Rupert Sanders may have done just that, delivering a thought-provoking, action-packed, and accessible quest for self-discovery
The Discovery brings to memory the sci-fi masterpieces Christopher Nolan typically churns out
To say I love The Marine franchise would be a bigger BS lie than Michael Cole professing that he "LOOOOOOOVES Final Fantasy"
Outside of torpedoes and heat-seeking missiles tearing up the icy ground, one character is tasked with obtaining a very precious package. It's freaking awesome, and that's all I'm saying
Every dilemma is resolved minutes after it begins. There is no danger, no complex character to dissect, nothing.
The Armenian people deserve a better film bringing their horrific struggles into the spotlight, and maybe one will eventually come, but with that said the film isn't a complete disaster
Graduation is assuredly a slow burn that revels in subtlety and true to life human interaction, but it builds to a fitting ending that both emotionally resonates and feels slightly predictable
Everyone is here for the violence and colorful characters, to which Free Fire delivers with gleeful overindulgence

James Gunn has written and directed the two best films in the entire MCU thus far; his work continues to contain superb irreverent humor, boast visually and emotionally captivating spectacles, and embraces being different
Honestly, Sleight deserves a sequel, as with the origin story out of the way there is room to create something truly bold and refreshing within the oversaturated superhero genre

Go for the stunning, beautiful shots that will elicit oohs and ahs, and you won't be let down. But don't expect a thought-provoking, cohesive message, because that really wasn't up the filmmaker's alley.

Heist movies seem pretty quaint and analog in our era where high stakes crime is primarily electronic in nature. But until someone can make embezzlement cinematically interesting, we're left with theft and this movie just gets away with it.
It's a testament to the strength of Jolie's craft that the taboo relationship at the picture's core is interwoven into the wartime fabric without seeming like a cop out.
movie_title: In the Land of Blood and Honey (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The film trades in subdued emotions and subtle currents of longing that are deeply felt.
A stodgy, ridiculous movie with a horse that simultaneously serves as an allegory for the bond that unites all mankind and as a symbol of profound, idealized purity.
The movie successfully reflects turmoil, looking at the world from the specific standpoint of a child who's ill-equipped to comprehend it, trying to survive as best he can.
The doc offers a well-rounded treatise on Corman's indelible influence, benefiting from a strong cast of talking head contributors.
movie_title: Corman's World: Exploits Of A Hollywood Rebel (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It trades in discomfort and unease, not catharsis. That's an achievement worthy of admiration, if you can endure it.
The film emphasizes subtle, sly character details at the expense of flashy, straightforward storytelling.
Director David Gordon Green stops pushing buttons and settles for the mundane when the movie demands the offbeat and the dark.
Beneath the manly posturing and thrilling handheld camera-captured combat scenes is a story bereft of heart, a mundane violent enterprise without any emotional appeal.
It's a soulless, distancing portrait set against a bland elite Manhattan universe of sleek high-rises and glamorous bars.
The film is really about Scorsese sharing with us, on a deep visceral level, his extraordinary affection for the medium that's his passion, his profession, his everything.
It's a smart study of the root causes of destructive human behavior, but there's a flat quality to the dark impulses on display.
The film views Thatcher with sympathy and admiration; the effect is a strange movie that manages to compel while also coming off as shortsighted.
The truth, of course, is that Marilyn Monroe is what you make of her. Still, Michelle Williams offers a powerful way in.
Happy Feet Two works because the prospect of penguins singing covers hasn't lost its appeal.
Sandler's drag act becomes so excruciatingly unpleasant that it inspires involuntary shudders and post-traumatic nightmares.
The film demonstrates Werner Herzog's unparalleled knack for drawing out the harmony and discord in nature.
The movie delves beneath Paul McCartney's polished celebrity exterior to draw out the essence of the man.
The latest Harold & Kumar is a symphony of pristine ridiculousness, rendered in the third dimension.
Foster, Reilly, Winslet and Waltz (four Oscar wins among them) share a preternatural gift for imbuing even the quietest moments with extraordinary, unconventional feeling.
It's all way too cut-and-dry, an enterprise in which a pedestrian plot and a straightforward aesthetic have been applied to a grand idea.
The conflicts are undercooked, Johnny Depp's performance rote and the film mired in a sort of existential haze.
A compelling film about the visceral facts of the depressing, confusing, exciting, terrifying moment that its protagonist is stuck in.
A simplistic, poorly-constructed exercise in low-rent genre moviemaking. It's as if Kevin Smith made the movie just so he could promote it.
An assured, moody police procedural rendered with rich cinematography.
One of the blandest imaginable comedies, a PG-rated flick that's so nice and so harmless it's like inhaling pound after pound of flavorless tofu.
Don't be afraid of the movie's grim facade: this is an uplifting journey worth taking.
This is, of course, Hollywood schlock, directed by shlock-master Brett Ratner. But it's also a surprisingly effective social drama.
At the end of the day, this is a long-winded SEALs recruitment tool, a noble gesture that's just not sufficient basis for a feature film.
The film offers shifts in perspective that express deep humanist overtones and the conviction that life can't be seen or understood in simple terms of black and white.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in Anatolia (2012)

movie_review_blurb: It's impossibly labored and dull, a case study in the wrong way to make a horror movie.
It's every bit as sharp and funny as Slap Shot.
A collection of beautiful visual compositions, deliberate long takes and all-around distinguished dramatics that remains perilously detached from start to finish.
The bloody violence is so expertly choreographed that it's practically poetic.
It's short of that essential added spectacle, the visceral, tumultuous event that really shakes up the characters and creates a journey worth taking.
Nicolas Cage plays the regular man protagonist with surprising ease, dialing down the nutty affectations and keeping you engaged.
A lovingly understated film from masters of naturalistic cinema.
The filmmakers screw up the ending so monumentally here that all the good will they've built up is squandered.
Visionary and philosophical, with the sort of complex allusions to death, immortality and the destruction of civilizations that you don't expect from a $250 million film.
The modern Jewish parable Footnote imbues a classic moral dilemma with a fraught, fascinating twist.
Jennifer Westfeldt's observant writing keeps things grounded and the strong performances root the movie in truthful emotions
Project X flops, principally because its characters basically have a great time partying. There's no real danger, or regret, just bacchanal.
This mediocre movie should have bypassed theaters and gone straight to Netflix.
The picture offers such a loving, moving reproduction of Dr. Seuss' warm images that you almost wish the filmmakers had forgotten about the plot.
The movie gleefully pushes boundaries, but it's a collection of a few worthy skit ideas and lots of non-starters in search of a unified whole.
movie_title: Tim and Eric's Billion Dollar Movie (2012)

movie_review_blurb: It's an intriguing spectacle, but there's no substance behind it.
It's a classic slow burn, a collection of patiently assembled observational sequences that collectively portrays the psychological toll facing teens under siege.
The filmmakers understand that they have happy, productive, kooky Nicolas Cage on hand, not sullen money-hungry Cage, and they let him loose.
It's an absurdly bright, peppy affair that's clearly been test-screened to death in order to find the "perfect" balance of action and romance.
Transforms the story of a struggling high-school football team into a deeply moving portrait of teens learning, for the first time, that they're capable of greatness.
Director Jill Sprecher keeps things moving at a fast and funny pace, with the narrative's sleazy underpinnings well disguised by the Upper Midwestern niceties.
If it's not quite the unholy mess that the reviews have promised, there's no question that this is a sloppy, hubristic affair.
The hand-drawn, watercolor-style animation is a natural fit for the story, with its retro sensibility and timeless effect.
Denzel Washington is one of those rare actors blessed with enough natural charisma that he can repeat things and still entertain us.
It's a hopeful, upbeat film about people finding comfort and strength in their loved ones, a rare feel-good movie that truly earns that designation.
If you should find yourself trapped at this diva show and are willing to give in to its heightened stupidity, you'll get your money's worth in a perverse sort of way.
The film is so bent on reflecting its abrasive main characters' psychological states that it's often insufferable.
It'd be hard to conceive of a movie more painstakingly comprised of dramatic filler.
This is familiar narrative terrain, of course. But it's affectionately re-worked in Burns' atmospheric rendition.
There are extraordinary degrees of emotion and intelligence to be found in every word spoken by Tom Hardy and Joel Edgerton.
Infused with mystery, tragedy and humor, serving as a genealogical study and Greek tragedy wrapped in one, it's a fine achievement of bold, deeply felt cinema.
Offers a valuable look at an iconic historical event from a never-before-seen perspective.
The plot buried beneath all the narrative playfulness has a fleeting, pedestrian feel.
Trades on an indisputable fact: Ecologically friendly movies about cute animals are just about impossible to resist.
The picture thrills in large part because the filmmaker so gleefully indulges in the craziness of the conceit.
An appealing, often hilarious corrective to the conventional pop cultural idealization of the superhero.
Fulfills the "Golden Hasselhoff" rule, which holds that any work of "art" blessed with The Hoff's presence is all the better for it.
Spotlights Duncan Jones' cinematic muscle, specifically an all-too-rare aptitude for molding classical technique with experimental touches.
There's no arc to what's on screen, because the film essentially begins right before the real story's climax, draws things out for 90 minutes and ends with a thud.
Filmmaker Zack Snyder fails to give the narrative the grounded coherence required of a work that indulges in dreamscapes and complex imagined worlds.
A strangely arid experience, without the gleeful, drugged-out weirdness of a truly offbeat endeavor.
The film offers a portrait that's revealing and mysterious, as the folksy subject welcomes Press' camera into his routine while keeping a tight-lipped distance from it.
Spurlock is the right filmmaker for this sort of tongue-in-cheek look at pop cultural excesses.
movie_title: POM Wonderful Presents: The Greatest Movie Ever Sold (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It marks a vivid return to a world defined by antiquated social mores and timeless emotions.
A ridiculous teenybopper-geared retooling of the fairy tale.
The film stands apart from its countless predecessors in its evocation of the existential essence of a life spent perpetually looking over one's shoulder.
The awe-inspiring 3-D work offers a richly textured, luxuriously detailed vision of life on Mars.
Radnor's script is well-attuned to the lonely disorientation of being young and less than wealthy in the increasingly gentrified, high-end Big Apple.
A damn fine western, an entertaining throwback to classic B-pictures that pays clever tribute to its predecessors.
The premise promises an engaging wronged-man thriller with metaphysical overtones, but director George Nolfi fails to deliver.
Hall Pass shows flashes of '90s-Farrelly magic; and even at its most reductive, the film can still fall back on a basic tenet: These guys know their way around a gag.
The actors are submerged in a layer of artifice so thick that it's impossible to regard the characters as anything but pawns in the writer-director's cinematic game.
The movie builds up to a climax that makes one question whether it was ever worth the effort.
You fidget and squirm, watching with absolute disinterest that morphs into total disgust. I can't remember the last time I felt so detached from a movie.
A slight yet haunting thriller that replaces easy answers with the pervasive sense of unknowable, evil forces at work.
Grau never offers a tangible way in, a meaningful reason for the audience to try and probe below the grotesque surface.
Makes the fatal, conceptual mistake of turning a picture about a mysterious alien attack into a sub-par, propagandistic combat demo reel.
With terrible acting, a narrative on autopilot and chaotic blurs passing for action scenes, it's a direct-to-DVD caliber sojourn through the dregs of comic book adaptation.
The movie moves forward in a reductive will-they-or-won't-they-cheat fashion, without much depth or character-driven insight.
This is, yes, a movie about a hobo with a shotgun, but it's also an inspired parody of the post-apocalyptic whack-a-mole revenge flick.
A painstakingly old-fashioned drama that's far more interested in the nuances of human behavior than exploitation or pyrotechnics.
The film is so difficult to watch, and it's such a chore to discern a sense of place and perspective, that it sits onscreen like a big, dead weight.
A bearded, long-haired, Crocs-clad Paul Rudd just owns the part and makes it all worthwhile.
There's a serious disconnect between the highfalutin atmospherics and the nitty gritty sloppiness of the premise.
movie_title: Don't Be Afraid Of The Dark (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The fractured chronological foundation doesn't translate to film, with the character arcs stifled by the fragmented glimpses at their stories.
In its quiet way, Amigo builds to a devastating portrait of war's terrible cost.
This is a snarky, humorous movie about blasting aliens to bits, but if you're looking for more, you won't be left hanging.
The film simultaneously hurls you into the highly-charged world of Formula One and the private emotional space of its complex protagonist.
Testifies to the remarkable, democratizing nature of cinema and the power of images seen and voices heard for the first time.
The movie seems to be intoxicated by how funny it thinks it is, gleefully descending into a swell of hyperactivity, with each new scene engineered to one-up the last.
Sharply directed and appropriately tear-jerking, imbued with the gravitas of such an epic finale.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: This Sarah Palin hosanna is done in by the simple fact that its director needs to go back to film school.
This Winnie the Pooh is, in every respect, a fitting tribute to author A.A. Milne and his illustrator E.H. Shepard.
The stars lack the charisma, the comic energy and the overall appeal of the A-listers playing supporting roles. That's a fundamental miscalculation.
With sensitivity, and a unique protagonist bestowed with a proud, unshakable spirit, the movie abandons snarky black comedy for deeper existential truths.
[The] film asks us to identify with a woman who behaves rather heinously, while it relies on her mean-spiritedly outrageous behavior to sustain all 92 minutes.
The message of valuing family over work feels half-baked because the film defines doing the right thing as breaking penguins out of a zoo and harboring them in a high-rise.
Fun comic horror with a classic tough-guy protagonist and just the right amount of frigid, Norwegian atmosphere.
Part African noir and part concise summation of busy, heady life in modern-day Kinshasa.
Super 8 is really about the thrill Abrams must have felt when he and his buddies discovered films and filmmaking, awakening in them that ancient drive to tell stories.
It's an impassioned cry of disgust, a fervent plea to wake us up to a grand injustice.
An efficient and emotionally affecting character-driven spectacle that is enhanced but not overwhelmed by its elaborate action scenes.
The movie smartly evokes the yearnings and insecurities of a young man gradually growing into his own skin.
Resurrects and expands upon the original's blend of creatively filmed action, broad comedy and classic Chinese motifs interspersed with that animation standard: cute animals.
It's an experience that stays with you, getting you thinking about the deepest recesses of space, the farthest reaches of time and what it all means.
The quest for the Fountain of Youth is weightless filler that means nothing, with little broader ramifications.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: With a likable Will Ferrell as its lead, the film offers an incisive personal spin on these tumultuous economic times.
The picture entertains, at times legitimately and at others in a cheesy, '80s action sort of way
Willem Dafoe is the perfect actor to carry a film like The Hunter, which is guided by the internal journey experienced by his unusual character.
Taps into some appealingly old-fashioned ideas about the magic of what was once America's Pastime.
What could have been a smart Kubrickian enterprise, or at the very least a top-of-the-line sci-fi piece, instead aspires to little more than stock C-grade action schlock.
A rare modern genre piece that doesn't shy away from being impossibly bleak and downbeat.
An arty action flick that's almost worth watching. The odds of director John Hyams pulling off such a feat were only slightly worse than winning Powerball.
Anchored by Robert Carlyle's strong, naturalistic performance, in which he relies on his big smile and sad eyes in equal measure.
A convincing allegorical portrait of the recession-era crime business.
To watch Anthony Hopkins play Alfred Hitchcock is to experience an onscreen transformation that's so complete, so comprehensive, it's as if the real person has been revived.
What sounds like a movie of the week formula plays much more convincingly thanks to assured direction and powerful performances.
movie_title: De rouille et d'os (Rust and Bone) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A sobering portrait of five lives destroyed on a terrible night and an earnest plea for thoughtful, well-considered justice in the future.
The film is at once heartfelt and funny, farcical and sincere, and packed with performances that pull off that difficult balancing act. In short, it's a masterpiece.
Director Joe Wright pulls off an impressive feat, taking the iconic, timeless work and making it his own.
It's a film about a society at a crossroads, with two competing visions of the future being hashed out against a backdrop of political intrigue. Sound familiar?
Skyfall stands out by bringing Bond into a real world milieu. For many reasons, things aren't so comfortable and secure anymore.
Director Barry Levinson appears reinvigorated here, smartly building tension and a sense of ominous foreboding with the multimedia approach.
It's simultaneously an enlightening historical account and a softhearted comedy of manners, and you wish director Roger Michell had gone one way or the other.
However inconsequential the struggles of pretentious artists might be, A Late Quartet depicts the passage of time, the specter of death and the promise of rebirth, in time-honored dramatic form.
The characters are kept at such a distance, and the movie is so opposed to basic dramatic impulses, that it's like watching a stranger's vacation footage.
There are some clunky moments here, but the movie conveys the fundamental truth that some victories don't always feel so victorious.
It's a reminder of what the movies can offer when they're at their best: an escape into another world and a pertinent look at our own.
when it comes to insight into being a teen in this day an age, or any of the other traits that set the best high school movies apart, The First Time comes up empty.
It offers a relatable depiction of the powers of a positive mental attitude and perseverance in spite of horrendously bad luck. And some Oscar-caliber acting, to boot.
You'll either run with it or you won't, but you can be sure you've never seen anything quite like it.
Eugene Jarecki, an adept chronicler of corrosive societal corruption, offers a thoughtful look at the human cost of the epic, decades-long War on Drugs.
The filmmaker alludes to racial tensions, alcoholism and other hot-button period taboos, but they jumble together in a soup of sweaty nonsense.
With Sarah Palin, the movie's thinly disguised object of derision, now operating on the fringe of mainstream culture, the entire film feels like yesterday's news.
From the carefully choreographed action scenes to the themes of revenge and redemption, Looper is the work of a visionary. Don't miss it.
A meat-and-potatoes movie, it's basic, dependable fare that's cooked well and goes down easy.
Writer-director David Ayer drives home the existential displacement that must come with being a cop on a dangerous patrol.
Stands out as a plea for tolerance, a film about the shared humanity that can overcome even the most intractable of differences.
It's about as much fun as spending 100 minutes in a room full of annoying strangers.
It's a shame to see Peter Jackson treading water when there are so many new cinematic horizons worth exploring.
It's one of the great recent works about the investigative process, a streamlined, riveting portrait of a nuts-and-bolts inquiry over the course of a decade.
Everything is so low-key it doesn't really stick, which is strange when you consider that the movie is about nothing less than a supernatural war over a teenage girl's soul.
The greatest film ever made about living, breathing garden gnomes.
A meticulously constructed depiction of modern alienation, from the great Abbas Kiarostami.
A fascinating period re-creation if not an especially compelling drama.
Every new Soderbergh film, even the failures, is a gift for viewers who love movies. Side Effects is no exception.
The film reveals a depth and weight to the Charlie Sheen archetype that we haven't experienced before.
movie_title: A Glimpse Inside the Mind of Charles Swan III (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A thoughtful look at the fundamental reasons a down-and-out city was primed to embrace this larger-than-life cheerleader for all things Gotham.
There's not much to the story beyond its thin conceit, so the filmmaker relies on his stars' charms. Even when it comes to Oscar winners, that approach only gets you so far.
You're meant to feel Jimmy's pain, to share his rage, but that's hard when he doesn't even seem human.
With so many famous people in one movie, you might have thought, 'Gee, how bad could it be?' The answer: Very, very bad.
This is classic grindhouse material pretending to be something it's not.
Unlike Werner Herzog's vintage efforts, Happy People plays like an everyday Discovery channel special.
movie_title: Happy People: A Year in the Taiga (2013)

movie_review_blurb: It's an uncompromising portrait of the aging process, with the experience of getting older rendered in a harsh light rather than a comforting golden glow.
It's got the heart and soul, but not the brain.
Tom O'Brien smartly stresses realistic, submerged feelings instead of overwrought dramatics in his low-key portrait of friendship and all its complications.
No movie starring these actors could possibly be all that bad. But Quartet is tepid when it wants to be sophisticated, a slow-moving, middlebrow endeavor.
This is the story of people who dream big dreams and find a common understanding in the face of impossible difficulties. It's hard not to get behind that.
movie_title: A Bottle in the Gaza Sea (2013)

movie_review_blurb: There are bad movies. There are BAD movies. And then there's The Guilt Trip.
There's a finely-tuned sense of how difficult it can be to live life on your own terms, but the film so resolutely adheres to indie conventions it's hard to take seriously.
There's joy in the small moments and fierce, humanist dignity in Alan Cumming's performance.
The film gives us vintage Tarantino, a pastiche of Western, blaxploitation and Civil War-era movie tropes that's packed with his characteristically rich dialogue.
A fracking drama that's more about the ethical dilemma facing the main character than easy answers to tricky questions.
A definitive portrait of a real-life travesty of justice. Provides a strong sense of the scope of this tragedy and a thoughtful investigative probing of the facts behind it.
A '60s-set film that's rendered with with an eye for authenticity instead of period fetishism.
Judd Apatow mines recognizable thematic territory -- after all, we've all had to grapple with that big birthday and what it represents -- and he does so with vivid immediacy.
Riveting for a spell, but imbued with a phony uplifting sensibility that detracts from the Thailand tsunami's real story.
There isn't much of a story here, though it's great to see Arnold back where he belongs.
Writer-director Stephen Chbosky's adaptation of his novel is so infused with honey-glazed recollections of suburban Pittsburgh in the early '90s that it suffocates.
movie_title: The Perks of Being a Wallflower (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Here's an old-fashioned thriller-cum-morality play that trades in compelling characters and sharp storytelling.
Josh Radnor's Jesse is not a likable character in any sense, and more than anything you wish he'd just grow up already.
This isn't really a movie. It's a collection of covers. And if it's possible to have a decent time, you can't help but be struck by the emptiness of it all.
For all the promise of minor-key, David Lynch-esque surrealism with a French twist, the movie offers perilously little payoff.
A tame indie with sci-fi leanings that nearly gets by on Aubrey Plaza's unique charms.
A love letter to the people of the Bayou State, who have persevered in the face of apocalyptic tragedy.
Robert Pattinson fits right into this material - a blistering critique of a man who can't overcome his self-hatred.
This sequel puts such little effort into the same basic setup that it's barely even a movie.
It's about a 'high' school, and once you've gotten that you've pretty much figured out this stoner comedy.
The filmmakers present a sharp, well-argued case that exposes the rampant cronyism and greed eating away at the heart of the United Nations.
Features characters worth caring about, actors who are adept at making you feel for them and an inspirational narrative centered on meaningful, affecting human growth.
As per the director's norm, the film offers a triumph of style over substance. But sometimes, when it's not just typical summertime bombast, that's what you need.
The experience of watching Samuel L. Jackson actually act is the only real pleasure to be gleaned from the movie.
It's filled with shocking dialogue and disturbing content, but treats it all in a strangely facile way.
It plays less like a movie Woody Allen truly needed to make and more like one he took on so he could get a little work in while vacationing in Rome.
There's heartfelt drama, droll humor, an affecting love story and a feminist message that sticks.
An adaptation of an old, antiquated TV show that feels fresh and alive in large part because of its star.
This powerful drama is set at that key moment in life when the realities of the adult world impinge on and irrevocably alter the optimism of youth.
A stark vision of American civilization crumbling amid a morass of loud, cacophonic nonsense.
Bess Kargman's movie is imbued with a seriousness that sets it apart from typical 'competition docs.'
The movie teeters on the edge of caricature, but Kathleen Turner keeps it grounded and relatable.
Why resurrect an American literary giant onscreen so he can help a police investigation? Sure, Poe essentially invented the detective genre, but come on.
A dark, humorous look at southern oddballs that's also a powerful meditation on human fragility.
The convoluted, goofy B movie lets down its hardworking star.
The film is poignant without being overbearing, emotionally affecting while remaining rooted to the real world.
movie_title: Un amour de jeunesse (Goodbye First Love) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The predictably fine acting can't save the movie from the insipid writing, which is centered on the less-than-illuminating insight that some people really love their dogs.
This long-awaited horror movie is smart and fun, packing unexpected surprises while cleverly recalibrating genre expectations.
This is a quiet movie centered on small moments that collectively form something deep and profound.
If you're after an interesting cinematic experience about convincing characters facing some sort of meaningful human dilemma, it'd be best to keep on looking.
The film doesn't go far enough in exploring the unique setting, playing things safe when they should be outrageous.
movie_title: Seeking a Friend for the End of the World (2012)

movie_review_blurb: There's a conceptual flaw here: the actual details of Lincoln's life were so fascinating, filled with such drama, that there's no need to make him a vampire hunter at all.
Michelle Williams' sublime, open-hearted work carries us with her as Margot experiences the pleasures and pains of that confusing journey we call life.
This movie defies the usual fresh-or-rotten dichotomy. It's an awesome feat of filmmaking, but so opaque that it keeps you at a remove and proves hard to sit through.
Heidi Ewing and Rachel Grady evoke the human heart of the economic malaise that's eating away at the core of this country, while pointing the way toward better days ahead.
Bolstered by a terrific performance from Melanie Lynskey, who brings dignity and humor to what could have been a downbeat part.
This movie makes absolutely no sense.
In the end, The Possession is simply just another movie about a possessed demon child who does the things that demon children do.
A western-gangster movie hybrid set in 1930s Appalachia that's a welcome return to two old-fashioned, distinctly American modes of filmmaking.
Instead of perseverating on the gender behind this phone sex comedy, it's best to flat out state that the movie is hilarious.
A compelling, character-driven film about a particularly antiseptic form of madness.
It lasts an astonishing 154 minutes, pushing on so far past its expiration date that you'll squirm uncomfortably for the final act.
Mike Birbiglia adeptly navigates the comic, self-mocking confessional terrain.
The action has an appealing old-fashioned feel, relying on genuine stunt driving instead of the usual recipe of CGI and incessant cutting.
The clichés are expected and could be forgiven if the movie ever departed from the standard template, even for a minute.
The hilarious thought of stunned Team Edward devotees scratching their heads at this mystifying David Cronenberg movie is about all there is to get you through it.
This is an illustrated lecture - a jumbled, rushed cinematic rant. The ideas are there. The story is not.
This is total nonsense, of course, but Sylvester Stallone and company, weirdly bulging arms and all, are at their tongue-in-cheek best throughout.
An appealing fantasy depiction of cosmopolitan life in the heart of Manhattan.
In short, the movie's not funny enough or serious-minded enough to warrant 95 minutes of your time.
A waste of talent and a tired enterprise, with its brief snippets of compelling content undone by the overarching blandness.
Killer Joe, packed with miserable stereotypes doing miserable things with no sense of a higher purpose, plays like a dramatized version of The Jerry Springer Show.
The screenplay wades through a stream of absurd situations during the trip, but they're treated with an earnest, understated hand that keeps the focus on the characters.
The characters are props in what's essentially a lame screenwriting exercise.
It transforms from a mocking portrait of exorbitance into a sympathetic depiction of a family struggling with their own version of what most of us have gone through.
With attractively costumed actors and a no-expenses-spared approach, the movie is the closest we'll get to experiencing Versailles alongside the queen.
The greatest mystery of all -- why this family believed the imposter and welcomed him "home" -- remains hauntingly unsolved
The film is undone by the fact that both protagonists are obnoxious caricatures.

Sure, the protagonists are self-indulgent bores, the narrative peters out with a weird bout of self-reflexive tomfoolery and the movie won't be remembered as one of Stone's masterpieces. But it's a lot of fun.
A fun, ribald time that's also a a nuanced take on a man who is all-too aware of what his life is missing.
What really matters is the affectionate, humanist perspective from which the filmmaker dramatizes the plight of a man who simply can't bare the weight of his job.
Espouses smart and meaningful insights into the challenges of falling in love with the "wrong" man and joining a family in which one might not be the most natural fit.
It's powerful material for Werner Herzog, a premier chronicler of the madness of men, and Nicolas Cage, who brings a fevered intensity to every project he takes on.
movie_title: Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The movie's hot, bathed in an erotic glow, but horribly empty.
The film works best for a simple reason: the depth of feeling Goldthwait and Williams pour into the story of the coming of age of a middle-aged man.
Conventional modes of representation hamper Fifty Dead Men Walking and its look at a subject that demands a fresher point of view.
The film seems predisposed to come across as dated and nonspecific as possible.
A movie that's a gift for anyone who's ever been a fan of Led Zeppelin, U2, The White Stripes or music in general.
Tugs at the heartstrings with the aggression of a linebacker pursuing a quarterback.
An unabashed work of pure entertainment made without the slightest agenda beyond replicating the look and feel of a Saturday morning cartoon.
movie_title: G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra (2009)

movie_review_blurb: For all its merits, Julie & Julia is felled by a near total lack of compelling drama.
Rowan Woods indulges in some sub-subpar Crash territory here, with a laughably self-serious narrative that has less to do with reality than histrionics.
The film works as a morality tale, a thriller and more.
A work of earnest self-reflection that candidly looks at the A-list world Apatow and his cohorts have begun to inhabit at this particular stage in their lives.
While the film periodically threatens to veer into extreme cutesy indie territory, Daniels and Graham keep it grounded.
Well-researched, conclusive proof that the men and women we've put in charge of our lives are as dunderheaded and regressive as the rest of us.
Taking Woodstock could have used a bit more old-fashioned Ang Lee brooding and torment and a bit less forced joy.
The movie takes a premise that might have served as the basis of a weepy romantic drama and turns it into something very different, but no less insulting.
Transforms a thoroughly outrageous premise into a thoughtful study of the burdens of 21st-century masculinity.
It's funny stuff, but more in a "look at how outrageous we're being" sort of way than one that comes close to engaging in meaningful social commentary.
[The film] benefits greatly from the inspired casting by director Christine Jeffs and her team, and the insights into loss and motherhood professed by Megan Holley's screenplay.
There's no depth to the surface machinations, no sense that the central romance features fully formed individuals connecting on an elemental level.
Falls short in the areas that set great cinema apart.

This movie is one of those good, thought-provoking, adult-oriented science fiction sleepers like "The Arrival," "Gattaca" or 'Dark City.'

A great-looking action film.

This is a well-written, well-acted and well-constructed film. Not a classic, but a worthy entry into the POW genre.
'The Score' is a caper movie featuring big-time talent hampered by a drowsy story line.
The movie is very good-natured, folksy and easy-going, it just isn't very funny.
The best film of 2001.
It seems to be more of a cautionary tale about the sometimes deadly power of human sexuality.
Director Ron Howard uses interesting visual techniques to show how Nash makes his amazing mathematical connections.
This is a highly amusing tale that is probably supposed to be more serious than it seemed to be on the screen.
'Ali," despite some fine performances and well-staged fight scenes, is a major disappointment.
It takes more than a little sex to overcome 16 tons of emotional baggage.
Much of the power of "The Endurance" derives from the artistic images captured during the voyage by pioneer Australian documentary photographer Frank Hurley (1885-1962).
The last third of Mulholland Drive looks like a cobbled-together mess of a film, rather than the masterpiece Lynch lovers claim it is.
Unlike most American dark comedies there is no soft edge to be found anywhere in this devastating indictment of war.
It is not a realistic story at all and it is predictable and derivative.
This is a sweeping epic of a film, which also manages to remain rooted in the personal dramas of its central characters.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring (2001)

movie_review_blurb: It is a gripping, suspenseful drama that grabs you by the throat and just won't let go.
If you don't mind a film that challenges you to think and to re-evaluate your perceptions, you might just like it.
Virtually all of the film's drama is character driven. The motivations are unforced and believable.
It makes you wish the real world was like this movie. It is a light story filled with wonder and good humor, a real audience pleaser.
Almost an hour of new footage has been added to the film, making an already long film even longer, but not better.
Ocean's Eleven" is a very thin, but very slick caper movie. There is no substance to it, but it is a lot of fun to watch.
Hedwig and the Angry Inch" is a top-notch rock and roll musical along the lines of "Moulin Rouge" and "Rocky Horror Picture Show.
While it is both funny and tragic, the two themes don't always work together.
It was sort of like going to a dinner party and finding yourself surrounded by a group of insufferable snobs, none of whom you would ever think of inviting to your house.
A fascinating story of a friendship and a company under enormous pressure
It isn't a great film, but it is important in a historical sense.
This is obviously not a serious, or a believable, film. It is just very thin, light entertainment.
The story is burdened by a thousand clichés ...
It looks good, but it is essentially empty.
It has some quality computer-generated graphics, while the story and artwork are imaginative.
Director Mark Pellington does a good job of establishing just the right atmosphere of creepiness and mystery.
If any of the characters was the least bit appealing, I might have had more patience waiting for something to happen.
Hamlet, and some good acting, keep the film from being a stinker, but it never rises above mediocrity.
This is one of the rarest kinds of films: a family-oriented non-Disney film that is actually funny without hitting below the belt.
An average action film that is rather sloppily put together.
Of over a dozen film versions of this story, it is one of the best, with solid performances and lavish production values.
The finest Disney feature-length animated musical ever made
This time they've added some heart and insight and cut back on the gross-out humor.
The film is buoyed by some excellent performances.
It would have made a funny 15 to 20 minute sketch in a format like the very funny short martial arts sketch in "Kentucky Fried Movie.'
While the time travel plot is downright silly, fine performances and excellent romantic chemistry rescue the story for the most part ...
Judging the film on what it is, rather than what it is not, I'd have to say this is one of the best films of 2001, and the best war movie since "Saving Private Ryan."
This skewed view of reality is one of the charms of a Capra kind of film, the kind of movie that sees the best in us.
This is the best documentary I have seen in 2001.
'Serendipity" is a nice light romantic comedy well-suited for the holiday season.
An odd combination of fiction and fact, a sort of docudrama.
movie_title: Kandahar: Le soleil derrière la lune (2001)

movie_review_blurb: This one-joke movie manages so many imaginative wrinkles that it successfully extends the joke into a feature length film.
It is a pretty good, by the numbers, adventure yarn, but a raptor could write something more original.
Story is weak and bleak ... but enjoyable because the characters are so interesting and so loaded with human frailties ...
Spy Game emphasizes brains over bullets and fists. It is a slickly-made film about a more cerebral conflict.
It is so insubstantial and comically weak that it barely tickles the laugh meter. It does provide a number of smiles, however.
movie_title: The Curse of the Jade Scorpion (2001)

movie_review_blurb: It is an odd mixture of the mundane, the deeply moving, the absurd and the tragic, all told with equal enthusiasm.
While the on-screen romantic chemistry between the stars is less than electrifying, the supporting performances are excellent, and production values are sky high.
Rock Star is a good idea for a movie, and is well executed with solid acting, music and production values.
It is an interesting character study as far as it goes, but it seems a bit slight and low-key. It isn't simplistic, but it isn't all that rich and complex, either.
movie_title: Le goût des autres (The Taste of Others) (2000)

movie_review_blurb: This could have and should have been a much funnier film.
While it does contain many action film clichés, it also has some quirky characters who give it some charm.
I went into "American Pie 2" with low expectations and was disappointed even at that.
As crass and foul as it may be, in this age of low-brow comedies, this is nevertheless more intelligent and witty than most.
movie_title: Jay and Silent Bob Strike Back (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Sci-fi fans will also recognize this plot from "Pitch Black" and "Red Planet," both of which are superior to this film.
Kidman hits perfect notes of stubbornness, desperation, denial and terror as the film builds to its climax.
This film adaptation of Shakespeare's "A Midsummer Night's Dream," just might be the best one ever made.
It is a charming bit of fluff, aimed at younger audiences, but there is not much cleverness to it and it is sloppily constructed.
The 40-minute car chase ... is one wild ride. The rest of the film, however, is sorely lacking.
At times, the film seems like a documentary, and other times it is more staged, but it is playful and entertaining most of the time, and always instructive.
The set-up is slow and weak, but once it gets rolling, it works pretty well.
This sequel is, like most sequels, a watered down version of the first film.
While Spade did succeed in winning my sympathy, it wasn't worth sitting through all those bad jokes and weak comedy sketches to get to that point.
It is a potent action film with some philosophical meat on its bones
This is obviously a low-budget "B" film, but it does explore some interesting ideas ... the acting is solid.
As an exercise in stunts, action and special effects, the film does well enough, but it lacks the strength of characters and story to make it better than average ...
While the story does have a lot of humiliation humor, it also has its heart in the right place most of the time.
The film's combination of sex, humor and violence looks like a cynical attempt to capitalize on the unsophisticated juvenile video market.
It delivers exactly what you would expect from a popular fairy tale in this age of digital animation.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Suffers from some of worst problems of the martial arts genre: bad dubbing, bad soundtrack, chaotic plot, no character development ... but it has great fights and stunts.
movie_title: The Legend of Drunken Master (Jui kuen II) (Drunken Fist II) (1994)
