This slow-moving film has long periods of inaction and generates little suspense, making it the worst film in the "Twilight Saga" films so far.
Great title, but this silly vigilante action movie is so exaggerated, so over-the-top that it is over the hill. It has gone to seed and needs to be weeded.

Thomas Horn's performance is the sword's edge that splits the divided reactions to this film. It is a fine performance, but the character is weird. Oskar doesn't talk like a child. He is more like a miniature Woody Allen, without the sense of humor.
The human follies abound: Running naked in the Norwegian snow, a couple of foolish affairs, a boy who wants to be a modern slave master.
A good, but not great film, it's plot seemingly derived from well-known films about films made back in the 1950s such as 'Singin' in the Rain'.
The best animated film of 2011.
Proves the old John Waters adage that the establishment thinks it is O.K. to have graphic sex scenes in movies, as long as the participants don't seem to be enjoying it.
Good performances by McGregor, Plummer and Laurent. A lot of odd characters in this film. The idea of a cute little dog communicating with people by telepathy worked pretty well.

I would be more willing to suspend my disbelief if the movie didn't drag me through this stupid psychological deterministic slime. While I do admire the filmmaking craft that went into it, the experience of watching it is less than satisfying.
movie_title: We Need to Talk About Kevin (2012)

movie_review_blurb: This film has both the strengths and weaknesses of the psychological thriller genre. Mental states are hard to depict. The strength of the genre is that it serves as a showcase for actors. It is a mixed bag, but it does deliver a heavy dose of creepiness.

While this film could win some kind of award for getting the most out of a limited budget, the low budget of the film is a handicap that isn't fully overcome. It is an experimental film that works part of the time and fails part of the time.

There has always been this ultra-cool tendency in British spy movies, but I don't ever remember seeing one this emotionless. There probably have been some, but few have combined emotional detachment with such technical mastery of filmmaking techniques.
This strange film about a woman pretending to be a man in 19th Century Ireland has some surprising twists and turns in it and some very good performances.
This whimsical, ethereal tale of love and death is as light as a feather, but charming in its own way.
It shows the worst things that people do to each other in the name of religion. This could have been more of a thought-provoking film, but it turns into a gore porn display.
This marriage for profit story featuring a delusional wedding crasher is neither romantic nor funny.
This strange film involving four clowns and an acrobat sounds like the setup for a joke, but it turns out not to be very funny.

This tragic story about the accidental death of a child raises a lot of issues about parenting, responsibility, guilt, blame and remorse. These issues have broader implications for society as a whole, far beyond this specific example.
This very unusual modern adaptation of the Shakespearean play works remarkably well, thanks to solid performances by a talented cast and a clever script.

Although this film contains a great performance by Streep (one of the greatest actors of her generation) and strong supporting performances, the muddled multi-flashback story spends far too much time on Thatcher's late life mental problems.
This film not only provides an effective love story. It goes well beyond that to examine the way believable characters deal with problems resulting from forced separation due to immigration policies.

This documentary film about the rise and fall of big nightclubs is a cautionary tale about the abuses of police power as well as a tale of two completely conflicting conservative political policies relating to the regulation of businesses.
This film works both as a suspense thriller and as a character study.
Michelle Williams, who has received a lot of criticism for the shape of her body, deserves recognition for one of the year's best performances for her very convincing portrayal of Marilyn Monroe.
A movie about our unending desire for second chances, no matter how rarely they happen.
This fresh new angle on teen sexuality goes well beyond the usual film treatment of this material, creating memorable characters and real drama.
This film will appeal to anyone of any age who doesn't have a heart of stone.
This French crime action film doesn't take long to get going and once it gets going it goes supersonic until pretty close to the end of the film.
I've seen enough of these samurai films to be in a position to say this one could be a considered a classic of the genre.
Steven Soderbergh's lean, fast-paced medical thriller 'Contagion' doesn't have much heart, but it has plenty of suspense and drama.

There have been a lot of sports dramas made into films over the years, including "Rocky" and last year's over-praised "The Fighter," but "Chariots of Fire" remains one of the best because it transcends sports.
Not perfect, but it is very good, and very moving, with some wonderful performances.
It works well enough as a revenge movie, thanks to some good performances, some good action sequences and some Mission Impossible-like tactical operations.
Surprisingly effective, even though its ape characters are a lot more interesting than the human ones.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Talented director John Favreau ("Iron Man") keeps the pace of the film brisk and you never have to wait long for some action to come along.
If Herzog had chosen realism over surrealism, this film would have been predictable and unentertaining. As it is, I found it oddly captivating. This is one weird movie.
movie_title: Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It is a good superhero origin story, a bit better than the last such Marvel movie, 'Thor.'
Thank god it is finally over.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Michael Bay's mission, and he chose to accept it, was to make a Transformers movie sequel that was not as bad as the last one. The bar was set very low for the success of this mission and Bay cleared the bar. This sequel is better than the last one.

It is a good film, but lacks the emotional punch of "Up" or the exquisite ending of "Toy Story 3." Maybe this one is bad enough that the establishment will allow an animator other than Pixar to win the top awards this year.
The only reason you go to see a movie like this is the special effects and the fight scenes, right? It has both in spades and the 3D effects are good, too.
This is a film with a message, but it doesn't preach. The primary focus of the story is not on the immigration issue, but on Tania and her love for her son.
Despite the weaknesses in the story it is pretty compelling and it has good characters worth following. The special effects are good and the story upholds a fairly good moral standard too.
The characters are well-drawn and the story is compelling. The acting is solid and the special effects and action scenes are well-done.
I was pleasantly surprised that this sequel turned out to be a good film, as opposed to most sequels, and there have been tons of them this year.
This film, despite its dazzling special effects, is devoid of originality, character and human values. It is the very embodiment of what is wrong with popular entertainment.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: This is not a great comic book adaptation, but it is a serviceable one with good production values, a slick look and a story that works.
One those exceptional sequels, even better than the original film, 'The Fast and the Furious.'
If you like creepy movies that are a bit grisly, this is better than most films of this ilk. All the talent that went into this does show.
movie_title: Don't Be Afraid Of The Dark (2011)

movie_review_blurb: This is a thought-provoking film for those interested in journalism.
movie_title: Page One: Inside the New York Times (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Expertly directed by Nicolas Winding Refn, nothing seems wasted. Every scene is lean and to the point.
The story is predictable and follows a well-worn formula, but it does it pretty well.
It's got a weak story, weak characters, weak acting and a lot of blood and gore.
In a way, Nim's life journey mirrors our own, particularly if we end up alone, no longer having much control over what happens to us.
This clumsy farce is funny in places, but the comedy is uneven, with an equal number of hits and misses. It is a kind of tame, low-rent version of 'Blazing Saddles.'

It seems American drama tends to veer between simplistic morality tales like this where the good guys eventually triumph, and nihilistic tales where evil triumphs. I prefer dramas which lie in between these two extremes.
It successfully combines action with wit, social commentary and comedy.
Generosity, compassion, courage, determination, love and caring are the things that are emphasized in this film.
It is a farce with a lot of class and style, carried off with some brilliant acting. It also has what most films with idiot plots lack, restraint, subtlety and sly wit.
Although the structure of the film is conventional, the ending of the film is not. Unlike most films, it does have a real hero, Carlos.
All the back stabbing and double dealing in the film is depressing and uninspiring. Nevertheless, I was impressed with the dialogue, the acting and overall slick way this film was crafted.
There are some good fight scenes, some nice dance numbers and a lot of swashbuckling in this film.
The film is a fascinating look inside a little-known arm of the larger environmental movement.
movie_title: If a Tree Falls: A Story of the Earth Liberation Front (2011)

movie_review_blurb: This emotional documentary film about the stages of grief, anger and recovery of people year by year after the 9/11 attacks in New York features subjects who are open, articulate and honest.
A rock documentary that makes punk rockers very human, vulnerable and down to earth. Powerful emotions are on display.
It seems to be a cross between an experimental art film and a grindhouse movie, comparing favorably to some similarly-themed mainstream movies such as 'Grindhouse.'
I felt like I was trapped on a slow-moving wagon train to nowhere with a bunch of people I wanted to escape from.
It is tough to make a comedy about cancer, since it touches us all. It is not funny. When you have Seth Rogen in a film, however, anything can be funny.

There have been a lot of movies about fighting, but few have been more personal and emotional than this one about a whole family of fighters divided by a bitter past of desertion, alcoholism, regret and death.
While most of the characters are not very appealing, young Dakota Goyo really carries the day. He keeps this film afloat when none of the other characters seem to be worth watching.
The film works well enough, despite the twisted plot, because of some nice performances by a talented cast and some well-staged action scenes.
It is not easy to make a film about quiet courage and unassuming heroes like these, but this film rises to that challenge and hits one right out of the park.
What it does have is a very smart script and a tremendous amount of visual flair.
The film is well-written and well-acted by a talented cast of performers.

It looks like most of the money spent in this project went to explosions, which are many and huge, and to acting salaries, at the expense of special effects and the script, which could have used a big upgrade.
You would think after all these decades of making these kinds of movies Disney would do a better job with this, but it really is terrible.
This film is probably yet another bit of fallout from that blight on civilization known as reality television. God help us all.
A half hour of entertainment sprinkled sparingly over 2.5 hours.
This film is both funny and moving. It focuses on how families can provide strength in times of need.
The jokes and sight gags are hit and miss, but the plot and characters are compelling and it has a lot of twists and turns that keep you guessing right up to the end.
Funny, but not as funny as Raimi's earlier horror films were.

There are no sustained characters of any kind, despite some capable acting talent. There is no believable relationship between the characters. There is no attempt to develop any of the political issues the film touches upon.
It does focus on spirituality, a vital part of most human beings which nevertheless is absent in most films.
This is a good romantic comedy, and that is a genre that often gets messed up. Here, the old formula comes out just right.
The scattershot story never builds dramatic momentum, but it does take some interesting twists and turns and it does have an air of authenticity.
An unfunny comedy with a limited imagination and a steady diet of fat jokes.
If the movie is trying to help us understand what schizophrenia is, it fails in the attempt.
Dan Brown may not know much about history, religion or science, but the guy can spin quite a yarn.
Great characters, nice comic touches, but the plot cries out for an intervention.
Not bad. It is funny and touching at times, even though the premise is pretty close to impossible.

The latest edition of the X-Men franchise is easily the least, with a convoluted storyline, poorly defined characters and a dark one-note tone that lacks the humor and light touches of the earlier three installments.
An astonishing achievement for writer-actor François Bégaudeau who adapted his own book for the screenplay and also stars in this absorbing film about the challenges of teaching in a public school.
The production values of this film are very good, but it wanders away from its three main storylines often enough that it may not hold the attention of children.
As you would expect, this is a sci-fi war movie of man against machine and there is plenty of action, but also some food for thought.

Now that all the actors playing children in this series of movies have grown up and become adults, finally we get to the first movie in the series that allows them to act like children, however briefly.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The movie also has its heart in the right place and it is as earnest as it can be. It simply falls short of being a great movie.
Apatow and Sandler chose not to wander far from their core teen male audience, even in this darkly comic film about a comic movie star reevaluating his life in the face of death.
Writer-director Nicolas Winding Refn uses some inventive theatrical interludes and soliloquies to diversify what might have otherwise been a rather one-note depiction of prison life.
Regardless of whether or not the film means anything at all, it is a triumph of visual imagination, production and set design and costuming.
It is, quite simply, a dazzling piece of filmmaking.

The quality of the stories has gradually declined in each succeeding sequel since the original film was released in 2002, but the technical quality of computer animation has improved during that same time.
movie_title: Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs (Ice Age 3) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It doesn't break any new ground or have any new ideas. It is just a perfectly cast, well-written, well-directed, well-acted film that is bloody funny.

This movie does what science fiction is supposed to do, but seldom does anymore, it makes a comment about today's society by taking current trends and carrying them to a profound technological conclusion.
The result of this odd mix of elements is a film that is both genuinely funny and moving.
Is Whitacre as smart as he seems to be, or is he as dumb as he seems to be? One thing's for sure, nobody knows what this guy is going to pull next.
This film is uneven, but it has enough effective humor, good characters and nice 3D animation to make an entertaining movie.
movie_title: Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs (2009)

movie_review_blurb: If you can get past the mercurial changes in emotions and the slow pace you'll find a film that has a lot to say about war and peace, hatred and love, revenge and reconciliation
The basic material is here for a good film, but it doesn't quite achieve that threshold. Fortunately, the film has some interesting characters.
That potential is not realized in "Shorts" primarily because of the chaotic structure of the story, which lurches back through a series of disjointed flashbacks.
movie_title: Shorts: The Adventures of the Wishing Rock (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Enough action and ghoulish humor to offset all the boring "my dinner with Fritz" pace-killing scenes, adolescent slasher gore, misogyny and Bush-Cheney-inspired anything-goes war rules.
A very odd black comedy.
Another brilliant animation by a Japanese master.
A delightful dessert of a movie.
The film's message, that compassion and humanity extend far beyond our own species, isn't subtle, but it is effective.
Time travel is an interesting plot device, even when it doesn't work well. It works just barely well enough in this movie.
As a pure action movie, a popcorn movie if you will, G.I. Joe delivers the goods.
movie_title: G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A good old school western with solid acting, a great musical score, wonderful cinematography and beautiful desert scenery.
This slapdash documentary about left wing political movements is probably best understood in the original French and was a lot more relevant in 1977 when it was first made.
movie_title: Le Fond de l'air est rouge (A Grin Without a Cat) (The Base of the Air Is Red) (1977)

movie_review_blurb: 'Fight Night' (AKA Rigged) is no classic but it works the fight movie formula well enough to make it a winner.
While the drama surrounding the murder is not especially gripping, the drama on the journalism side of the story is palpable.
A methodical, but workable suspense film with one big action scene.
A conventional sports movie with an Oscar-worthy performance by Mickey Rourke.
It is hard to empathize with the petty problems of people living in luxurious houses the size of hotels when so many people in American have lost their homes.
Agonizingly slow-moving and it has a bare-bones plot in which nothing much happens.
Interesting characters interact in a complex tangle of interesting relationships.
As lovers, these two are not convincing. They don't produce enough of a spark to set off gasoline vapor.
A unique film. On the one hand, this is a silly musical comedy and mock documentary. On the other hand, it is also a serious documentary about a woman who seems to have sold her soul for power.
The result of all this combined talent is a masterpiece of a film that reveals the hidden disease at the heart of American life in the 1950s.
This documentary about a famous family of nomadic surfers is fascinating not only because of the certifiable oddball patriarch, but also because of his endlessly creative offspring.
The film looks great and the story is interesting enough for adults. It may be a little too complex and intense for young children.
Reveals ceremonies that are exotic, unexpected, colorful and incredibly ritualized, layered with vast amounts of denial, submerged agendas and hypocrisy.
A film that exemplifies the popular artistic notion of inescapable tragic destiny.
If you want to see a movie about mutants with superpowers, watch any of the X-Men movies or the "Hellboy" movies or "Wanted," any of those six movies is far superior to this.
This is a classic fantasy tale in the great tradition of the brothers Grimm and it is wonderfully visualized.
This is a lean, spare film, which is highly visual. There are long stretches of film with no dialog.
The film is done with style. Mostly through images.
Starts out like a tragedy, but lo and behold, this tale of woe turns into a nice little romantic comedy.
The first hour of "Lifelines" (AKA Wherever You Are) is as powerful as any movie I've seen in a long time.
The details of how the event was planned and staged are fascinating, but a crucial element missing from the film is good cinematography of the actual event.
It combines romance, comedy, the supernatural, violence, whimsy and music in a unique way.
The film isn't entirely believable in some places, but I did admire the skill of the storytelling and the neat way all the pieces come together.
The screenplay is fairly standard and even has a few cracks in it, but this film does have exceptional performances. Those performances lift this film above mediocrity.
An effective morality play. The plot has enough twists and turns in it to keep it interesting.
It might even be enough to get Americans up off their fat butts and do something to save themselves and their children.
Most war movies don't cover this painful subject, the loss of the innocents, but this film does. Attention must be paid.
A comedy so dark you have to turn the house lights on to see the screen.
This is not a movie for those with weak stomachs, but it is haunting if you can stomach the disgusting acts of sexual abuse and murder.
Some of the most amazing achievements of the prehistoric cultures of the British Isles are on display in this unique, folksy, entertaining travelogue.
movie_title: Standing With Stones: A Journey Through Megalithic Britain (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Its strength lies in the power of its characters, each of whom is flawed but also very compelling.
Director Cristian Mungiu makes effective use of fairly static camera setups, in addition to some hand-held shots, to give the film a documentary feel.
Not as funny as the title would suggest.
movie_title: El Baño del Papa (The Pope's Toilet) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Shallow, lighthearted, funny romp, but aimed more at juveniles and adults than young children.
A battle of wits with smart, capable people on all sides. It is very slick and well-acted by a troupe of pros.
A vulgar comedy that is pretty crude, but pretty funny, too.
It predicts a future when people act courageously and selflessly to preserve their families and the future of mankind. I can get behind that.
A real departure for Van Dame, but it ought to help his career. Who knew he could act?
Leaves a lot to be desired from the standpoint of plot, character development and scientific credibility.
Nails the fact that murder, injuries, sexual abuse, humiliation and degradation of prisoners was covered up and condoned at the highest levels of the Bush Administration.
Overlong examination of the life of an enigmatic, willful, disengenuous, fascinating, influential and enormously gifted filmmaker.
movie_title: Wonderful, Horrible Life of Leni Riefenstahl (1993)

movie_review_blurb: It is a very positive film, so it won't appeal to cynics, but it should appeal to just about everyone else.
The inevitability of the loss of innocence and tragedy is a heavy burden for the audience to bear.
movie_title: The Boy in the Striped Pajamas (The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: This movie is very deliberately aimed at teenaged boys (soft porn and gore porn) and it should do very well in the video market as well as at the box office.
This is a movie specially made for viewers who like a surprise ending.
This is supposed to be a romantic drama, but Woody Allen could have made a very funny film out of this exact same story.
This is one of Pixar's better films, comparable to 'The Incredibles.'
Both thought-provoking and entertaining.

The characters are the strong suit of this film, and the story is very good as well. The animation and 3D effects are excellent, especially the flying scenes, which are reminiscent of those in 'Avatar.'
The story is interesting enough, but the characters are so shallow and venal I couldn't work up any interest in what happens to them.

There are number of loose ends that are not tied up and some character motivations don't add up. Nevertheless, Polanski polishes everything until it gleams. This is a very slick, good-looking production.

The acting is excellent by this very capable cast, and the story is interesting. The cinematography, by Sebastian Edschmid (Adam Resurrected) is also excellent. The outdoor scenes are lush and gorgeous.
This has the look of a cheap quickie foreign film, not unlike a Hong Kong action film.
The look of the film is electric with amazing creatures and incredibly varied landscapes from lush to bleak.
In a sense, "Green Zone" is a movie which goes to great pains to point out the obvious.
The broken field running of the film's time line requires each viewer to reassemble the story in his head.
The dull gray monotony of existence never looked as uninviting as it does in this film.
People often behave foolishly in matters of love and just about everything else. That can lead to heartache and tragedy, but that same foolishness can also be very funny to watch, as it is here.
Unfortunately, despite clever writing and all of Scorcese's cinematic tricks, this film is not engrossing, compelling or entertaining. It is a slick, but hollow exercise in genre filmmaking.
An awful lot of acting talent goes to waste in this film, but there is barely enough here to marginally satisfy the younger set.
movie_title: Percy Jackson & the Olympians: The Lightning Thief (2010)

movie_review_blurb: I did find this film to be a little better than "Twilight" because of the romantic triangle aspect. That, and other plot developments add some complexity and suspense, making the film a bit more interesting.
The look, the unconventional cast and the unconventional story make this a unique film, one of Altman's best.
One would have to invoke supernatural influences to make it believable, and that is pretty much what is being invoked.
The story is odd and doesn't really hang together very well, but the film is worth watching mainly to experience the wonder of Mr. Gilliam's fantastic visual imagination.
Passable entertainment because it is more imaginative than most vampire films and because of Willem Dafoe's performance, but it should have been better.
This bittersweet family road film about a man trying to forge new connections to his children and grandchildren is powered by a strong Robert De Niro performance.
A very ambitious film that journeys up the Danube from its mouth to it's source('s), noting the history of places, people and thought along its 3,000 kilometer length.
All in all, it is a pretty good adventure. The acting is adequate, but in these kinds of film it really isn't about the acting at all, is it?
The documentary film crew gets remarkable behind-the-scenes access to Valentino's fashion empire.
Certainly entertaining enough as an action film and it works well enough as a love story, but there are some serious problems with the dramatic portions of the film and its warped moral message.
Typical popcorn film, except for the huge budget.
The battles seem more realistic because they are done essentially like a stage play in real time. This requires real skill and training.
A mysterious main character, lots of action and a complicated plot combine for a pretty good summer popcorn movie.
Most sequels are inferior to the original film, but "Predators" is an exception, a film that stands on its own and is the equal of the original film.
It shows a fair amount of visual imagination, a brisk pace, solid acting, and lots of action, but is lacking in imagination when it comes to story and dialogue.
Kiddie-level animated feature with a lot of jokes that hit below the belt, but the characters are lovable and its heart is in the right place.

I thought this film was going to be a real brain-twister like "Memento" or "The Prestige," but "Inception" is not all that complicated, which is helpful, given all those special game-type rules you have to keep track of.
Watching this was a waste of time.
movie_title: Le Voyage du Ballon Rouge (The Flight of the Red Balloon) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The third in the Twilight series of films may be the best so far, but I still wonder if this series will ever amount to anything besides box office gold.
It is no surprise to me it is doing a better business at the box office than most experts anticipated.

What is missing from this version of Robin Hood is the fun that usually goes with things like robbing the rich and giving the loot to the poor. This comes across as very serious, and it doesn't need to be.

Douglas gives a tour de force performance here and the rest of the cast is excellent as well. While I couldn't really buy Kalmen's behavior based on his motivations, Douglas does a tremendous job of selling this character anyway.
This is a summer action film and it does deliver on the promise of action. While the action is so extreme as to border on silliness, this is often done intentionally for comic effect.
This is a story that most people can probably relate to, unless you are one of those lucky people never to have been on the losing end of the game of love.
Wacky, over-the-top action sequences, self-mocking tone and quirky characters combine to make a good summer action movie.
A powerful emotional kick, strong performances and pretty scenery overcome the overlong, overstuffed plot.
Combs, the only breath of fresh air in the film, is the only guy in the whole movie who is in on the joke.
A swashbuckler in the grand tradition, it has the ingredients of a good summer popcorn movie.
movie_title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010)

movie_review_blurb: There probably will not be another Shrek movie, but if there isn't, this is a good place to end the franchise, and two out of three is a far better average, as far as quality goes, than most sequels.
Fantastic creatures, fantastic photography
Nygard has done a terrific job of asking questions, getting answers and finding interesting people to appear in this film.

The story makes little sense to those unfamiliar with Indian culture and literary traditions, but it is made accessible for westerners by the use of a kind of Greek Chorus of shadow puppets who help interpret the story.
The film does go through a lot of extra action sequences just to fill up time (not just one, but three trips in a dump truck) but it is worth the wait for that exquisite ending.
Another in the endless stream of movies about the British monarchy, but a cut above the average in terms of story and acting.
The problem trying to deal with a self-destructive pessimist is you can never convince them that tomorrow might just be a better day.
One of those rare, intelligent, thought-provoking science fiction films that come along less often than a blue moon, but there are some problems with the narrative and the science.

A remarkable story, all the more remarkable for the era in which it happened, an era when most women had almost no opportunities to become famous, rich and powerful. Gertrude Berg not only triumphed during this time, she was the Oprah Winfrey of her time.
Every player in the NFL should see this film. They need to start treating the former players with some respect and treat them right.
The overall story serves as a metaphor for American life, where too many people spend a lot of time keeping busy without ever really enjoying the moment and without ever being truly alive.
This is sort of a modern costume drama. It is a lot like a Jane Austen story.
An interesting low-budget cinematic experiment, but I just couldn't work up much enthusiasm for it. The experiment may have been a success, but the subject is dead.

One shocking segment of the film follows the story of Moe Parr, a man legally hounded out of his business of cleaning seeds. He is a victim of laws which allow seed patents which are leading to corporate seed monopolies.
It is suitable for kids, and parents won't have to suffer much if they accompany the kids.
This is one of those movies that makes you want to find out what happens next, and those are the best kind.
This story is a myth, but it is pleasant, gentle and funny. Like all myths, it reveals certain truths.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: This is definitely a side of the news that gets very little play in the mainstream media. For that reason alone, this film is worth a look.
This film is not very believable, and it really doesn't seem to go anywhere.
It's got a story, it's got music, it even has a hero, but what it lacks is soul.

This is not just a character study. This film has battle scenes of such immediacy, intensity and suspense it puts the battle scenes in most other war movies to shame.
It is a sweeping epic with classical themes lifted from the teachings of Joseph Campbell, but it maintains strong central characters.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode IV - A New Hope (1977)

movie_review_blurb: [A] sorry excuse for a comedy.
Not to say this is not a well-crafted movie with excellent performances. It is. It is also curiously one-sided and shallow like many movies about famous outlaws tend to be.
In this adaptation, the Arthur Conan Doyle character is turned into a slightly crazed superhero, an autistic detective savant, in an action movie.
This film is dark and scary enough that it just might scare some in the audience straight.
This movie is well acted, directed, edited and filmed, however, it is also depressing, uninspiring and sickening. Like a glacier, it moves slowly and inexorably towards its final conclusion.
Strong acting props up this emotionless process film. It is like something David Mamet would make, slick and clever, but lacking in real feeling or drama.
Paul is a sad figure, but the edge is taken off this by his single-minded (some would say dim-witted) devotion to the Giants.
It defies most conventions and it defies most categories too. It is part ghost story, part romance and part murder mystery.

A film that never rises beyond the workmanlike to the inspired.
It's all a bit underwhelming.
Ends on a mixed note of hope and helplessness that clings to the consciousness for days.
The story speaks to universal human emotions that transcend country and culture.
Violent but compelling yarn.
It slowly builds in emotional power.
Emotionally arid and narratively lazy, the film is so tentative it seems to be evaporating before our very eyes.
It's not particularly good as a movie but as a collection of jokes it's pretty sublime.
Cars creates a world so palpably real that within minutes we accept that its only sentient creatures are automobiles.
A collection of good jokes looking for a plot, Thank You works best as a character study of a contentedly amoral man.
While it delivers a few good laughs, the film is short on drama and suspense.

In short, an overwhelmingly joyless movie consumed with its own sense of importance.

movie_title: The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada (2006)

To watch Michelangelo Antonioni's 1975 masterpiece is to see film the way it once was and may never be again.

In the end V for Vendetta is as cold and unsympathetic as the regime it criticizes.
Utterly forgettable.
While offering no tidy answers, The Big Question does illustrate the astounding variety of human experience and belief. Perhaps we can find some spiritual satisfaction in that.
Amusing and often outright hilarious.
movie_title: Tristram Shandy: A Cock & Bull Story (2005)

... all atmosphere with little dramatic juice.

A comedy that's never funny enough or clever enough.
Almost nothing works in this incoherent and uncompelling movie.

Cheap-looking, gore-drenched and so postmodern and self-consciously above it all that it's hard to care about anyone's fate, Feast is sort of a mean-spirited variation on the vastly superior Tremors.
A gripping, deeply affecting experience delivered with no Hollywood hooey but an appreciation of small lives and human foibles.

One of the season's most humane and heartening films.

Colorful, respectful and features cinematography (by Reed Smoot) so flat-out beautiful that you'll spend most of its 40 minutes with your mouth open.

A crashing bore.

It's a movie so audacious as to take your breath away -- and one whose slashing style infuriates almost as often as it satisfies.
This film feels truly lived in, and guides us without ever feeling manipulative or calculating. The performances are naturalistic and utterly convincing.
Will leave audiences cold and not a little depressed.
Full of surprises.
A film as mournful as it is amusing, one that forces even a seasoned agent provocateur like Moore to admit that he cannot answer the questions he poses.
Everything about the production is tasteful and carefully modulated -- but there's no spunk here.
The ambiguous note on which Heaven ends would be irritating in a conventional film, but here it seems curiously fitting.
Just about everyone involved here seems to be coasting. There are a few modest laughs, but certainly no thrills.
Kinnear and Dafoe give what may be the performances of their careers.
Warm, funny, informative, breathlessly paced and inspiring.
Wright's direction starts out realistically enough but gradually deteriorates into what feels like a messy parody of a European art film.
Borat will offend as many as it delights. It's practically a litmus test for thick-skinnedness. It's also one of the funniest movies ever made.
movie_title: Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Nolan is a very clever fellow, no argument there. He's skilled at juggling big ideas and making us think. Now if he can just make us feel.

The real revelation is Hill. Usually cast as a scruffy type, here the portly actor is fastidiously clean-cut and well-groomed, a façade of normalcy that makes his anger and insecurity all the more disturbing.
Perhaps Chanel and Stravinsky were too consumed by their art and egos to be truly vulnerable and giving. Certainly they're not portrayed as likable.
Mere mediocrity is soon forgotten. Pure awfulness endures.
At every opportunity Kurt Wimmer's screenplay puts star Angelina Jolie into situations that are pure Hollywood hokum and from which no mere mortal could escape unscathed, although she always does.
The production's blend of traditional cowboy tropes and 20th-century elements give it an out-of-time feel that's appropriate for what is basically a teenage boy's extended fantasy.
movie_title: The Good, the Bad, the Weird (Joheun-nom, Nabbeun-nom, Isanghan-nom) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The key word here is "work." If she isn't out there making somebody laugh, Rivers feels she no longer exists.
movie_title: Joan Rivers: A Piece Of Work (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Something's wrong when dead rodents generate a film's biggest laughs.
Have the movies ever seen a heroine like Lisbeth Salander?
movie_title: The Girl Who Played with Fire (Flickan som lekte med elden) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Fans had hoped that having Robert Rodriguez as a producer would revitalize the series. Sorry, this is just more of the same.
A comedy that perfectly balances natural hilarity with genuine drama while exploring a whole slew of issues.
Sounds fairly simple, but Blakeson has a fiendish way of twisting around his plot and characters.
This documentary from writer Sebastian Junger will leave audiences with a new admiration for what fighting men must endure.
Basically you have Ferrell -- whose recent output might charitably be described as "iffy" -- working a couple of dweeby riffs for all they're worth.

Let us not underestimate the contribution of our lead. Roberts plays down the glamour and turns up the soulfulness, and her off-the-charts likability makes her winning and watchable, even when Liz is at her whiny wimpiest.
There's only so much you can wring out of detachment.
Lucy Walker's documentary is a blood-curdling look at the world's nuclear arsenal that suggests atomic Armageddon remains every bit as likely as during the height of the Cold War.
There's zero heat between Aniston and Bateman; what synthetic feelings the film does generate involve the father/son relationship.
Gotta love Emma Thompson. Her Nanny McPhee persona? That's another story.
A slickly efficient cops-and-robbers yarn, largely uncomplicated yet offering a few moments of insight and dramatic weight.
While the tone of Return to El Salvador is cautiously optimistic and generally even-handed, there's no escaping the lump of outrage at its center
Swinton saves the day.
Behind the Burly Q is a mess, but an enjoyable one.
A bit of whimsy is good. Unfettered whimsy? Well, that may wear out its welcome.

As a mystery, Mother dishes a couple of shocking turnarounds, but its real value is as a character study of a woman whose desperate love pushes her to decisive action, even if the source of her devotion isn't worth it.
Catch a Fire was shot in South Africa and is well-acted by Luke and Robbins, who give their characters complexity and subtlety.
It feels narratively overcooked and comically undernourished, a pale shadow of the earlier entries.
Is Exit Through the Gift Shop a real documentary or an expert hoax? Does it really matter as long as you're laughing and thinking?
Like most Jerry Bruckheimer-produced hot-weather epics, it's big, loud and as empty as a loan shark's conscience.
movie_title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010)

movie_review_blurb: For the first hour or so it works. Unfortunately, the film is two and a half hours long.

Its real power lies in the passage of time, the dull ache of loss and the grim satisfaction of revenge, and yearnings of love unrealized. There's an awful lot going on in this film, and all of it is good.
movie_title: The Secret in Their Eyes (El Secreto de Sus Ojos) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The film isn't good, exactly -- Natali struggles to keep the creepy and goofy elements in balance -- but it's just weird enough to become a cult favorite.
Jackie Chan, Oscar nominee? Not as farfetched as you might think.
All this makes for a hugely insightful drama but not a particularly endearing one.
For those willing to pay attention and get into the rhythms of this stubbornly unconventional movie, the rewards are substantial.
There's lots of action, most of it so badly edited you can't tell the good guys from the bad guys.
You can try to put on your game face, to resist the emotional call of Toy Story 3. But you'll find yourself practically sobbing over the fate of inanimate objects.
No movie is perfect, but this Sundance winner comes close.
Survival is crawling with weird ideas that make no sense, but Romero treats them as gems of life-changing import.

Nothing earth-shaking goes on here, and Holofcener has the good sense not to make her issues seem all that important. This is a lightweight comedy about mostly likable people who are a bit too wrapped up in self-analysis.
It's lightweight but enjoyable summer fun.
The latest from Adam Sandler is a big unruly bundle of midlife clichés peppered with the physical sadism and potty humor that are the hallmarks of Sandler's comedy.
Garcia keeps his various stories flowing and in perfect balance.
Compared to Ben Kalmen, the aggressively amoral former car dealer Douglas portrays in Solitary Man, Gekko is an upright guy.
A terrifically smart film that precariously balances sophisticated laughs and inspired visual slapstick.
A quietly amusing minimalist tale of a grouch who finds he's still capable of pleasure.
A French film about a traitor you can't help but love.
It's like ordering a hamburger and getting escargot. Which is OK if you like snail, but it's an acquired taste.
Screenwriter Mary Bing and director Dover Koshashvili seem baffled about what they're trying to say here.
I know, I know ... how exciting can a cooking movie be? As it turns out, really exciting.
Director Robert Schwentke does as much as he can with the cartoonish story and stunts but after a while can no longer maintain the illusion that RED is actually about anything.
Waiting for 'Superman' isn't just a well-made, persuasive documentary. It's a turning point. At least you come out of the theater hoping so.
"Heartbreaker" has some amusing moments and gorgeous settings (the Riviera), but it never achieves the smooth slickness director Pascal Chaumeil aims for.
Stephane Brizi's "Mademoiselle Chambon" is a remarkably moving effort, thanks to two superbly down-to-earth performances.
There are momentary flashes of dramatic power here, but ultimately "Stone" runs aground on its unfulfilled ambitions, which are both lofty and maddeningly vague.
As an evocation of a time, a place and especially a state of mind, Howl is fascinating.
Here a mature filmmaker at the top of his game muses on life after death. But this is no starry-eyed, gullible wallow in the bathos of eternal bliss.
Despite the long haul that the siblings endure, Goldwyn and screenwriter Pamela Gray give the story an immediacy and dramatic tension.
Leaving The Tillman Story you won't know whether to weep or put your fist through a wall. This documentary from director Amir Bar-Lev is that powerful.
Work of art or huge practical joke? Can't say, but you've never seen anything remotely like Enter the Void.
Ultimately it's a collection of gags that don't add up to much.
Megamind is full of good ideas. But they never coalesce into a satisfying whole.

For Colored Girls raises the question of whether Perry, having made more money than he could possibly spend, will now turn his attention to ever more challenging, if not so popular, stories and themes. If so, this film is a good first step.
The real subjects -- and strengths -- in this narrowly focused biopic are the two women who, more than any one else, were responsible for molding the future star's psyche.
Heartbreaking and humanistic in the best sense.
A remarkably pure cinema experience, not just because it's about selfless parental devotion but because the film itself has been stripped down to the basics.
A sobering and sad story of the terrible cost of a lack of moral fiber. Not a happy yarn, but it's been well-acted, and afterward you'll feel as if you've been at sea for a week.
McAdams goes beyond the cute-young-thing and makes Becky a workaholic who's a bit challenged in the love department. It's not much, but it's enough to keep our interest.
Don't go to Unstoppable looking for subtext or subtlety or any of that other fancy-schmancy stuff. Go for 100 minutes of nonstop thrills.
Whatever its failings, Hornet's Nest allows us to say goodbye to beloved characters. That is, unless those rumors of a fourth Millennium book prove true.
movie_title: The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest (2010)

movie_review_blurb: There's no arguing with the performances.
It's a gentle meditation on food and companionship.
Never Let Me Go offers a potent blend of intriguing premise, fine acting and quiet poignancy. Usually this would leave me an emotional wreck. Yet it didn't.
Aside from the inherent thrill of the races themselves, the new equine biopic Secretariat is dull stuff.
Making a parody of bad movies that is itself not a bad movie is a delicate balancing act, and Rodriguez and Maniquiz get it right about half the time.
A relationship movie in which the f-bomb gets dropped about once a minute and the screen is dotted with bare derrieres (male).
A sumptuous feast for heart, head, eye and ear.
The movie works, thanks in large part to Chi's performance.
Hilarious.
The latest from director Rob Reiner is a well-meaning mess that wants to tap into universal experiences of childhood and first love but bogs down in squirm-inducing banalities.
Ghost Bird feels a bit flat and by-the-numbers, and at almost 90 minutes, padded.
Ben Affleck grew up in Boston, which may explain why The Town reeks of authenticity, along with a palpable sense of desperation and existential angst.
This is all fine, but it doesn't add up to much. There's no through-story here, just a collection of observations.
movie_title: Brutal Beauty: Tales of the Rose City Rollers (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Very well-made and well-acted.
A funny, sweet and pleasantly goofy exercise in the language of Goethe.
Douglas is fun to watch. Little else in this movie is.
I did a lot of squirming with this one.
Writer-directors Peter Brosens and Jessica Hope Woodworth are less interested in telling a conventional story than in dispensing poetic impressions. And, boy, do they.
You'll learn about an important artist from this film, but you'll also leave feeling a bit ravished.
movie_title: Louis Sullivan: The Struggle For American Architecture (2009)

movie_review_blurb: This is one of the best movies ever about film directors.
A wrenching, deeply disturbing drama about a kid who finds that his relatives are conscienceless crooks.

The brilliance of Eisenberg's performance is that even when you want to slap his Zuckerberg silly you can't help but admire his creativity, his ambition and his almost religious dedication to the Internet's potential.
A mere shadow of its predecessor.
A modest but effective comment on the chaos, brutality and dehumanization of combat.
Perhaps the best recommendation one can give Let Me In is that you walk out thinking not about the horror but about the heartbreak.
Graced by appealing newcomer Keir Gilchrist and augmented by a heartbreaking serio-comic Zach Galifianakis, this junior-level Cuckoo's Nest is smart and sensitive.
movie_title: It's Kind of a Funny Story (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Ironically, The Secret of Kells might be best served by watching it with the sound turned off. As a purely visual experience it has no peer.
This ugly-duckling romance is as stale as last week's bagel.
This Robin is undoubtedly more authentic to the realities of life in 12th-century Britain than the iconic Errol Flynn version. That doesn't make it more enjoyable.
The story it tells is little short of incredible.
A phony premise made tolerable only by the efforts of a strong cast.
The results are honorable but not terribly interesting.
movie_title: The Private Lives of Pippa Lee (2009)

movie_review_blurb: So earnest that it borders on hagiography, Clint Eastwood's Invictus remains a powerful slice of history that will leave you amazed at the decency of which we are capable.
As drama Red Cliff is overwrought. As spectacle, though, John Woo's latest is the real thing, an old-fashioned cast-of-thousands collision of armies.
The film's trailers don't fully convey the credible magnificence of Cameron's vision, one that sucks us in and makes us believe.
This is what happens when you throw reliable talent at an awful script.
movie_title: Did You Hear About the Morgans? (2009)

movie_review_blurb: As serious as it is funny, as substantial as it is breezy, Up in the Air is an astonishing balancing act from writer/director Jason Reitman.

Linklater's directing style is pretty much gimmick-free. No razzle-dazzle is required when you have a story as rich as this, characters as fascinating as these and actors who can bring it all to life.
Worst of all, this Sherlock Holmes isn't fun.

Just roll with the amusement provided by Cera and a deep supporting cast (Justin Long, Fred Willard, Adhir Kalyan, Jonathan B. Wright) and the ability of director Arteta and screenwriter Gustin Nash to keep matters at just the right ironic distance.
Imaginarium might have worked as a short film, but at two hours it becomes a soul-sucking void.

Without ever turning didactic, "The Maid" suggests that domestic employment cannot help but affect human relationships. It may be honest work, but that doesn't mean that on some level it doesn't wear away at the soul.
You leave this film with the sense of having spent time with real people with real-world problems.
Sex, cinema and fate -- three of Pedro Almodovar's favorite subjects -- are lovingly examined in his Broken Embraces.
Ultimately, The Lovely Bones works best when Ronan simply reads Sebold's simple yet evocative prose.

Not only does it contain Colin Firth's finest screen performance to date, but it was directed by tyro filmmaker Tom Ford (the fashion designer and former Gucci executive) with the sort of assurance one associates with Citizen Kane.
Not even an actor with Washington's gravitas can keep eyes from rolling at the silliness dished here.
Above all else the film is a treasure trove of fantastic archival material, much of it never before shown.
Writer Jim Britts and director Brian Baugh know what they want to say but ultimately fall short of delivering the full-blooded drama they're after. And at two hours the film is way too long.
The whole affair has the atmosphere of a disease-of-the-week drama.
It seems a strange thing to say about one of the most depressing films ever offered as popular entertainment, but The Road is a beautiful movie.
What it lacks in originality, Crazy Heart makes up for in delivery.
Spielmann sets a tone of weary desperation and rarely strays from it. Not a happy film, but a gripping one.
There's little dramatic tension and, despite the fact that Bella is being stalked by the vengeful vampire Victoria (Rachelle Lefevre), not much sense of danger.
As a jigsaw puzzle it's diverting, but I never cared much for the people.
If you must, go for the scenery.
The Baker is an iffy affair made palatable mostly by Lewis' lead performance, an attractive blend of naivete and deadly efficiency. But we've seen it before.
The onslaught of tastelessness begins even before the opening credits and continues nonstop for 103 deliciously sleazy minutes.
movie_title: Not Quite Hollywood: The Wild, Untold Story of Ozploitation! (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The resulting movie isn't for young children. I'm not sure it's for grown-ups, either -- not unless they're into boredom.
Director F. Gary Gray keeps the thrills coming at a relentless pace that leaves little time to ponder the Mack truck-sized holes in the logic.
It's kinda inspiring. It's also very funny.
The strong supporting cast is wasted... evidently these characters would have more to do in sequels which, let us pray, we never have to sit through.
movie_title: Cirque du Freak: The Vampire's Assistant (2009)

movie_review_blurb: There's plenty to both cheer and ponder.
Despite the padding, there's enough interesting sociological digging here -- not to mention the easygoing presence of comic Chris Rock -- to keep us entertained and even enlightened.
This film, coming 72 years after Earhart vanished -- plays it awfully safe.
The brothers' deadpan style is hugely effective -- so much so that even if you hate the message you enjoy the messengers.
You can try to resist it, but by the time Cherien Dabis' writing/directing effort is over, you'll be completely sucked in.
An epic look at a recent blood-soaked episode of post-war Germany.
movie_title: Der Baader Meinhof Komplex (The Baader Meinhof Complex) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: In the end you don't have to analyze it... that tear in your eye tells you it's working.
In the end the film is more desultory than disturbing.
The Men Who Stare at Goats is a handful of hilarious scenes looking for a movie.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Now we know how the world ends -- with a whimper, a very loud whimper.
The soundtrack overflows with great rock, and individual scenes and performances click.
It's all very uplifting. It might even move some youngsters to start their own businesses.

That Krentz keeps all these balls in the air for as long as he does is little short of amazing. There's nothing wrong with this filmmaker that a bit of maturing can't rectify; with any luck we'll be seeing much more from Matt Krentz.

Especially effective is the gently comic interplay between the solemn Michael (Aaron has little dialogue but speaks volumes through his expressive eyes) and Bullock's pushy Southern mama, who has a firm grip on tough love and usually gets what she wants.

There's no way that Inside Job can be described as an enjoyable night at the movies... not unless unbridled greed, rampant arrogance and eager malfeasance leading to the collapse of the republic is your idea of a good time.
Love him or loathe him, the Melster still has screen presence. That's why he's a star.

Features Oscar winners Benicio Del Toro and Anthony Hopkins at their most take-the-money-and-run uninspired. That the film is set in the 1890s didn't prevent these two from phoning in their performances.
Date Night is an OK comedy. But that's not good enough.
It's a tale we've heard 100 times, like another three-chord bar-band rock anthem.
The result is a film that seems to slide effortlessly between situations and seasons, presenting a kaleidoscopic look at a community.
This well-made film chronicles the sweat, tears, false starts and massive expenditures involved in getting such an operation up and running.
Good detective stories need a solid mystery, sure, but they also thrive on unusual characters. The Swedish Girl With the Dragon Tattoo has a whopper.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2009)

movie_review_blurb: By turns scathingly satiric and fan-boy celebratory, ridiculously violent and politically incorrect (at least when it comes to our notions of childhood), Kick-Ass is an absolute hoot.

Alain Cavalier's film, in re-release, offers plenty of left/right, labor/management, humanity/ideology contrasts, but dramatically it's silly. It's worth watching for Schneider, who is simply radiant.
movie_title: Le Combat dans l'île (Fire and Ice) (1962)

movie_review_blurb: As it stands, it's a mildly diverting dramedy of missed opportunities.
We can care about irritating characters, sure. But not this one.
At least they got the name right.
Giovanna Mezzogiorno's performance is so rife with eroticism and anger that it's practically operatic. Yet it remains firmly grounded in reality.
Filled with familial love, youthful spontaneity and gentle humor.
movie_title: L' Argent de Poche (Pocket Money) (Small Change) (1976)

movie_review_blurb: The screenplay by Danny Dey and Nilsson is nothing if not ambitious; in fact it may cram too many big ideas -- most about the uncomfortable truce between the sexes -- into a small space.
You needn't like the characters in a noir thriller as long as you're immersed in their growing desperation.
A portrait of a marriage that epitomizes "lives of quiet desperation."
This is such a gripping yarn it plays more like a thriller than a documentary.
movie_title: Most Dangerous Man in America: Daniel Ellsberg and the Pentagon Papers (2009)

movie_review_blurb: I'd have told even non-comic book fans to see the original Iron Man. I'd recommend this sequel mostly to the initiated... which probably accounts for 80 percent of all moviegoers.

There's no narrator telling us what we're looking at or what to think. The adults here speak different languages, but the film is such a tour de force of visual storytelling that subtitles are unnecessary.
A terrifically convoluted yarn with dozens of major players.
No, this is a wonderfully nuanced tale of love and loss set in a picturesque Irish coastal town during its annual literary festival.
Director Gary Winick and screenwriters Jose Rivera and Tim Sullivan deal in genre clichés, sure, yet they let us view them with fresh eyes.
The reach of Lawrence filmmaker Kevin Willmott (C.S.A.) exceeds his grasp with The Only Good Indian.
Dear John isn't so much old-fashioned as it is clichéd.
An epic crime saga, but a curiously claustrophobic one.
Even spectacle becomes boring when there's nothing behind it.
Hope they had fun making Valentine's Day. There's little to be had watching it.
A tough, borderline unpleasant movie that keeps us on edge and waiting for something awful to happen. It may be honest, but, like its protagonist, it isn't likable.
Martin Scorsese has been making good movies for so long that according to the law of averages he was overdue for a turkey.
While it's no classic, taken on its own terms it's effective.
Lock up this humorless buddy comedy and throw away the key Read more: 'Cop Out': Lock up this humorless buddy comedy and throw away the key.
Wildly inconsistent, veering from boredom to moments of visual beauty to some of the most ghastly gruesomeness ever seen on screen.
He [director Tim Burton] beat the odds and made this Alice a real wonder.
A smothering pall of corruption and futility.
Smart and atmospheric, with a delicious undercurrent of brutality, this is a political thriller executed with the panache of Hitchcock in his prime.
Here's all you need to know about Our Family Wedding: It thinks that feeding a goat an entire bottle of Viagra is the height of hilarity.
A fast pace, a nagging mystery and bone-crunching action captured with director Paul Greengrass' signature hand-held camera and rapid-fire editing.
A wonder of minimalism, Claire Denis' 35 Shots of Rum...quietly observes the lives of several Africans living in a Paris suburb.
Even-handedness is the film's strength and, paradoxically, its weakness.
It will seem awfully familiar territory.
What we need are some cinematic repo men to rip this movie from the theaters.
There's no subtext and not much character development, but those aren't really missed.
The results, though, are simply crass.
Parents should enjoy it, and kids will absolutely love it.
Yeah, it's kinda kinky. But given that Moore and Seyfried are terribly attractive women, watching their little dance of desire has its pleasures.

Town looks deliberately crude, so much so that it takes a while to realize just how cleverly it has been animated. Ditto for the humor, which at first smacks of childlike chaos and then segues into subversive sophistication.
movie_title: A Town Called Panic (Panique au village) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Much of what goes on here is seriously disturbing. Be thankful, then, for non-actress Jarvis' mesmerizing performance.
The Last Song is predictable, exactly what you expect it to be.
The film has been built around the live performances, which become an aural backdrop for beautifully edited archival footage and photos of pre-war Jewish life.
The upside of this, one supposes, is that when Part 2 comes out next year it will be nonstop excitement. We've already endured the iffy parts.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It's fun to watch the methodical way this novice plans and executes his daring scheme ... fun enough that most of us will put our reservations on hold.

It's not overstating the case to say that Dakota Johnson achieves stardom with this role. She mines moments of humor that help offset the soul-searching and weeping, and she's appealing without being impossibly beautiful.
[Belgium's Dardenne brothers] They've never done anything as powerful as Two Days, One Night, featuring Marion Cotillard in what someday may be recalled as her greatest performance.

Director Ava DuVernay has given us Selma, a docudrama about a pivotal campaign in the fight for civil rights for black Americans. You could say this film writes history not so much with lightning as with compassion.

Unbroken is a good film. But you can't help wondering what it would have been like if it had been made by believers ... or at least by talents not averse to considering the role of faith in human perseverance.
It's Mulligan's Bathsheba who gives the film its center, providing us with an utterly modern woman fighting the constraints of a Victorian world.
Ridley Scott's Exodus: Gods and Kings runs for almost 21/2 hours, and that still isn't enough time for it to figure out why it's here or what it wants to say.
With his sophomore effort, The Homesman, Jones gives us a revisionist Western that defies expectations at every turn. It's a genuine art film in the vein of Aussie productions like The Proposition.
It's easy to appreciate what Baumbach is aiming for in While We're Young, but it feels more like an intellectual exercise than an involving, emotional encounter.
There's nothing of substance here, but there needn't be. It's just pure escapist fun, wittily delivered.
I hardly laughed at all.
Every filmmaker is allowed a few career missteps. Lynn Shelton seems to have spent all hers on just one movie.

With his feature debut, writer/director Theodore Melfi can be accused of dishing Hollywood cliches, but his cast's sheer good humor and professionalism lift this yarn. And the pile of improbabilities is offset by real heart and solid laughs.
Leviathan is an angry/mournful look at how the system - any system - works to grind down the little guy.
[Julianne Moore] delivers a brilliant performance that buoys Still Alice just when it seems too much to bear. Oscar is waiting in the wings.
For the most part Rosewater is well-acted, tension-filled and slyly iconoclastic. Say hello to Jon Stewart, movie director.
The Judge has a few good things going for it... What the film doesn't have is faith that the audience can appreciate solid dramatic acting for more than, oh, three minutes at a stretch.

This mashup of rap concert, poetry reading (the bulk of the dialogue is in rhyming verse) and burlesque sometimes slips into preachiness or heavy-handed satire, but even the shortcomings become part of the film's overall strength.
The film has special effects so incredible that it will become the standard by which future efforts are measured, and it leaves the audience cheering and happy.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VI - Return of the Jedi (1983)

movie_review_blurb: To answer the big question first: Yes, The Empire Strikes Back is just as enjoyable as Star Wars. In fact, this is one sequel that defies tradition by being better than the original on several counts -- most of them technical, but a few dramatic.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode V - The Empire Strikes Back (1980)

movie_review_blurb: Genuine humanity in a Michael Bay movie? Oh, it's not enough to bog down the action, and it never descends to touchy/feely navel-gazing, but it represents an emotional honesty he has never delivered before.
movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It shouldn't work. It shouldn't move us so. But it does.
Focus was made by the writing/directing team of Glenn Ficarra and John Requa... The twisted charm [their] earlier titles generated is utterly missing this time around.
Go for the laughs. But don't expect the spell of "Hail, Caesar!" to stick with you beyond the closing credits.
At least the film ends with a big Bollywood song-and-dance number. But it's too little too late for all but the most die-hard fans of the original.
movie_title: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Holding it all together is Diesel, who comes off as a steroid-stoked Buddha; even in the midst of chaos he calmly delivers proverbs in a rumbling basso: "Everyone's looking for the feel, but what's real is family." Whatever.

Terrific acting and fight film cliches battle to a split decision in Antoine Fuqua's Southpaw, further proof both of Jake Gyllenhaal's awesome range and of the odds against making a truly original boxing picture.

Oscar-winning director Daniel Junge chronicles the man's life and lasting influence through a plethora of hair-raising news footage and the memories of those who knew him, hated him, and still revere him.

Only the most politically ill-informed viewer will be surprised by the content of Our Brand Is Crisis. Then again, being politically ill-informed seems to be the status quo. For all its faults, the film has a message worth hammering home.

Even if it didn't feature the best 3-D of any film since Avatar, Robert Zemeckis' The Walk would be a winner for its heady blend of gritty reality and lighthearted whimsy, not to mention yet another terrific performance from Joseph Gordon-Levitt.
With The Martian, director Ridley Scott and star Matt Damon deliver an almost perfect piece of popular filmmaking, an intimate sci-fi epic that is smart, spectacular and stirring.
Ex Machina piques our curiosity, lights up our imaginations and sets our nerves a-tingling in ways that few other "robot" movies can match.
The film treats its women with respect and insight, and the relationship of Binoche's and Stewart's characters has a depth and nuance almost never seen in mainstream cinema.

If you can get past its narrative muddle, really irritating dialogue and a plethora of unanswered questions, Tomorrowland offers a potent metaphor about the triumph of human hope and ingenuity. Wish it were enough.
Bill Pohlad's Love & Mercy spectacularly chronicles one man's rise-fall-rise in riveting human (and musical) terms.
The film and the performers grow on us... and the production values are solid (why haven't more filmmakers employed the deep music catalog of Brian Eno?). It all ends with a good, guilt-free cry.
movie_title: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The overall effect is mildly diverting and almost instantly forgettable.
"The 33" does a pretty decent job of laying out a complicated yarn and seasoning it with dramatic moments as it twists and turns toward an uplifting conclusion.
It's only at the end, when the ancient detective finally recognizes the simple comfort of holding another person's hand, that Mr. Holmes finds its emotional footing. Better late than never.
It's a small film, but one that resonates strongly with the aging demographic that frequents the art house scene. You could even call it a perfect fit.
movie_title: I'll See You in My Dreams (2015)

movie_review_blurb: In Mission: Impossible - Rogue Nation, the obvious comfort level between star and director pays off nicely.
At its most basic level [Irrational Man] is, like 2005's Match Point, a murder drama. This time around, though, the satisfactions are relatively few.
The film looks good (albeit deliberately dark, as if shot through a gray filter) and Flynn's grim world view comes through loud and clear. Overall, though, a bit of a letdown.
Should we consider the Shaun the Sheep Movie an art film? Look at it this way. It's foreign (British). It's subversively funny. And it tells its story without one word of dialogue.

The main problem with The Man From U.N.C.L.E. is its tone. We can't take this stuff seriously, yet Ritchie misses all sorts of opportunities to make the movie fun. The result isn't particularly satisfying as either adventure or comedy.
The movie's first hour is a bit slow precisely because the filmmakers refuse to inject conventional dramatic elements... But it all pays off in the devastating finale.
In the just-opened Grandma Lily Tomlin gives a performance that is more than Oscar-worthy - it is, in fact, a kind of summation of her career to date.
The Gunman is generic moviemaking that can't be lifted even by some usually solid performing players like Ray Winstone, Mark Rylance and Idris Elba.
Not even uber-likable Chris Pratt can dispel the pall of been-there-done-that.
As a directorial debut the film is little short of astounding. It gives us one more reason to never forget.

There's no shortage of film-themed documentaries that have dealt in some way with Sir Alfred and his career, but "Hitchcock/Truffaut" introduces a new element by allowing Hitch to comment on his movies.
Mills' setup could be played for sitcom shallowness, but here his two leads inhabit their characters with small gestures and moments that add up to an unexpectedly compelling film.

There is perhaps less here than meets the eye - this is second-drawer Almodovar - but in Suarez's performance as the mature Julieta, the director has an ideal vessel for expressing parental pain and loss.
The overall quality of these short efforts is spectacular, particularly with the live-action and documentary slates.
Usually this category is good for at least one gut-bustingly funny entry. This year's nominees, though, are overwhelmingly somber.
That said, the overall quality of these short efforts is spectacular, particularly with the live-action and documentary slates.
Like the nominees in the feature-length best documentary category, the five films in this group demonstrate a commitment to both relevance and experimentation.
A one-of-a-kind film that lingers long in the memory, "The Red Turtle" suggests that when it comes to animation, there are still whole new worlds to explore.
Bottom line: This Beauty is big, well-designed, tuneful and -- finally -- romantic. But here's the odd thing: It made me want to revisit the original.
Light, glib and easy to forget.
"Free Fire" is a no-subtext zone. What you see is what you get. But concentrate on the action and the smart-ass insults and you'll be OK.
Hunnam looks good but can't do much with the material, for there is not one genuine moment of emotion in the whole laborious mess. Even the action scenes are more confusing than stimulating.
movie_title: King Arthur: Legend Of The Sword (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Early reports on "Dead Men" suggested it was a step up from the last couple of "Pirates" pictures. That's like saying Grandma showed impressive speed in outrunning Great-Grandma.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The results are both familiar and fresh.
Ultimately "The Beguiled" is clinical when it should be compelling.
It's hard to overstate just how effectively "The Big Sick" balances its romantic inclinations against life-or-death drama, or how its comedy co-exists with potential heartbreak.
Stick with it and you will be treated to what very well may be the year's most unique cinematic vision.
Whether soaking away her pain in an ice cube-filled bath or savagely kicking Commie butt, this "Atomic Blonde" grabs our attention and won't let go.
"Detroit" is a crushingly visceral experience, one filled with indignation not only for what went on in 1967 but for today's troubling displays of shoot-first law enforcement.
There are a few moments when "The Glass Castle" threatens to come to emotional life. But they pass.
Sheridan's screenplay provides plenty of thumbnail portraits of colorful characters.
As a recap of a monumental, astoundingly rich life, Wait for Your Laugh is a marvel.
In the end, "Silence" offers scant comfort and little uplift. And did it really require 2 hours and 41 minutes to state its dour case?
"Race" will undoubtedly raise awareness of Owens' accomplishments and the travails he endured. That's a good thing. But one could wish for more substance in his personal story.
The film is afraid to address the troubling issues it raises. This is understandable -- agonizing moral issues are a downer. But why bring them up if you're just going to blow them off?
Yeah, it's heavy. It's also unexpectedly funny, deeply moving and almost unbearably wise when it comes to the labyrinthine workings of the human heart.
Doris may be a convenient cinematic conceit, but Field gives her real juice, moving from a timid wraith to someone who realizes to her amazement that she might be lovable.
A taut, well-acted thriller that raises all sorts of moral questions - Hitchcock with a conscience.
"I Saw the Light" gets the music right, though there's not near as much of it as there could have been. But as drama this one is dead in the water.
It's not a smooth or easy ride. But it's worth sticking with.
The best way to approach "Looking Glass" is as a two-hour 3-D special effects demonstration reel. With lowered expectations it might not be so bad.
Rarely rises above the level of a well-staged history lesson.
Spielberg brings back the awe with "The BFG," a fantasy designed to tickle the kid in each of us.
It's the rare film that discovers dignity in foolishness.
"Hell or High Water" is about two brothers on a crime spree. But David Mackenzie's film has a lot more on its mind than mere suspense and thrills.
"Southside With You" is a terrific film - funny, romantic, respectful without being stuffy and, yes, inspiring.

What was deeply moving on the printed page seems mechanically melodramatic when dramatized in Derek Cianfrance's film. You want to be moved but can't shake the feeling that mostly you're being manipulated.

Hanks is this generation's Jimmy Stewart and Henry Fonda all wrapped up in one perfect package. Nobody else working in movies can take common decency and make it so compelling, can project integrity without a hint of sanctimony ...
When the camera zooms in to study the paintings in detail, the film comes alive.
movie_title: Hieronymus Bosch, Touched by the Devil (Jheronimus Bosch, Touched By The Devil) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Most of "Snowden" is talk - pretty smart talk, actually.
Tim Burton's latest is pretty much par for the course: two hours of great art direction in search of a movie.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It makes each viewer a member of the slave community. By the time it's over we wonder not that Nat Turner turned to murderous violence but that it took him so long.
In the end ... we're left thinking about how much better it could have been.

That "Arrival" works so well is in large part due to Adams, whose fear/eagerness in confronting beings from another world registers squarely with viewers. She can project deep emotions with a minimum of expression. It's all in the eyes.
An emotional powerhouse that will leave audiences drained and exultant, "Loving" is the best film I've seen so far in 2016.
If "Rules Don't Apply" is a comedy, why aren't we laughing? If it's a romance, why don't we feel something? If it's a tragedy, why don't we care?
It has great cinematography. Deep connections between humans and animals. And a ton of female empowerment.

Despite his tender years, Chazelle is a master of composition, color and camera movement, and there are shots here so drop-dead gorgeous you wonder how he and cinematographer Linus Sandgren pulled them off.
A lovely film.
American Sniper does the near impossible, celebrating the warrior spirit while refusing to look away from the chaos it generates. It will leave you with your pulse racing, and your heart aching.
A mind-boggling exercise in pure action Mad Max: Fury Road is overwhelming, achieving the sort of visual poetry typically ascribed to Ben-Hur's chariot race or one of Sam Peckinpah's blood ballets.
This excruciating exercise in indecision sometimes feels like a glum comedy, sometimes like a silly drama. But it never, ever achieves anything like a coherent, consistent tone.
It's a godsend in the January movie wasteland.

The Way Back works well enough as a sprawling adventure of unimaginable hardship. The rugged vistas (it was filmed in Bulgaria, India and Morocco) are impressive. But it feels just a bit underpopulated.
That blend of the bizarre and the banal gives The Rite a badly needed edge, but it's not enough to make it a keeper.
How much longer can Statham keep afloat unremarkable action pictures? Will he ever burst out of his comfort zone and surprise us?
Love Javier Bardem. Not so thrilled with Biutiful.
It's a heartbreaker, but one made bearable by Ryan Gosling and Oscar nominee Michelle Williams, who deliver performances that feel so real they transcend acting and become something else altogether.
In the hands of British Oscar nominee Mike Leigh and a spectacularly good cast it makes for riveting, ruthless movie watching.
Very rarely does a film so nail the zeitgeist as to qualify as a cultural touchstone. The Company Men comes very close.
It's painful to watch.
The Eagle isn't smart enough to be engrossing or campy enough to be a guilty pleasure.
