It's no classic, but until a better thriller comes along, Unknown will do.
Somewhere begins with a fancy sports car driving in circles out in the desert. It's a great-looking machine, but it isn't taking us anywhere. It's a metaphor for the entire movie.
Reilly is an absolute hoot as a glad-handing carouser with an inexhaustible supply of cheesy catchphrases, while Heche finds unexpected depth as a wife and mother on the prowl.
Barney's Version is narratively awkward, but in the performances of Giamatti and Pike it finds a truth that cannot be dismissed.
Ultimately the film takes a long time to go nowhere.

This effort from writer/director David G. Evans gets points for soft-peddling dogma in favor of human stories. And the film benefits from a compelling performance by Michael Joiner, a Kansas City-based stand-up comic who provides a watchable center.
The result is a film that works on multiple levels, casting light on a worldwide problem while delivering a big jolt of human hope.

None of this is remotely surprising, yet I frequently found myself laughing (particularly at Fogler's wild-man behavior) and sympathizing with Matt's predicament (face it, Grace is impossible to dislike).
The film features some of the most astounding computer animation ever, and, thanks to a slew of terrific voice actors who are obviously having a great time, the film is wildly, weirdly amusing.
Not for everyone. But for those who can revel in the moment, this seemingly nondescript effort offers some unexpected depths.
Told largely in flashback, Norman Snider's screenplay zips between Abramoff's high-rolling past and his current situation, which will lead to a prison term for fraud and corruption.
A metaphysical love story with some wonderfully droll ideas.
This is an overlong, empty bore that squanders its possibilities.
All Good Things is curiously underwhelming.
Moral: If you're going to defy the White House, be prepared to have your life taken apart brick by brick.
Good info. But Jews and Baseball is too genteel, too reverential and not nearly exciting enough.
movie_title: Jews And Baseball: An American Love Story (2010)

movie_review_blurb: This tongue-in-cheek retelling of Rapunzel gradually picks up steam until we're firmly in the grasp of its hip hilarity and sincere romance.
Jake Gyllenhaal and Anne Hathaway put on such a display of star power and acting that they almost make us ignore the film's shortcomings.
No finesse. Just plot and dialogue that land with audible thuds.
Diverting but not terribly compelling.
A borderline terrible movie that plays like a parody of a Hemingway story.
The film feels impersonal and obligatory. Not even a last-reel appearance by the lion Aslan (possibly the greatest computer-generated animal character of all time) can make this one a keeper.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The Tourist is memorable for one thing, at least. It's the first movie to make Venice look boring.
The film works because its stars make up a trifecta of terrific performers who overcome the clichés inherent in their characters.
A Film Unfinished is a sort of ghost story. It's guaranteed to haunt you.
An eye-catching 3-D roller coaster ride propelled by a plot and characters of not even passing interest.
Don't like boxing movies? No problem. The Fighter isn't like any other boxing movie you've seen.
A mind-twisting meld of the grand and the goofy, Black Swan is a long way from great... despite a great-ish performance by Natalie Portman.
Here's a cheery lump of coal for your stocking.
A technical triumph, a little jewel produced on a backyard budget.
It's great.
An amusing and weirdly affectionate ride. Anyone want to sign up for the Free Steven Russell movement?
Against the odds, The King's Speech is a triumph, a laugh-until-you-cry, cry-until-you-laugh emotional roller coaster.
After a while you find yourself giggling uncontrollably as Paltrow lurches through her scenes.
William Ivory's screenplay cannily balances Rita's personal transformation against the women's underdog quest for equality. The results may not be original, exactly, but they're no less enjoyable.
The lesson at the film's heart is that when tossed down the rabbit hole of bereavement, there is no "right" response. It's unmapped territory that each of us must learn to negotiate.
These performers are just good enough to wrest a few memorable moments from the general chaos of an eccentric romantic comedy that isn't particularly romantic or funny.
This isn't your typical fairy tale version of Little Red Riding Hood.Actually, it's hard to tell just what this film by Catherine Hardwicke is meant to be.
When you're not slack-jawed in amazement at the fancy footwork, you'll probably be giggling (or groaning) at Flatley's overcooked sense of the dramatic.
A pleasant diversion that may not make you smarter but at least won't make you dumber.
It offers good production values, name performers and insights into the chaos of civil war. But it's too stiff, too cautious, too calculating to feel genuine.
The art on display in Cave of Forgotten Dreams is so jaw-droppingly beautiful that it can move a viewer to tears.
Looking for proof that humans are hard-wired for compassion and altruism? Look no further.
It's Hangover raunchy, yet this ribald comedy is also surprisingly perceptive when it comes to confronting middle age, maintaining friendships and finding one's way in the world.
Funnymen seem to have a secret desire to play drama.At least Will Ferrell has the chops for it.

Hawkes' performance reflects the gentle unaffectedness of Ordal's writing and directing. Earthwork hasn't any big bombastic moments. Instead it worms its way into your good graces slowly and thoughtfully until you're hooked.
Ty Jones' Last Breath won't be everyone's cup of sadism, but beneath its torture-porn exterior this Lee's Summit-lensed thriller has heart and, even more remarkable, soul.
Is it more manly to fight back or to turn the other cheek? This film will have you debating such issues long after the lights come up.
Vision, a somber but beautifully rendered story of the life of 12th-century mystic Hildegard von Bingen, isn't a religious movie so much as a movie about people who take religion seriously.
movie_title: Vision: From the Life of Hildegard von Bingen (2010)

movie_review_blurb: "Jurassic Park" is such an impressive technical achievement that it seems churlish to note that it accomplishes this at the expense of more substantive elements.
'Til There Was You is a rarity -- a film in which absolutely nothing works. Nothing. Not one redeeming performance. Not one convincing moment. Not one solid laugh.
There's nothing earth shaking going on here, and on occasion the proceedings deteriorate into pure silliness. But The Discoverers is gorgeous to look at, and the cast is astoundingly deep.
Land Ho! feels like the perfect combination of scripted dialogue and off-the-cuff improvisation.
Action fans will not be disappointed. Fury is a slam-bam, blood-spattered, convulsively kinetic experience.
Birdman is a tour de force, a heady mix of dark comedy and psychic meltdown with energy vibrating from every frame.
Suspense, social commentary, great performances and a seriously twisted outlook -- Gone Girl is one killer movie.
In a year of terrific performances by leading men, Cumberbatch gets my vote for top honors.
Written and directed by Rock, this meta-saturated comedy/drama may be the biggest surprise of this holiday film season.
They aim for the heart, not the head. Darned if they don't pull it off.
Parsons delivers this tongue-twisting patter with a happy eagerness that is both amusing and ingratiating.
Who knew that beneath her coolly gorgeous exterior, Catherine Deneuve is actually funny?
Some will find White Material's puzzlements evocative. Others -- including yours truly -- will leave irritated and unfulfilled.
This sequel is that rarity -- a film in which practically nothing works.
It's an attempt to capture the essence of monasticism: self-sacrifice, introspection, obedience and achingly lovely moments of quiet brotherhood.
Despite the presence of De Niro and Cornish, Limitless is pretty much a one-man show. Happily, Cooper is up to it. Limitless may not be a slam dunk, but this guy's got it.

Charismatic and oozing oily self-confidence, the character Mick Haller dovetails perfectly with McConaughey's skill set and dazzling grin. After a string of desultory romantic comedies, this actor once again has a winner.
It's an audience-friendly drama about family, conflict and the healing power of music.
A modest but terrifically acted independent feature. In just his second feature film, director Marc Meyers hits the right buttons.
Ready, Set, Bag! delivers plenty of warm and fuzzy while giving us a mainline fix of the sort of small-town cheerfulness you might have thought died with the Andy Hardy franchise.

Perhaps the neatest thing about Phil Grabsky's In Search of Mozart is that after watching it for more than two hours your first impulse is to rush to the Internet and download a slew of Mozart recordings.
Remarkably coherent and weirdly compelling.
An engaging, sobering documentary that celebrates his life and music while suggesting that in the Dylan-Ochs rivalry, Ochs never had a chance.
movie_title: Phil Ochs: There But For Fortune (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Lots of us are interested in clothes. But few can match Bill Cunningham's passion for fashion.
There's some heartbreaking stuff here but also moments of triumph. Not to mention visuals that will leave audiences breathless.
Only Mirren really delivers. Her depiction of Hobson's love for/exasperation with the errant Arthur provides the only genuine moments in this misfire.
It's a solid effort that delicately balances hilarity, suspense and affection for its characters' foibles.
This may be the most psychologically dangerous film version yet of Charlotte Bronte's novel.
The "awwwww" factor is off the charts for Born to Be Wild.
It feels strangely undernourished, as if the filmmakers were afraid to really let go and express big emotions.
[Stevenson is] crazily charismatic here, a blend of brash cockiness and sensitivity, and he makes a satisfying film even better.
The Scream movies have always been clever. The problem is that they never move beyond cleverness.

The film seems obsessed with making political points at the expense of storytelling. Not even McAvoy and Wright, who have repeatedly shown their ability to anchor films, can bring it convincingly to life.
A documentary that examines the exotic animal phenomenon and discovers -- without getting sanctimonious -- much madness.
movie_title: The Elephant In The Living Room (2011)

movie_review_blurb: This one practically screams "foreign film" ... and that's a good thing.
The strong suit of this melodrama from music video director-turned-feature filmmaker Francis Lawrence is its sense of time and place, namely America in 1931.
It's when the action slows down that you can feel the brain cells dying.
As you watch, your indignation grows. Moore has chosen precisely the right moment to tap into the throbbing vein of anti-corporate, anti-rich anger.
Waking Sleeping Beauty will matter only to those who grew up on Walt Disney's animated films. In other words, all of us.
All this is very, very funny.
Leave it to the French to deliver the best film version ever of D.H. Lawrence's Lady Chatterley's Lover.
Heavy-handed sentimentality.
If your idea of a good time at the movies is watching paper-thin characters lob ideological grenades at one another, this is your dream date.

For all the slash and burn of the action sequences and the 3-D technology with which it is being shown in many theaters, this Beowulf from director Robert Zemeckis feels more like a chore than a pleasure.
My Kid Could Paint That may not deal with life-or-death matters like murder or child molestation, but it raises questions that will nag viewers for days and weeks after the experience.
There's plenty to enjoy here.

With No Country for Old Men the Coens may have made their ultimate statement. You may not agree with their pessimism, but they so effectively tell their story that you cannot help but be swept up in their vision.

By the last reel The Golden Compass has created a magical environment we believe in completely. It's a Herculean task that Weitz and his collaborators handle with seeming effortlessness, leaving us ready for more.
Go for the thrills, for some nerve-gnawing suspense, for the wonderful production design and for the opportunity to spend some time with Will Smith. But this one is not the stuff of legend.
Margot at the Wedding is a good film that's painful to sit through, and Margot is a protagonist who's virtually sympathy-free.
A great film, a landmark in musical cinema and the best movie of 2007.
movie_title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Though pitched as comedy with absurdist flourishes, you can't help thinking that Charlie Wilson's War accurately captures the less-than-kosher methods by which laws are passed and money dispersed in our nation's capital.

What propels the film into the stratosphere is Juno herself. As played by Ellen Page, Juno is a winning combination of fierce intelligence, irrepressible irony, casual profanity and, though she doesn't want to admit it, emotional vulnerability.
The Savages isn't so much about plot as about moments, and this film -- thanks to Linney and Hoffman -- is filled with keepers.
It's a thinking person's movie in the best sense of the phrase.
Nicholson and Freeman are consummate professionals, and their dance of liking and loathing generates some good laughs and, if youâ(TM)re inclined toward emotional displays, even a few tears.

The Orphanage works in large part because [the filmmakers] create horror through a slow tightening of tension rather than with lurid "gotcha!" moments. And because in Rueda they have a compelling and heartbreaking leading lady.
The results are emotionally charged but not manipulative.
movie_title: The Diving Bell and the Butterfly (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The f/x guys have provided a seamless blending of computer-generated and real footage, and by limiting our perspective to just what Hud sees through his viewfinder, the fantastic is rendered plausible.
[It] may not be awful enough to merit shredding but which evaporates from memory the minute the lights come up.
The tone feels all wrong.
Goran Dukic's film starts off seeming hip and funky and dark, but almost immediately runs out of steam. It feels like a short carelessly padded to feature length.
Ultimately the film belongs to Day-Lewis, whose devotion to character is itself a bit mad, and Paul Thomas Anderson, who takes us places no other filmmaker dares.
There are no absolute answers to these questions, but like a brain-tickling puzzle, Crossing the Line keeps us on our toes and digging for more information.
Has the makings of a seething human drama yet somehow fails to move us in the manner everybody involved clearly intended.

Director Rod Lurie and screenwriters Michael Bortman and Allison Burnett have fashioned a sneaky drama that sets us up for bland clichés and instead veers into big questions of ethics and exploitation.
3:10 to Yuma started out as a pretty straightforward tale. But so much stuff has piled onto this simple structure that you can hear it creaking.
Shoot â(TM)Em Up is like a manual of creative mayhem, a distillation of Sergio Leone Western and John Woo Hong Kong gun-gasm.

As much an anthropology exercise as a cinematic experience, the Australian Ten Canoes goes back nearly a millennium to immerse us in the lives of the Aborigines who survived on the land centuries before the arrival of Europeans.
Eventually we wake up. This is really just another Ms. .45 revenge flick, only with artistic pretensions.

Casting About is less a documentary than a lyrical tribute to women in general. Strong women, confident women, nervous women, goofy women, beautiful women and just normal-looking women. This film adores them all.
Mortensen's work is so good that you'll want to go back and see Eastern Promises a second time just to appreciate the way he plays us.
The performances are solid , the settings authentic and the film's vein of bleak humor refreshing.
This one will sneak up on you.
A comedy so formulaic and uninspired that you'd swear you've seen the movie before.
Sinks into a jingoistic action film cliché.
The film is a history lesson, certainly, but history as seen through the eyes of the men who made it.
movie_title: In the Shadow of the Moon (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A modest proposal: What say we declare a moratorium on special-effects movies about adolescents on a quest to save the world from darkness?
movie_title: The Seeker: The Dark Is Rising (2007)

movie_review_blurb: An intermittently amusing but mostly improbable comedy about romantically challenged women who devote six months to reading and discussing all six of Austen's early-19th-century novels.
Sean Penn's achingly poetic Into the Wild seduces gently, creeping up in incremental steps. Yet in the end it leaves us drained and devastated.
The film has an admirable humanist agenda, but good intentions don't matter much when you can't care for the humans on the screen.
See the movie for the vampires, which are at least visually interesting. The humans are so boring I couldn't wait for them to die.
Dysfunctional families have long been the favorite subject of filmmaker Wes Anderson, but he has rarely approached the topic with as much heart as he does here.
A tightly controlled, carefully modulated piece of drama that will keep you thinking long after youâ(TM)ve left the theater.
[Director] Bier steers clear of Hollywood formula. Her low-key, natural style comes by its drama honestly, with little manipulation and lots of character development.
movie_title: Things We Lost in the Fire (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Mostly the laughs are based in behavior and character. Carell once again displays the range that makes him something more than just another funny guy. Binoche is so appealing that you immediately understand why Dan has been smitten.
Unlike the Godfather saga, what you see here is all you get.
Describing the plot and characters doesn't begin to convey the out-of-control energy the film radiates. You have to be there.
A competent but unremarkable crime thriller.
It's riveting.
It's not often you encounter a feature film that contains not even one believable minute.
Forgetting Sarah Marshall has a workable if unoriginal setup, but as a story it's like one of those hotel guests lounging in an inner tube and drifting in lazy circles. It doesn't really go anywhere.
If it were executed with more energy or panache, it could have been something special, and that makes the disappointment that much harder to take.
As for Argento ... yeah, she's got something. Now we'd like to see her in a movie that makes sense.
Most of the time Baby Mama relies on the string-pulling of sitcom television.
Cho and Penn are winning leads and play well off of each other. When the film works, it's often due to their interaction.
movie_title: Harold & Kumar Escape from Guantanamo Bay (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A generic thriller with a generic title, Deception is so predictable you could guess what happens even if the trailer hadn't already given away just about every important plot development.
A largely satisfying summer entertainment blending brains and geekiness in equal measure.
The real subject here isn't post-9/11 xenophobia but rather friendship, how it changes us, heals us and how the arbitrary intrusion of outside forces both threatens and strengthens us.
Redbelt is screaming for the guidance of someone with enough distance from the subject to mold it into satisfying drama.
Its subjects are so compelling that Young @ Heart becomes a blisteringly funny and deeply moving meditation on music and mortality.

Hunt, who also co-wrote the screenplay from Elinor Lipman's novel, scrupulously avoids anything that smacks of TV sitcom humor. This is admirable, but the result is one of the glummest romantic comedies in recent memory.
Priceless ends on a sweet, sentimental note. Yes, it's unrealistic. But, hey, that's why we go to the movies.
None of this is earthshaking, but Prince Caspian is a largely satisfying experience -- not too serious and not too silly with just the right 'wow' factor.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Great to have Indy back. Wish he had more interesting stuff to do.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It's the perfect vacation-time movie: not a serious moment in its whole two hours but so crammed with laughter, thrills and cinematic sleight of hand that audiences will be sorry when it's over.
It lacks the sense of detail that made Raiders such a treat. It isn't very clever, very funny or very compelling.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom (1984)

movie_review_blurb: This is reportedly the last time producer/writer George Lucas and director Steven Spielberg will treat movie fans to an Indiana Jones adventure, and it's pretty obvious they were determined to send Indy riding off into the sunset in style.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade (1989)

movie_review_blurb: What could have been an insightful look at how film and television mold our personalities is instead just another film about childhood friendship -- sweet, huggable and toothless.
If you loved Sex as a TV show, you'll want to check out the film because it's like attending a class reunion. It's a chance to catch up with people who meant a lot to us.
Kung Fu Panda is one gorgeous movie. If only the story and comedy were half as absorbing.
The critic in me found plenty of nits to pick with Under the Same Moon. The sentimentalist, though, was ready to blubber.
Feels more like a polemic than drama. But at least it hammers home the message that under the right circumstances even the 'good guys' can behave like monsters.
The screenplay's stabs at witty dialogue end up sounding forced (again, only Church delivers his lines with anything like conviction), and the film's emotions are all synthetic.
Lest we forget that they truly are the world's greatest rock 'n' roll roll band, the Rolling Stones make their case loudly, lovingly and conclusively in Shine a Light.
As a swashbuckler for youngsters it's colorful, diverting and, every now and then, genuinely magical.
The biggest problem with Definitely, Maybe is that leading man Reynolds feels strangely out of water in a role that never lets him unleash his comedy chops.
In Bruges is memorable for its two leading men, whose Mutt and Jeff killers are nearly as fascinating and likable as those played by Samuel L. Jackson and John Travolta in Pulp Fiction.
Leaves us with images that aren't easily forgotten and a grudging respect for people who blaze new trails in search of a thrill.
Semi-Pro is all fancy dribbling and passing, with nobody actually scoring.
Aspires to be a whimsical modern fairy tale about a princess, a family curse and self-acceptance but just can't conjure up any magic.
Don't be surprised if after seeing this movie you find yourself eyeing travel brochures for Barcelona.
A strong camp sensibility is just about the only thing that might have saved this lumbering beast.

Equal parts sadness and inspiration, fury and compassion, the film is sure to divide audiences along ideological lines. But there's no denying the reality of Tomas Young's experiences. A man who has paid so much is more than entitled to his opinions.
This is powerful stuff that reasserts both the evil and the good in human hearts.
Haneke is a master at creating dread and doom. And then he builds upon it.
An astonishingly comprehensive look at the use of torture (or whatever euphemism you prefer) in the war on terror.
It's an astonishing piece, and Cristian Mungiu establishes himself as a world-class director.

A deft and dramatic melding of talking-head documentary, historic photos and film footage and readings by a cast of actors, the film is a devastating depiction of man's inhumanity to man. It is also about how some of us are brave enough to say 'No.'
Arab-Israeli relations get the warm fuzzy treatment in The Band's Visit, a wonderfully appealing Israeli film that should have been up for a foreign-language Oscar.
Movies have rarely depicted brothers in arms with as much accuracy and compassion as Stop-Loss.
It's glitzy. It's suspenseful. It's a wallow in get-rich-quick ambition. Of course, it's also largely uninhabited. But at least the empty vessels are attractive.
Labaki is so enchanting you'll find yourself looking forward to her next appearance.
All this will be way too arty for most viewers. But those willing to take a chance will find unexpected if hard-to-describe pleasures.
Married Life is genteel, well-mannered -- and boring.
A good idea and a great cast are wasted in Nim's Island, a kiddie flick pitched to second-grade sensibilities that still manages to underestimate its audience.
Just a lot of huffing and puffing ... and nothing blows you away.
Basically it's a half-hour Twilight Zone episode blown up to feature length.
Someone not so overexposed may find this a satisfyingly provocative creepfest.
Berinstein's film captures all the hopes, thrills and heartache of an endeavor in which every night is a high-wire act.
Feels like a Masterpiece Theatre production -- solid enough, but at the same time oddly generic.
Notes on a Scandal isn't deep. It's chilly and mean and takes a largely dim view of humanity. None of which prevents it from being good, nasty fun.

Curse of the Golden Flower has no emotional center. There's nobody to root for here (even the wildly charismatic Chow Yun-Fat seems remote and surly), and the characters' scheming seems more like an elaborate pageant than a viable drama.
Though the film is mostly fiction, Idi Amin was the real deal, and Whitaker revels in the role.
Working with no directorial flourishes or fancy camera pyrotechnics, Eastwood's approach is natural and unforced. It's exactly what the material requires.
In its supremely confident and effortless blend of the fantastic and the grittily realistic, Pan's Labyrinth not only compares favorably with Terry Gilliam's best work (Brazil), it also exceeds it.
We end up caring nothing about anyone. They're all instantly disposable. Not to mention one-dimensional.

I could deal better with mean-spiritedness if the film were better written and directed. But the picture's humor is hit and miss, with long unfunny passages and characters who really don't change much.
A well-meaning but pedestrian low-budget melodrama.
Phillippe and Cooper remind us that real espionage isn't about chases and gunplay but about the duplicity of the human personality.

The closer the character gets to actually firing up his rocket, the less fun the film becomes. The Polish brothers lose their goofy sense of humor, and The Astronaut Farmer turns serious and, heaven help us, inspiring.
Visually stylish and dramatically moribund, The Number 23 is a half-baked idea posing as profundity.
It's an existential thriller in the most literal sense.
Jackson and Ricci are terrific, deftly negotiating the film's shifting currents of the lurid and the spiritual. And the music cooks.

Inland Empire is self-indulgent and overlong and guaranteed to try the patience of all but the most devoted Lynch fan. But for all that I don't regret having spent three hours wallowing in its eccentricity.
300 may be the Guy Movie to end all Guy Movies.
Reichardt's low-budget feature, shot in one weekend with a skeleton crew, quietly observes both men and passes judgment on neither. It's a minimalist masterpiece.
Miss Potter isn't deep, but it is curiously endearing. Anyone who has ever been charmed by a Potter book will be equally charmed by this cinematic take on her life.
Conventional storytelling may not be Barney's thing, but he has a superb cinematic eye, an incredible imagination and the wherewithal to make his visions happen.
A kinda supernatural, kinda psychological thriller that establishes a perplexing situation and never gets around to figuring it out.
The film is terrific at providing a kaleidoscopic sense of life unfolding, with imaginative editing and colors that seem to leap off the screen.
Volver shifts effortlessly from suspense to pathos to giddy humor; the cast members negotiate all these changes while delivering low-keyed, reality-rooted performances.
A slow, deliberate and often achingly beautiful film about how we often keep at arm's length that which we most love.

Apparently Besson became so enamored of CG animation's possibilities that he forgot basic rules ... such as the one about animation thriving on clear-cut, distinctive characters whose personalities are established in the first few seconds they're on screen.
movie_title: Arthur and the Invisibles (Arthur and the Minimoys) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Relying on previously unseen film footage, still photos and voice recordings, Jonestown paints a portrait of a fantastically charismatic preacher.
Stranger Than Fiction is odd and eccentric, but in the end it finds its heart. After all, if there's hope for a drone like Harold Crick, there's hope for all of us.
One suspects it was a lot more fun to make this movie than it is to watch it.

Because of its thematic flaws, Babel isn't the masterpiece some are claiming. Yet it remains powerful stuff, a glum but concerned look at how a seemingly isolated event can affect lives on the other side of the globe.
After seeing this performance one can only be excited at the prospect of watching Craig's Bond mature and change over the course of several films.
It piles lots of contemporary issues on what should be a simple children's fable and becomes an overlong, emotionally muted and tiresome epic.
Richard Linklater's latest is a humorless, glum multicharacter melodrama that plays like John Sayles Lite.
Shut Up & Sing is further proof that today's best American films are documentaries.
movie_title: Dixie Chicks - Shut Up and Sing (2006)

movie_review_blurb: I can't stop thinking about it, a good indication that this beautiful, frustrating film is tapping into something I can't put my finger on.
I don't doubt that people who've worked in Hollywood will find plenty to chortle about. For the rest of us, though, For Your Consideration is largely insider baseball.
It's cool and detached, and even its shocks feel calculated and contrived.
movie_title: Fur: An Imaginary Portrait of Diane Arbus (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Loud, noisy and not nearly as smart as it thinks it is.
For this viewer it felt a bit too much like a made-for-TV special.
The difference between a great movie and a merely acceptable one often isn't a matter of what you put in, but what you leave out. Apocalypto could have done more with less.
You can see DiCaprio and Connelly acting. They're trying too hard.
...Rachman's film makes the case that under the right circumstances anger and outrage and defiance are an art form unto themselves.
Few on-screen father-son relationships have felt more authentic than that depicted by Will Smith and his real-life son in The Pursuit of Happyness.
Charlotte's Web ends on a grace note that should keep you feeling whimsical for many days after.
Drug addiction is bad. Given the universal consensus on this topic, anyone making a movie about it needs to come up with a fresh approach.
Rocky Balboa is the best Rocky movie since the original and a fitting final (we hope) tribute to one of the great American movie characters.
If you're looking for action, The Good Shepherd will be a letdown. But as a deep meditation on the nature of espionage, it's a minor classic.
If the Christmas movie season sometimes seems like a holiday smorgasbord stuffed with empty calories, Sweet Land is a much-needed palate cleanser.
Any way you look at it, Dreamgirls works.
Superbad delivers some of the summer's biggest laughs.
Reign Over Me has the good sense not to claim that everything's going to be OK. It simply recognizes that there's still hope.
What makes The Lookout really memorable is Gordon-Levitt's nuanced portrayal of Chris.
For every dork who has stood before the home stereo speakers and banged away on an invisible instrument, here at last is validation.
It's safe to describe Jindabyne as a haunted movie.
A romantic fairy tale of astonishing delicacy and emotional nuance. This movie is so good I wasn't even bothered by [director] Carney never giving his characters names.
From comedy to drama, varied anthology is worth the trip.
Apparently all the money went into the animals. The jokes wouldn't earn a round of applause at open mic night at your local comedy club.
A Mighty Heart has no discernable political agenda. It's simply a straightforward look at a terrible event.
For a deep-in-the-bones sense of dread that great horror generates, 1408 comes up short.
There's still some 'Yippe-ki-yay' left in this franchise.
Even people who hate Michael Moore might warm up to Sicko, an indictment of America's health care industry so damning that it could galvanize citizens from all over the political spectrum.
Evening wants desperately to be The Hours. Better luck next time.
Paprika probably won't win many converts to anime, but the faithful should be satisfied.
Ratatouille is a delight -- with explosions of delicious humor and a gorgeous look that will have you rethinking what animation can accomplish.
[The fans] have a lot invested in Harry Potter, and far from running out of steam it seems the series is willing to take them to new and unsettling places.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A grown-up movie with droll, sophisticated humor and a deliciously subversive sense. We don't see too many of those any more.
Hairspray is more fun than anything we've seen at the multiplex so far this year. And unlike most of this summer's blockbusters, it's got something on its mind.
... a visually sumptuous, dramatically inert fable ...
Don't go to Killer of Sheep expecting a conventional movie experience. This is an art film, a realistic-yet-poetic examination of a time and place and the people stranded there.
The Bourne Ultimatum slips into high gear practically with its first shot, and after that you're hooked.
How are we supposed to view Lavoe? The film never makes up its mind. The man apparently started out as an innocent and quickly went to the devil.
The biggest drawback is that young stars Cox and Danes are insufferably colorless. Automatons could have given these performances.
Despite some pacing problems two-thirds of the way through, first-time feature director Fleischer does a fine job of juggling mayhem and merriment.
For anyone who's ever had an adolescent girl in the house, Gracie will be both eerily familiar and a bit scary.

Clearly, the real Jim Ellis pulled off a miracle. Too bad, then, that this film about him feels phony, full of clichés and bristling with subplots that smack of Hollywood storytelling rather than real-world situations.
There are flashes of near-greatness here, and the moments of dramatic power and aura of moral ambiguity set it apart from just about every other movie out there this season.

Unfortunately, once in front of the camera Depp isn't given anything interesting or funny to do. So this fine actor is left to drag out the same shtick that once seemed refreshing -- three films and an Oscar nomination ago.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: At Worlds End (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The bottom line here is that 3-D turns a just-OK movie into a shouldn't-miss experience.
Warrior is a good-looking film that feels more like an allegory about the power of positive thinking than a drama.
This is a very good movie.
Grindhouse has plenty of fun moments, and with a running time of more than three hours you can't complain that you didn't get your money's worth. But it only half works.
Has no shortage of heart, but it has been so clumsily organized and falls back so often on clichéd storytelling that any early goodwill quickly morphs into resentment.
Hallstrom, never a show-offy director, keeps the action buzzing along to a very satisfying conclusion.
Perfect Stranger is so intent on fooling us with a last-minute 'gotcha' revelation that it ignores just about everything else that matters.
Pacing problems aside, Hot Fuzz is a lot of fun. If only filmmakers would remember that with comedy, less is more.
[Kasdan] has drawn such terrific performances from his players that the film's shortcomings are excusable.
A low-budget effort with a huge emotional and intellectual payoff.
At least Next has a sense of humor, which helps soften (though not enough) the ridiculous premises on which the enterprise rests.
Is Year of the Dog a comedy? A tragedy? A celebration? A cautionary tale? Actually, it's all of the above.
I liked that last Spider-Man so much that I walked into 3 will a full head of residual good will. But after 2 1/2 hours of empty summer movie, my supply was pretty much exhausted.

Leading lady van Houten seems game for anything her director throws at her. She exudes a happy sexuality that kept me watching well past the point of losing interest in the plot. Koch is terrific as her German lover.

About the only person here who seems to be working hard for laughs is Braff. Even Bateman, who was so brilliantly hysterical on TV's Arrested Development, is denied any major comic moments. And that's a crime.
The real reason most people go to zombie movies -- the mayhem -- is so poorly staged and edited that most of the time you can't tell what's going on.
The Wind That Shakes the Barley may want to view the world in black and white, but it's honest enough to admit that most of the time the truth is gray.
movie_title: The Wind That Shakes the Barley (2007)

movie_review_blurb: There are shocking and heartbreaking moments scattered throughout The Italian, but [director] Kravchuk approaches them with a nonjudgmental, observational style that avoids most of the pitfalls of melodrama.
You don't go to a Shrek movie for the plot. You go to have your funny bone stroked by the patented blend of fairy tale tradition and pop culture references. And Shrek the Third delivers.
Sarah Polley gives us one of the year's best films.
Some viewers may feel betrayed when the film's light-hearted and gently mocking attitude suddenly turns deadly serious. I thought it was breathtaking.

As he did with Virgin, Apatow here pulls off the not inconsiderable feat of making the crude seem somehow endearing. There's something in the Apatow style that makes palatable material that in the hands of other directors would be tasteless.

These interlocking stories don't add up to a conventional narrative. It helps to think of Jellyfish as a tone poem. And like the invertebrate that is its namesake, the film is by turns beautiful, stinging and rather shapeless.
Taken as speculative fiction, it is thoroughly satisfying.
All this plays like a pale retread of a Mission: Impossible script. Which would be fine if Get Smart were actually funny.
It's good-looking, surprisingly steamy cinematic silliness.
As rousing as a Klingon war chant and more fun than an engine room full of tribbles.
Fueled by great performances, keen observations of human behavior and a streak of dark comedy, Lymelife is a coming-of-age movie with a kick.
Fados is basically a collection of musical performances by two dozen practitioners of the form, but Saura always finds a way to make it cinematic.
The results are wildly uneven. The good news is that certain individual scenes work well, provided you don't take offense at the manipulative nature of the enterprise.
You'll leave the theater feeling really, really good.
By the time it's all over audiences may feel they've been had by a fiendishly manipulative storyteller. But then, being had is one of the reasons we go to the movies.
Sugar is a baseball movie in the way that Macbeth is a play about kilts. The description is accurate as far as it goes, but it doesn't go nearly far enough.
It's basically a cheap thrill. An expensive cheap thrill.
Busy is not the same as clever.
movie_title: Night at the Museum 2: Battle of the Smithsonian (2009)

movie_review_blurb: This is a very fine film debut.
It's funny and affectionate and so well-crafted by writer/director Joe Heyen and editor/cinematographer Anthony Ladesich that it overcomes some considerable drawbacks.

This film is lovely in attitude and execution. In a world that sometimes seems filled with mean people, mean institutions and mean humor, Up is friendly, affirming and deeply moving. It's funny, too, but never at anyone's expense.
Yeah, Drag Me to Hell is schlock cinema. But it's schlock cinema with a Ph.D.
It's diverting for an hour or so, but one tires of all this forced playfulness long before the final reveal.
There's humor in all this misfortune. But the more you watch, the more you empathize.
Until Mike Tyson writes an autobiography, this documentary will do.
This is the worst adaptation of a classic kids TV show to the big screen since ...well, since last year's joyless movie Speed Racer. But Land raises the bar on joylessness.
It's satiric, yet Cuaron is like a boxer who prefers gentle sparring to throwing a knockout haymaker. The film needs to punch things up.
You don't go to a movie by Tony Scott looking for subtlety and subtext. But give him a good story and Scott delivers.
The film is never as good as its parts -- some of which are very good indeed. But Keaton knows how to control the medium and establishes a palpable mood without getting all artsy. It's a good start.
I suspect even Marvel die-hards will find this a letdown. It's a prime example of the law of diminishing returns.
This is a film about young dancers desperate for a job auditioning for a show about ... young dancers desperate for a job. It's wonderful.
A memorable study in humanity rather than the sentimental bath it might have been.
It's almost a relief when one of the characters comes down with a deadly disease.
Though it generates a few laughs, The Class is anything but uplifting. In the end you find yourself moved not by triumph but by the seeming futility of it all.
Director Andy Fickman does an OK job of keeping all the balls in the air, though when it comes to loud but bloodless action, he's all thumbs.
Absurdistan lives up to its name with its virtual nonstop drollery. And in Malerova the film has a most appealing leading lady.
Its effortless evocation of poverty's emotional brutality could hardly be more topical.
The performances are just about perfect -- powerful (but never show-offy) and carefully modulated.
In the end, this is all Rudd's movie.
The first 10 minutes of this mirthless mess was interminable, and it didn't get any better. I'd feel cheated if I'd rented this one from the red box at Mickey D's.
As a collection of often-interesting information it's fine. As a movie it wears out its welcome.

Slight but satisfying, The Great Buck Howard examines an over-the-hill performer with an objective eye that is borderline brutal. Yet this comedy softens the blow with laughs, heart and a lingering sense of mystery.
See it for the dozens of homages to old movie monsters and movie genres.
The performances are so "real" they don't seem like acting at all.
The movie around them has problems, but Amy Adams and Emily Blunt put on a first-class acting workshop.
A tryptophan yawn.
If his plot falls into a predictable pattern, Mottola is able to work some attractive variations with his strong cast.
Darvich does an adequate job of pointing the camera and letting people speak, but he provides no context
All the characters in Petr Jarchovsky's screenplay are drawn in shades of gray. The result isn't so much a morality play as an amorality play.
I'm not much of a fan of the whole Hannah thing, but it's pretty clear that young Miss Cyrus is the real deal.
Heiskanen is a revelation, capturing and illuminating every flicker of Maria's growing self-awareness.
movie_title: Maria Larssons eviga ögonblick (Everlasting Moments) (Maria Larsson's Everlasting Moment) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The film is a veritable litany of torn-from-the-headlines issues, yet they all dovetail nicely within a thriller format. And this is the rare film that sends you out of the theater feeling a bit smarter than when you entered.
With its little-bit-of-everything approach, Earth sometimes feels more like really glorious wallpaper than a satisfying story. But there's no arguing with those images. They're fantastic.
Amarcord will make you howl with laughter and then choke back a tear. And all the while you'll be building your own memories of this landmark movie.
There's only so much you can do with a cliché.
It's only the best superhero movie ever made.
Black, who has been hilarious elsewhere, is working so hard to be funny that it's exhausting.

While the entire cast is very good, Abbass must carry most of the film, with little dialogue. Her subtly expressive face is a script unto itself, conveying everything from formal, traditional modesty to angry defiance.
The acting is terrific.
Taking a traditional sci-fi approach, Blomkamp examines contemporary society through a new prism.
There are certainly elements of the tragic here, but the film never quite delivers.
Even atheists may find their world rocked by Nati Baratz's Unmistaken Child.
Nothing wrong with potty talk. But if that's all a movie has to offer, the humor quickly evaporates.
movie_title: The Goods: Live Hard, Sell Hard (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The biggest drawback here is that Charlyne Yi has no screen presence.
That isn't the way the history books tell it, but after seeing this overripe wonder you may prefer Tarantino's take.
For any teenager tempted to sneer at Mom and Dad's veneration of the whole Woodstock thing, this film explains why those three days in 1969 had such a profound effect on a generation.
Dancy gets the juiciest role and wisely underplays it.
There's considerable pleasure in watching Bateman take a fairly bland character and imbue him with personality, humor and even a dash of pathos.
Part thriller, part natural history lesson.
Maybe a sitcom laugh track would have helped. At least it would provide a hint of where we're supposed to chuckle.
The film offers a unique take on the future and enough dazzling sights to merit a second and even third viewing.
The screenplay by Jon and Erich Hoeber and Chad and Carey Hayes (too many cooks?) is confusing and leaps huge gaps in logic.
It's the relationship between Coddington and her boss, the icy, remote Wintour -- a genius of another sort -- that makes The September Issue so fascinating.
The ironically titled World's Greatest Dad is one sick movie. That's a compliment.
What's missing is charm. The book had tons of it, while the movie buries it beneath an avalanche of movement and busy design.
movie_title: Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Dare you not to smile.
This film about the doomed love affair of poet John Keats and his neighbor Fanny Brawne left me underwhelmed.
My beef is that this yarn -- story by Matheny, screenplay by Kyle Mangrum -- is nowhere near as original as [his student film] The Scientist.
Part of the problem is the computer-generated Hulk. It's OK in the early going, when the big green guy is mostly hidden by darkness or smoke. But in the light of day he looks cartoonish.
Absolutely, beautifully, tear duct openingly right.
Its plot is ridiculously simple, yet we watch Tulpan in open-mouthed awe because of director Sergey Dvortsevoy's astonishing technique.
This is one lip-smacking, celestially aromatic, drop-dead delicious movie.
The film belongs to its two stars.
Something is seriously amiss when a movie as noisy and frenetic as Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen is so boring it puts you to sleep.
A film that overcomes an obscenely melodramatic setup to come by its tears honorably.
It never adds up to a satisfying whole.
Frequently this doc plays like a real-life Fellini movie, filled with beautiful people and bizarre incidents. And ultimately it's an unexpectedly touching love story.
Away We Go is a road-trip comedy. It's also one of the best films about love I've ever seen.
Is there any role Johnny Depp cannot make his own?
Purportedly a tale of seething emotions, Cheri almost never registers love or anguish. It's banal.
Unlike last year's Vicky Cristina Barcelona, which felt fresh and contemporary, Whatever Works seems dated. Allen has covered these themes so often that they provide few surprises.
Director Robert Kenner's documentary is powerful. Maybe even life-changing.
It's not sentimental. Yet it's devastating.
Moon is darn good science fiction.
The troubles start with the casting. Rust is only 28, but he has the hangdog look of a 50-year-old plumbing salesman. Charisma is not his strong suit.
Simultaneously funny, infuriating, daring, cruel and tasteless.
The greatest pleasures offered by Steve Kloves' screenplay involve these familiar characters enduring the unexceptional pangs of adolescence.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Put on your outrage cap.
Often feels more like propaganda than drama.
The Ugly Truth is about as subtle as a boulder rolling downhill through a crowded playground.
Employing handheld cameras and very little music, Bigelow creates a claustrophobic and palpably dangerous environment in which one mistake could prove disastrous.
This unremarkable fellow finds himself in some strange circumstances, thanks to the imagination of writer/director Bent Hamer.
Best of all, Mann and his cast achieve a grim atmosphere of fatal inevitability as the net slowly tightens around Dillinger and his free-wheeling criminal cohorts.
The film's nexus of mortality and humor from the gut provides plenty of diversion.
Gentle, goofy and never mean, Management isn't earth-shaking. But it's a fuzzy warm blanket of a movie.
Hugely watchable, practically mesmerizing.
Grey is comfortable in front of the camera (and this time she gets to keep most of her clothes on), but her range is limited.
Despite the torn-from-the-headlines subject matter, The International feels generic.
The spell cast by most films evaporates before you can fish out the car keys. Elegy, though, only grows in the memory -- more potent, more immediate, more disturbing.

What Burn does deliver is a handful of superbly dry comic scenes, some memorable depictions of human perfidy and idiocy and a couple of shockingly violent plot twists that'll have you wondering if you really saw what you think you saw.
Righteous Kill was helmed by Jon Avnet (the excruciatingly bad 88 Minutes) with the sort of phony, frantic energy that suggests a director with little faith in his material.
You can be all for religious tolerance, up-by-the-bootstraps enterprise and love of country and still be turned off by Proud American.
Those looking for big laughs will leave disappointed. OSS 117 barely qualifies as comic.
movie_title: OSS 117: Le Caire Nid d'Espions (OSS 117: Cairo, Nest of Spies) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Ghost Town works so well you just want to sit back and say 'Ahhhh.'
Lakeview Terrace may smack of cheap exploitation, but it's pretty great exploitation.
This love/hate tribute to [director Maddin's] hometown is one of the year's weirdest, most memorable 80 minutes of celluloid.
You couldn't call it a happy movie, but it's an absorbing one.
Some of us could happily watch Diane Lane reading the Congressional Record. But there are limits to that devotion. Like Nights in Rodanthe.
The film has no pace, no style and no sense of forward momentum. Rockwell is given lots of narration in an attempt to glue it all together, but it doesn't help.
A wildly improbable but often diverting effort that mixes ring action with a relationship movie.
In this docu-comedy Maher and Borat director Larry Charles team up for a guerrilla raid on religion that employs many of the same bait-and-switch tactics from that Sacha Baron Cohen hit.
It's a testament to Kinnear's charisma that we stick with Kearns through thick and thin.
Blindness is pretty grim stuff, but it's not all that involving.
It lacks the substantial story that would make it memorable.
Willmott gets it right more than he gets it wrong, but there are a few moments when things slide into broad caricature.
It's like two stories unfolding in parallel universes.
It will make you care even if you don't like sports.
Even if Body of Lies lacks a huge emotional wallop, it dishes plenty of food for thought.
Caroline Thompson's screenplay is dour in the extreme ... a bit of humor would have made this dystopian tale go down easier.
Traitor builds to an intensely suspenseful conclusion, but what lingers long after the film ends are the troubling questions it raises. Not too many movies can make that claim.
Amelie meets The Pianist in I Served the King of England, one man's surreal journey through 30 years of Czech history.
movie_title: I Served the King of England (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A transcendent film experience.
movie_title: Auf der Anderen Seite (The Edge of Heaven) (On the Other Side) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: There's plenty of skin and acrobatic positioning in Catherine Breillat's The Last Mistress, but the ferocious passions they signify are far more interesting.
movie_title: Une Vieille Maîtresse (The Last Mistress) (An Old Mistress) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The Love Guru is less a movie than a collection of related gags heaved at the screen. It's a mess, but an affable one.
An experience that will haunt all who see it.
This low-key yarn about lowbrow men isn't for everyone. But whatever its faults and limitations, Shotgun Stories casts a spell unlike any other movie we've seen in ages.

Give Mongol's makers credit for taking advantage of the spectacular scenery and creating an almost documentary reality regarding life among Mongolia's nomads. But as storytelling the film goes nowhere slowly.
With its split personality, WALL-E falls short of greatness. Even so, it pushes the animation envelope with every frame.
With a star-heavy cast, mind-blowing visuals and more blood than a vampire flick, this modern-day fantasy about an ages-old brotherhood of assassins is an over-the-top guilty pleasure.
That pain in your neck is cinematic whiplash.
Enjoy The Golden Army for what it is, a big fat piece of eye candy. But for the next Hellboy movie could we please have a lot more Hellboy?
A diverting if shallow entertainment, not to mention a glimpse of things to come.
movie_title: Journey to the Center of the Earth (2008)

movie_review_blurb: There's no editing within a scene, no close-ups. No incidental music. Just life, or a pretty accurate simulation of life.
movie_title: Le Voyage du Ballon Rouge (The Flight of the Red Balloon) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The Dark Knight is a good -- not great -- superhero movie that crams as many ideas into its 2 1/2 hours as it can and still be considered a summer action picture.
In bringing her stage production to the screen, first-time film director Phyllida Lloyd has retained the show's goofy charm and mostly breathless pacing.
A one-joke comedy that might have made a decent recurring sketch on Saturday Night Live, digested in five-minute doses.
Giving his film real emotional kick are the personal stories of Mad Dog and Stinky, two average guys chasing a media-fed dream that will only result in disappointment.

Quite aside from its dramatic ambitions, The Wackness does a nifty job of capturing the zeitgeist of Manhattan on the eve of Rudy Giuliani's big crackdown on drugs, thugs, sex shops and colorful street life.
A French thriller that teases the intellect, shocks the senses and is sometimes simply too suspenseful for comfort.
movie_title: Ne le Dis à Personne (Tell No One) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: If The Singing Revolution were a fictional film it would be dismissed as a pie-in-the-sky fantasy. But it's all true.
This blood-spattered stoner comedy -- the latest from Team Apatow -- is wildly uneven and at times trying. But even a DEA agent would find plenty to laugh at.
