movie_title: How to Lose Friends & Alienate People (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Based on a Davis biography, Gary Fleder's account is a noble attempt at humanizing the myth, but it succumbs to the worst sorts of sports-movie clichés.

By limiting herself to an actor, a painter, sculptors, and a printmaker, Boll gives herself plenty to work with; when the stories drag, and they occasionally do, the art's there to inspire and uplift.
movie_title: Who Does She Think She Is? (2009)

movie_review_blurb: How ironic that a movie filled with police officers should end up feeling like a hostage situation.

A juvenile fairy tale that plays like the pilot for a Jonas Brothers sitcom on the Disney Channel, The Rocker comes off as something penned by an old dude who hasn't bought music since it was sold 'on records.'
Nothing about Zack and Miri feels terribly fresh, much less transgressive.
movie_title: Zack and Miri Make a Porno (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Funniest movie of '08? Close enough, for those who don't mind monkeying around.
If nothing else, there's no need to worry about where Quantum of Solace fits in the Bond pantheon -- it's easily one of the worst.

To brand, then dismiss, Four Christmases as a disappointment would be giving it too much credit -- never, for a second, did this New Line Cinema cast-off scream or even whisper decent in the run-up to its opening.
There doesn't seem to be a single fact contained within writer-director Darnell Martin's ham-fisted fiction, which renders pre-rock musical history as yet another downer soap opera.
Nothing more than warmed-over holiday seconds, a repackaged best-of for those who already own the hits.
Valkyrie feels like another installment in the never-ending franchise -- not just the action-movie one, but the Tom Cruise one. Like the operation itself, it's a good idea -- just not well-executed.
Miller, comics-writing icon turned director, has rendered comics-industry revolutionary Will Eisner's crime fighter Denny Colt a grim shade of dull -- all talk, no action
[A] shiny sitcom pilot that looks like something yanked from NBC's shelves circa 1989.
Just buy the records; that's the point of this infomercial anyhow.
You're better off watching The Star Wars Holiday Special on YouTube. At least Bea Arthur sings.
Paul Rudd wears the constant look of glazed-eye amusement; everything seems to tickle him, even that which annoys or frustrates or disappoints him.
Director Craig Saavedra and writer Tom Nance's collaboration plays like something out of an indie-film paint-by-numbers.

As Star Wars movies go, The Clone Wars is minor to the point of irrelevance, nothing more than a stylized direct-to-DVD shrug projected onto a big screen while Lucas launches two more TV series filling in prequel blanks better left empty.
Sadly, Bottle Shock is far from a great movie -- a little too sweet to the taste, almost sickly so.
Definitely, Maybe is a surprisingly rewarding romantic comedy.
The greatest mystery is how a movie peddling the bliss of moviemaking is absent any hint of joy.
In the end, it's comedy comfort food, something powdered poured from a box.
A movie that wastes a lot of time and money and really, really shoulda stayed in Vegas.
Despite its formula and flaws (chief among them Foster's sitcom-campy performance), Nim's Island is a perfectly pleasant, agreeably innocuous 'tweener adventure film.
It's all action, no reaction. One minute they're miserable; 90 minutes later, aww better.
Even if his movie, produced by Apatow and directed by first-timer Nicholas Stoller, visits familiar territory, Segel's willing to go to dark, weird places his contemporaries won't.
It's the kind of film that only a mother, which is to say my mother, would love.
A Saturday Night Live sketch stretched a good hour past its breaking point of no return.
Director Paul Weiland and the three (!) screenwriters it took to boil down thousands of bad movies into 101 minutes haven't provided this one with a single original thought.
When it isn't tossing softballs at the studios, Tropic Thunder is the very thing it parodies: a wall of noise engulfed in flame.
Kingdom of the Crystal Skull is as joyless as its predecessors were blissful.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Stuck is both darkly comic and disgusting; the name alone reduces the crime to a sick joke.
The Incredible Hulk is The Pretty Good Hulk. All things considered, of course.
Effective nonsense, chilling nonsense, occasionally wrenching nonsense.
A film that's both breathtakingly majestic and heartbreakingly intimate.

The readings of Dalton Trumbo's letters to family and friends are starkly rendered-famous faces...recite rousing missives without the aid of sets or props of any kind save for Trumbo's own thunderous proclamations in defense of free speech.
It doesn't take itself as seriously as it should, and undercuts a final act that should have and so could have packed a mighty emotional wallop.
Episodes of Land of the Lost were more inspired.
movie_title: Journey to the Center of the Earth (2008)

movie_review_blurb: [It's] like they ran out of the $292.96 budget halfway through.
It's an indie about indies -- meta, right? But also mighty effective if you're into idle, drunken chit-chat about getting laid while waiting out the bogeyman in the bushes.
At last, a Judd Apatow production worth memorizing.
This is irritainment, something you snicker at while covering your eyes, praying that this guy never gets loose in the real world, when, in fact, he's your next-door neighbor. Or you.
The performances are transcendent -- especially Fanning's, as the little girl who wants to get better, who wants to be better, as she slowly disappears through the Looking Glass.
Yet another willful, comically tortured "indie" coated with Hollywood's happy-ending sheen.
Just as we thought the "bromantic comedy" had overstayed its welcome, the genre reaches its highest point with I Love You, Man.

Elf may be no more than a pleasant, amusing trifle, a grin that fades well before Thanksgiving, but it also will endure in the way that all decent Hollywood-made Christmas fairy tales last, if they're rendered with good cheer and goodwill.
Even without much character development, the compelling story holds, mostly due to Wilson.
Wright immerses his heroes in pop culture's detritus and diversions, but doesn't drown them in it. You don't have to be dazzled or tickled by the movie, or get every joke, to be touched by it, too.
Classiest. Comic. Book. Movie. Ever.
I found my son's Kryptonite: boring superhero rip-offs voiced by check-cashing actors. At least Steve Carell used an accent.

That's not to dismiss Paul's simple pleasures -- if nothing else, its fondness for sex and drugs and four-letter words rescues its references from the soft hands of wee ones into which they've fallen of late.
It really happened, it's really corny, and it's really great.
Crowe is back to what he's good at: small stories populated by everyday people.

When Garfield conceals Peter's confused-angry- betrayed scowl beneath that shiny red mask, Spider-Man 2 summons the giddy derring-do of the best Iron Man offerings. It's a good movie that could have been great.

The Life and Times of Hank Greenberg is precisely what a documentary ought to be: engaging and revelatory, turning forgotten footnotes and discarded minutiae into the stuff of riveting drama and poignant laughs.
movie_title: The Life and Times of Hank Greenberg (2000)

movie_review_blurb: The result is pleasant and diverting, if ultimately forgettable, and it's one of the rare instances in the recent history of 3-D's resurrection as The Savior of Cinema in which the technology doesn't dim the screen or distract the focus.
The down-for-anything cast, along with a handful of welcome cameos, can't prop up its weakest link: Seth MacFarlane.
movie_title: A Million Ways to Die in the West (2014)

movie_review_blurb: From Justin to Kelly is a musical so pedestrian it trips over its feet every time someone breaks into song or dance.
[Friedkin] knew he wasn't making art; he was concocting gross-out pop -- a movie so "scary" it borders on being silly.
What makes Crash so gripping -- so terrifying in spots, so moving in others, and even a little funny at times -- is how nothing happens as we think it will.
Marvel hasn't made a movie this fun - this bright, this charming, this joyful -- since the first Iron Man, in which Robert Downey Jr.'s entitled smirk was its most lethal weapon.
This is comfort-food cinema. Gorge on the endless buffet.

It's a narrative ready-made for the big screen -- the flipside to the feel-good story that was Friday Night Lights, in which the Carter Cowboys played a major role as the big-city villains who wrested away Odessa Permian's rightful title.

The Big Short sticks in the throat. You laugh at it only because you can't believe it was this awful -- that people were (and are) this awful. It's the horror movie soundtracked with nervous, incredulous giggles wrung from the rot of the soul.
In the words of The Joker in a far better Batman movie: "Why so serious?"
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A little too rambling at two and a half hours, but otherwise just the right shade of light and bright for a movie about superheroes fighting superheroes.
It's like a great singer's rendition of a hoary standard.
The tag line alone - "Live. Die. Repeat." - guarantees $30 million at least on opening day. It will deserve every penny.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: This is one muddled attempt at franchise-making: confusing, drab, sluggish. (Ugly, too, if you're forced to see it in 3-D.)
It's crude, loud, dumb fun. And, on top of that, it contains the greatest cameo ever by a winner of the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economics.
The animals here don't talk; that's the movie's one saving grace.
The grandeur of the effects -- the honest-to-God spectacle of the thing -- elevates Monsters vs. Aliens to something approaching art. It's not a masterpiece, but it's most certainly a milestone.
Most of the action is a mere replay of a single sequence: Wolverine and Sabretooth galloping toward one another, two immortal bros locked in eternal combat. Certainly feels like it.
It's enough to move even a Star Wars fan to tears.
Johnson has infused The Brothers Bloom with so much heart and beauty that one can and should easily overlook its discomfiting moments.
Rest assured, it gets funny. And it's thrilling, too, as the third act takes place almost entirely in the sky.
You know every tinny beat and false note by heart, from the implausible setup to the sprint-to-the-airport finish.

Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen is a bewildering, noisy, sloppy, cynical piece of work, a movie that sneers at the audience for 147 minutes and expects us to lap it up as entertainment -- and be grateful.
What is unexpected is the sincerity beneath the modest conceit that, yup, love hurts.

This deliriously foul-mouthed political satire is set sometime between 2002 and the day after tomorrow; hard to say, given that the country with which U.S. and U.K. pols want to go to war is unnamed save for its location in, you know, the Middle East.

If Ephron is to be criticized for treating Powell like a soggy sitcom creation, she (along with Streep) should be celebrated for rendering Child flesh and blood -- all passion and pleasure, even during moments of self-doubt.

Cera begins ingratiating himself into Yi's quest, but that part of the story is doomed from jump: It's entertaining for a moment, but hardly as enlightening or endearing as the from-the-heart moments surrounding it.

Marketed as a guitar summit between The Edge, Jimmy Page, and Jack White, Davis Guggenheim's affectionate, intermittently insightful behind-the-music doc is more electric triptych than meeting of the minds.
The filmmakers have painted a 1990s story with a 1970s palette, and the tone clashes with the setting, like plaid on paisley.
Highlights: Andrew Wilson as the roller girls' coach (ah, so there's the Wilson brother who can act) and the roller-derby vets (played especially well by Juliette Lewis and Kristen Wiig).
Saw with a conscience is not what the world needs.
The sex is polite, and there's not a whiff of dope.
The two-hour-and-40-minute 2012 is overstuffed with special-effects, but the Curtis clan's mad dash out of town is the closest the movie gets to actually being fun.
It's all so much raging bull.
It's a thoroughly delightful throwaway -- the kind of movie for which cable TV was made.
movie_title: Did You Hear About the Morgans? (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Nash and director Miguel Arteta try too hard; they want their movie branded a cult favorite before anyone's even seen it.
Filled with every cop-movie convention since the invention of gunpowder and curse words, Brooklyn's Finest is three movies in one, all of which you've seen before.
[T.J.] Miller's the find. He's out of this movie's league.
For a while, at least, a pitch-black (and, therefore, pitch-perfect) tale of our times.
Even at 100 minutes, this documentary about Vaughn and pals' 2005 bus tour from L.A. to Chicago (and all points in between, oy) plays a little long.
movie_title: Vince Vaughn's Wild West Comedy Show: 30 Days & 30 Nights - Hollywood to the Heartland (2008)

movie_review_blurb: While it's all so breezy and zippy and girl-power peppy, it's Keaton who makes Mad Money worth a few bucks.
As occasionally entertaining as it can be, Guantanamo Bay is essentially a bawdier -- but, sadly, dumber -- version of its precursor.
movie_title: Harold & Kumar Escape from Guantanamo Bay (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The big-screen Charlie Wilson's War, clocking in at 93 fly-by minutes, is dark and funny and mean and sexy, damned near pitch-black-perfect considering that at the end of this boozy comedy you wind up with, oh, Osama bin Laden.
It breaks no ground, but at least it doesn't bury itself beneath so much proselytizing and posing.
Charming, warming fable.
All it lacks is a laugh track -- appropriate since it also lacks a laugh.
What we get isn't so much a dismantled and rearranged puzzle-piece narrative as much as a song stripped of its verses, till all we're left with is the chorus.
A mature, informed piece of work that sticks in your head, your heart and your throat long after it's over.
A stunning piece of work -- stunningly inept, stunningly incoherent, stunningly awful in every single way imaginable.
The action gives way, time and time again, to the inaction of people sitting there, explaining why they're there and how they got there and why they're not leaving, which isn't thrilling at all.
The droll has been made dull, a most inexplicable and unfortunate turn of events for so adored a genius, goofball work as this.
movie_title: The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy (2005)

movie_review_blurb: The movie leaves us with a broad, genuine smile, not the smirk born of so many mockumentaries. This is phony, absolutely, but the good feeling it leaves behind is plenty real.
The performances all around are lousy -- histrionic and turgid, a most lethal combination.
If its story line isn't exactly novel -- a dreamer son sets off for the Big City to fulfill his destiny and make his poor parents proud -- its look is hypnotically visionary.
Beneath the sitcom sheen, there's a darker movie about broken people who use convenient, pitiful excuses to keep from growing up. You laugh at them, but you also have sympathy.
What ultimately redeems Cars from turning out a total lemon is its soul. Lasseter loves these animated inanimate objects as though they were kin, and it shows in every beautifully rendered frame.
A forgettable, formulaic comedy so predictable that seeing it and skipping it are the exact same thing.

[It] isn't an entirely unpleasant experience, which is to say it doesn't feel as though it's worn out its welcome before the second reel. It takes slightly longer before its gears begin to slip and its jokes begin to wear and its laughs begin to fade.
Smith's heart is in it, but it's sort of a broken heart now; Clerks II feels as though it was made by a man who needs a change but isn't permitted to make one.
The Ant Bully's just a little movie about a little guy who turns into a little bug for a little while, and learns some big things in the process -- and sometimes, a little can go a very long way.
There's no difference between the movie and the end-credit outtakes.
movie_title: Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby (2006)

movie_review_blurb: [The] characters don't mean anything because they don't say anything or do anything that feels rooted in the nitty-gritty of the everyday.
One of the few satisfying sports movies in which the foundation built upon a heap of clichés holds strong.
It's film noir, with too much noir for its own good.
The movie wouldn't work without someone as nondescript as Heder, because you can buy him as a do-nothing, go-nowhere man; he's perfectly, wonderfully forgettable, appropriate for a movie like this.
It feels like I've already seen Over the Hedge four times, after witnessing the parade of commercials for other junk its characters are pimping.
A note-for-note, beat-for-beat redo of its predecessor, only with all the entertaining stuff left out.
A deceptively thoughtful tale tricked up like an action movie; it's beautiful to look at but even more lovely to ruminate over.
Smith is the stale prince of charming grins and adorable asides; it's astounding that this is his first real romantic comedy, because it feels like he's been doing this shtick for years.
It's a self-satisfied, self-loathing mess that demands you adore and cheer for the very person you come to hate well before its 105 minutes are up.
It's like a perfect pop song -- that thing that makes you smile and tear up at the same time.
It's as though director Hugo Rodríguez and writer Martín Salinas watched every movie ever influenced by a Tarantino movie -- not the real thing, even -- and boiled them into something bland.
Sstirringly, thrillingly animated.
It wears out its welcome well before its halfway point, by which time you're either so tangled up in plot points you're strangling, or so bored you just wish you were being strangled.
Veers from moving to thrilling to wildly silly like a temperamental patient who has lost his meds.
But what does it all mean? Dunno and don't care, because there's nothing here to care about.
The movie works because Berg never forgets to keep his heart in the game and not just his head.
Love it or hate it, you won't be able to leave it alone.
If only the movie contained half as much life as Foxx, it would be something truly remarkable -- a movie with soul, rather than one merely about it.
You're almost tempted to laugh at Birth by the end, but by then you're too busy cursing it to bother.

Born Into This, its title taken from one of his poems, is a remarkable movie, because, like Crumb or even American Splendor, it adores the very people most of us might ignore if they passed us on the street.
The Ramones have been commodified, deified, even gentrified, but seldom have they been so thoroughly analyzed.
movie_title: End of the Century: The Story of the Ramones (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The Incredibles is beautiful to look at, but even more lovely beneath the computer-generated surfaces.

Watching it is akin to sitting next to someone else hogging the PlayStation controller as he steers a character through a maze in search of clues that lead only to more clues that finally land in a dreary dead end.
It's a love letter from a director to a ghost who still hovers over us all.
Less a story than a snapshot of a crumbling marriage populated by sitcom characters.
What's most troubling about Anderson is how lifeless his movies are getting.
movie_title: The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou (2004)

movie_review_blurb: It's great fun, but nothing more.
It's left to Barbra Streisand and Dustin Hoffman as Greg's parents to warm up the picture, and they light it on fire.
Penn's lead performance is the main attraction here, and it's a fine piece of work -- far superior to his overly showy Oscar-winning role last year.
[A] marvelous comedy tinged with substantial sadness around its edges.
Aims to be loud, dumb fun, only it takes itself too seriously to offer anything approaching a good time.
In short, it would have been great if it had stopped, oh, 12 minutes in.
It can't withstand the comparisons [to Capote]. It's good, especially during its first half, just not good enough.
The Heart of the Game is a sweet, engaging journey with the Roosevelt Roughriders, whose kindly coach encourages the girls to snarl like wolves and devour like lions.
It's the story of Patrick Chamusso, who intended no harm till harm was done to him. Fact is, he could be just about anyone anywhere -- South Africa, the Middle East, right next door.
A garish, dispiriting bit of work.
The Ten's biggest letdown are the interstitial sequences featuring Paul Rudd, [who is] usually the best thing about some of the worst movies.
This is less an adaptation of Neil Gaiman's 1999 novel than of its dust-jacket synopsis, which will come as disconcerting news to fans of the author's delicate jigsaw-puzzle fantasies.
[The King of Kong] would play like dark comedy were there not such honest-to-God cruelty at its core.
movie_title: The King of Kong: A Fistful of Quarters (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Death at a Funeral never even approaches the best of Oz's oeuvre.
Director Rod Lurie can always find the overwrought in the mundane.
Like many of the best movies about war and its lingering echo, The Hunting Party is full of dark humor.
Woodcock's a strictly flaccid family affair.

Hard to tell what's more annoying in this empty character study of eccentrics and the suckers who love them: the braying, blurting soundtrack or Douglas himself, who can't find his way into a man tortured by dull demons.

[Goldthwait] handles it beautifully, crafting from such rough stuff something astoundingly sweet and sharply funny about forgiveness, unconditional love, tenderness, and the things we hide just to get ourselves from one day to the next.
The thing's so charming and frothy and delightful and sentimental and beautifully shot and well-acted and sincere that it takes a good couple of hours before you start craving real nourishment.
It will no doubt be said time and again of Michael Clayton: best John Grisham adaptation ever.
This is as much a thoughtful meditation on the plight of the American farmer as it is a rant against our expanding waistlines.
The movie's just not very scary.
Sheen, like the movie itself, is trying too hard to inspire when the story doesn't need the help.
One could fill this entire space with the titles of films from which writer-director Peter Hedges nicks his story.
Martian Child certainly isn't much fun, unless you were desperately awaiting K-PAX with a kid instead of Kevin Spacey.
...what could have been a condescending descent into bottom-feeding turns into a loving, often heartbreaking portrait of decent people trying to scrape by.
Rock has but two scenes in the film, but he needs a hundred more. Give the man his own movie, please, if only because it'd bee far better than this one.
Easily the worst adaptation of a major novel by a Nobel Prize-winning author.
movie_title: Love in the Time of Cholera (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Enchanted isn't something to get worked up over -- not only because it's so boring, but because it can't even be bothered to adhere to its own internal logic.
By the end, it's unexpectedly moving without ever once trolling for crocodile tears. It's a sneak attack.
Highbrow camp masquerading as a history lesson soapier than any bottle of detergent.
This is PG-rated proselytizing tinged with Al Gore self-righteousness, all with the narrative thrust of a film about the apocalypse starring Kirk Cameron.
...it's amazing how something so cold is expected to generate so much heat.
Bloody disappointing.
The horror wouldn't work without Cusack, who makes what could have been a rote acting exercise -- Be tough! Now angry! Now defensively funny! -- a cathartic ritual instead.
Tenacious D is utterly harmless and totally pointless. Black and Gass have been at this so long their dirty little joke has all the punch of a Catskills routine.
movie_title: Tenacious D in The Pick of Destiny (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The movie, the first English-language film directed by Italian Gabriele Muccino, is too emotionally slick to work, too visually glib to have an impact.
As long as it is, Shepherd speeds through its leading man's life, cramming in 30 years without elaborating on any of them.
The first half-hour's too slow; the last half-hour's too manic, as if to compensate. But at least it entertains.
Everyone's a predator in this tale.
If nothing else, Alpha Dog's worth a look for the performance of Justin Timberlake, the moral center of a movie sorely in need of some conscience.
Seraphim Falls has decent pep in its step until the final 30 minutes.
It's not interested in cheap thrills or playing gotcha with the audience. (Which isn't to say parts of it aren't exhilarating.)
Writer-director Marc Lawrence foists upon his film a rather preposterous meet-cute that renders a promising premise about comebacks and rare second chances predictable and innocuous.

This movie works precisely because it's bereft of modern cinema's cynicism -- that above-it-all sneer that permeates most of the well-intentioned kiddie films made more to hold parents' attention than their children's.
To say Casino Royale ranks among the best Bond offerings is not intended as backhanded praise.

The feature debut from South African director Sunu Gonera is straight from the sports-film playbook, the one in which an underdog team coached by an obstinate overachiever overcomes obstacles and adversity to take home the gold.
This shallow comedy imagines itself as an amalgam of St. Elmo's Fire, The Wild Bunch, and Deliverance.
The magic of the movie is how utterly wrenching it renders [its] songs, which thrive alongside the film's simple, eloquent, dusky narrative.

Betsy Blankenbaker's film doesn't possess the kinetic charge of the tale itself; it's too reliant on talking heads and faded photos. In short, Cheer feels amateurish for a generation raised on sports films.
This isn't to diminish The Valet's good times, only to admit that it'll inevitably wind up with an English-language makeover and an 8 p.m. slot on ABC.
It's a little gloomier, a little coarser, and a lot more cerebral -- oh, and funnier than all the Reno 911! boxed sets combined.
It's a sincere meditation on adulthood, accountability, and fidelity -- and, yeah, getting high.
It's not the big picture that charms here, it's the details. More than anything, though, it's Costanzo -- a spindly Everydork who grows up not because he has to, but because he just kinda wants to.
Ironically, Disturbia's a thriller that doesn't want to bother you.

Gordon-Levitt's worth the admission all by his lonesome. He's that good - the proverbial young man with an old soul who brings unexpected depth, complexity, and sincerity to what could have been just another damaged-guy role. He's the one to look out for.
Narrative's beside the point in a movie created by two guys who gorge on pop culture's high-fat diet and regurgitate it into something approaching . . . art? Close enough.
movie_title: Aqua Teen Hunger Force Colon Movie Film for Theaters (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A cast of bright young stars and a promising new filmmaker transform XOXO into a fun, light-hearted romp that delivers a rare win for films based on the world of electronic dance music.
Renee Zellweger returns to her Oscar-nominated role without missing a beat, finally redeeming the character after her lacklustre sophomore appearance.
A promising setup yields nothing but a cliche story and endless logic gaps in When The Bough Breaks, a film with two lead actors who deserve far better material.
Ostensibly a tragic tale of out-of-control youth, White Girl collapses under its lofty ambitions, boiling down to little more than a retread of other, better films.
Tom Hanks turns in a beautifully restrained performance in Sully, but despite some memorable sequences, the plodding script feels padded even at barely over 90 minutes.
A hit-and-miss story is countered by a creative, though imperfect, vision and strong lead performances in Zoom.
My Blind Brother is an effective vehicle for its stars, but it never truly gels as a particularly compelling narrative with something meaningful to say.
Hands of Stone works so hard to convince moviegoers of its inspirational relevance that it ends up feeling like an empty collection of genre conventions.
Even an international superstar like Jason Statham can't save Mechanic: Resurrection from being a bland, pointless and uninspired action sequel.

Laika brings another visually dazzling epic to the screen with Kubo and the Two Strings, and while the narrative isn't the studio's finest, its stylish execution and thematic heft neatly pick up the slack.

The comedy in Mike and Dave Need Wedding Dates may not have a 100% success rate, but at least the charming cast - especially Adam Devine and Aubrey Plaza - manage to make it a worthwhile time at the movies.
movie_title: Mike and Dave Need Wedding Dates (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Though it takes liberties with the source material, The Little Prince enriches the novella on which it is based, developing its themes and characters into one of the best animated releases of the year.

Moviegoers hoping for a more traditional cinematic take on war may be turned off by just how quiet and contemplative Neither Heaven Nor Earth is, but those prepared for a more philosophical take will walk away satisfied.
movie_title: Neither Heaven nor Earth (Ni le ciel ni la terre) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Ellen Page and Allison Janney turn in compelling performances as two very different but equally troubled women, but Tallulah's story doesn't do justice to its cast.

Despite an opening act that adds some dead weight to the otherwise stellar tale, the voice talents of Kevin Conroy and Mark Hamill make The Killing Joke a must-see for Batman fans. Just keep it away from the kids.
Despite its worthwhile subtext, No Stranger Than Love fails in execution, dooming star Alison Brie with subpar material and a severely underwritten lead role.

This by-the-numbers buddy cop film offers little in the way of laughs or suspense, proving to be nothing more than a missed opportunity for its cast and crew to present a worthy addition to the genre.

Even though Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows may not inspire many new adult fans into the turtles' world, it delivers a vastly improved follow-up to the 2014 reboot and a fun sci-fi action/adventure in its own right.
movie_title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Code of Honor is a cliche-ridden mess that offers neither satisfying action nor a compelling story, proving that star Steven Seagal has certainly seen better days.

Those who are curious about what Ratchet & Clank has to offer are better off picking up a controller and experiencing the adventure for themselves. It's certainly going to yield a better time than this forgettable misfire.
Though it doesn't break any new ground, The Siege of Jadotville is a well-crafted piece of filmmaking that investigates the often-contentious relationship between politics and war.
Meryl Streep (of course) delivers yet another solid performance, but Florence Foster Jenkins gets a bit too lost in the balancing act between comedy and drama to emerge a bonafide winner.
Sarah Paulson and Mark Duplass shine in Blue Jay, a charming nostalgia trip tackling heady themes in a manner that is both lovingly awkward and brutally real.
In his big screen debut, Captain Underpants brings a much-needed irreverence and tongue in cheek sense of adventure to the superhero genre that should please more than just its target audience.
movie_title: Captain Underpants: The First Epic Movie (Captain Underpants) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Ordinary World - the first starring role for Green Day's Billie Joe Armstrong - may feature a conventional story, but it counters that with tons of heart and solid performances throughout.
Daniel Radcliffe does what he can to elevate the survival story at the heart of Jungle, but the film's awkward pacing and over-reliance on cliche hold him back.
The latest Denis Villeneuve achievement, Blade Runner 2049 is the rare sequel that both pushes the franchise to challenging new places and serves as a natural extension of what's come before.
Following The Mummy, American Made is easily the best Tom Cruise film of 2017, though it never strikes quite the right tone for the story it's trying to tell.
Lacking in imagination or genuine scares, Jeepers Creepers 3 falls tragically short on just about every front.
It may not quite reach the heights of Raimi's Spider-Man 2, but Spider-Man: Homecoming emerges as one of the character's strongest films to date, granting him a clean slate and infinite room to grow.

Despite a tacked-on framing device that mostly falls flat, Kevin Hart: What Now? proves to be a laugh riot thanks to the comedian's high-energy delivery and the broad spectrum of relatable topics he integrates into his set.
Just when you thought Sandler couldn't embarrass himself any further, he drops the laughless mess known as Sandy Wexler on Netflix subscribers.
Going in Style doesn't bring much imagination or innovation to the world of crime comedies, but its legendary stars enhance the experience enough to make it passable entertainment.

A blatant attempt to apply the winning 21 Jump Street formula to another television property, CHIPS instead winds up a standard hard-R action comedy that audiences will probably forget by the time they leave the theater.

A cast of reliable performers slum it in this by-the-numbers action thriller.

A listless cast and a crushingly flat script fail to illuminate the lives of high-wire electrical workers in Life on the Line, which instead resorts to tired story beats and a false sense of self-righteousness.
Idris Elba makes a dynamite action star, but this politically charged thriller doesn't give him the support he needs to become the next Liam Neeson.

Based on the popular toy line, Trolls bears all the earmarks of a blatant cash-in on a recognizable property, with little imagination to speak of and predictable creative choices from beginning to end.
While The Ivory Game's ambitiously broad look at the illegal ivory trade takes on a bit more than it needs to, it does shed some definite light on a growing global problem.
Leonardo DiCaprio takes viewers on a global tour exploring the ramifications of - and possible solutions to - climate change, and Before the Flood makes a compelling case for immediate action.
Keanu Reeves effectively anchors The Whole Truth, but a capable cast can only do so much to keep the lingering mystery afloat before logic weighs it down.

This new take on the beloved cult classic halfheartedly stages a "reimagining" of The Rocky Horror Picture Show but forgets both the humanity in its characters and the distinct tone that made it a sensation in the first place.

Disney's Tarzan is not only the summer's most thrilling mainstream movie so far, it's also the best animated feature the studio has put out since The Lion King.

movie_title: A Kid in King Arthur's Court (1995)

movie_review_blurb: What makes this wildly imaginative setup so much fun is the contrast between the deadpan gruffness of Jones and Torn, and the spectacularly strange environment in which they work.

Though it's a tad too schematic, Heat, written and directed by Michael Mann, provides a venue for white-hot acting by De Niro and Pacino.
Big Daddy is easily the laziest, most slapdash and altogether crummy picture Sandler's done to date.
This prison dramedy's muddled, episodic script seems to have gone on a hunger strike for humor!

Crowe draws terrific performances from the entire cast. And his magnificent dialogue limns emotional nuances and delicate truths rarely touched on in big-budget Hollywood movies, making Jerry Maguire a thoroughly unexpected pleasure.

American Beauty is a flat-out masterpiece, surely the best movie of the year; indeed, an all-time classic.

The English Patient's considerable pleasures are chiefly aesthetic, not emotional.

Ransom benefits handsomely from a story that remains compellingly believable, even as the plot twists become more baroque. Be warned, though, that Ransom is a violent film, with bloody shootouts that will not be easy to watch.

A romance that is not particularly romantic.
A hodgepodge of influences and devices without its own look or effective narrative structure.
